metadata.description: Reviewed annotations for all 40 cases from thresh_format/review

evidences: On February 28, 2023, the United States government filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.

Plaintiff sued Defendant Denka under Section 303 of the Clean Air Act, 42 U.S.C. § 7603, alleging that Defendant Denka's chloroprene emissions from its neoprene manufacturing facility in LaPlace, Louisiana, posed an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health across communities in St. John the Baptist Parish.
Cause of Action.value: Clean Air Act § 303 (42 U.S.C. § 7603) imminent and substantial endangerment action for injunctive relief against Denka.

evidences: Plaintiff sued Defendant DuPont under Fed. R. Civ. P. 19(a) and the All Writs Act, 28 U.S.C. § 1651, as Defendant Denka may need permission or cooperation from Defendant DuPont to take the necessary actions to abate the imminent and substantial endangerment posed by its current chloroprene emissions.
Cause of Action.value: Fed. R. Civ. P. 19(a) and All Writs Act (28 U.S.C. § 1651) used to join/bind DuPont to ensure cooperation with injunctive relief.

evidences: Defendant Denka argued that the Plaintiff’s issuance and application of its 2010 rule, which set the acceptable limits of chloroprene, was “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and not in accordance with the law” in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), because the rule makers failed to consider and ignored the best available scientific data, as well as new scientific models, despite concerns raised by qualified peer reviewers.
Defendants sought declaratory relief and injunctive relief enjoining Plaintiff from using the 2010 rule until it reconsidered the rule in light of the new evidence.
Cause of Action.value: Administrative Procedure Act (APA) counterclaim challenging EPA’s 2010 rule as arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and not in accordance with law; seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.

evidences: The same day, Defendant Denka filed a petition for review of the new rule in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, arguing that this new rule was arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and not in accordance with law (docket no. 24-01135).
Cause of Action.value: New 2024 EPA rule on chlorprene emissions caused Defendant Denka to file a petition for review to the U.S Court of Appeals in the D.C. Circuit as Denka perceived the rule as arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and not in accordance with law

evidences: Plaintiff argued that until Defendant Denka complied with the new rule, thousands of Parish residents would continue to be exposed to high levels of chloroprene emissions, exposing them to a higher risk of cancer.
Cause of Action.value: Plaintiff cause of action: Until Defendant Denka complied, thousands of Parish residents would be exposed to high levels of chloroprene, increasing their risk for cancer.

evidences: Plaintiff sued Defendant Denka under Section 303 of the Clean Air Act, 42 U.S.C. § 7603, alleging that Defendant Denka's chloroprene emissions from its neoprene manufacturing facility in LaPlace, Louisiana, posed an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health across communities in St. John the Baptist Parish.
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: Section 303 of the Clean Air Act, 42 U.S.C. § 7603 (imminent and substantial endangerment claim)

evidences: Plaintiff sued Defendant DuPont under Fed. R. Civ. P. 19(a) and the All Writs Act, 28 U.S.C. § 1651, as Defendant Denka may need permission or cooperation from Defendant DuPont to take the necessary actions to abate the imminent and substantial endangerment posed by its current chloroprene emissions.
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: All Writs Act, 28 U.S.C. § 1651 (to compel cooperation with injunctive relief)

evidences: Defendant Denka argued that the Plaintiff’s issuance and application of its 2010 rule, which set the acceptable limits of chloroprene, was “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and not in accordance with the law” in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA),

The same day, Defendant Denka filed a petition for review of the new rule in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, arguing that this new rule was arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and not in accordance with law
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: Administrative Procedure Act (APA) — arbitrary and capricious challenges to EPA’s 2010 chloroprene standard and the 2024 rule

evidences: Plaintiff sought injunctive relief requiring that Defendant Denka immediately reduce its chloroprene emissions to levels that no longer cause or contribute to unacceptably high cancer risks within the communities surrounding the facility.
Remedy Sought.value: Injunctive relief requiring Denka to immediately reduce chloroprene emissions to levels that do not cause or contribute to unacceptably high cancer risks in surrounding communities.

evidences: Plaintiff also sought an injunctive relief ordering Defendant DuPont to authorize and not impede construction and necessary measures for Defendant Denka to comply with the court’s order.
Remedy Sought.value: Injunctive relief ordering DuPont to authorize and not impede construction and other necessary measures enabling Denka to comply with the court’s order.

evidences: On March 20, 2023, Plaintiff filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting the court to order Defendant Denka to implement significant pollution controls to reduce chloroprene emissions promptly.
Remedy Sought.value: Preliminary injunction compelling Denka to implement significant pollution controls promptly to reduce chloroprene emissions.

evidences: Defendants sought declaratory relief and injunctive relief enjoining Plaintiff from using the 2010 rule until it reconsidered the rule in light of the new evidence.
Remedy Sought.value: Declaratory relief and injunctive relief (counterclaim) enjoining the United States from using the EPA’s 2010 chloroprene rule until it is reconsidered in light of new evidence.

evidences: Plaintiff further sought a status hearing and to reset the case for trial.
The Parties attended a status conference on November 21 to discuss the future of the case.
Remedy Sought.value: Plaintiff sought status conference to reset the case for trial; granted and held November 21, 2024

evidences: This case challenges the carcinogenic chloroprene emissions from Denka Performance Elastomer, LLC’s (Denka’s) neoprene manufacturing facility at the Pontchartrain Works Site in St. John the Baptist Parish, Louisiana, as being unacceptably high under EPA regulations.

This case challenges the carcinogenic chloroprene emissions from Denka Performance Elastomer, LLC’s (Denka’s) neoprene manufacturing facility at the Pontchartrain Works Site in St. John the Baptist Parish, Louisiana, as being unacceptably high under EPA regulations.
The case was assigned to Judge Eldon E. Fallon and Magistrate Judge Michael North.
The case was assigned to Judge Eldon E. Fallon and Magistrate Judge Michael North.
The case was later reassigned to Judge Carl J Barbier.

On July 1, 2024, the petition for review was consolidated with another petition for review (docket no. 24-1228). The following week, the court consolidated more cases (24-1249, 24-1250, 24-1251, 24-1252) with 24-1135.

The case was officially dismissed on March 10.

evidences: Denka Performance Elastomer, LLC’s (Denka’s) neoprene manufacturing facility at the Pontchartrain Works Site in St. John the Baptist Parish, Louisiana

Plaintiff sued Denka Performance Elastomer LLC, the owner and operator of a neoprene manufacturing facility, and DuPont Specialty Products, the owner of the land on which the neoprene manufacturing facility was located and leased to Defendant Denka.
its neoprene manufacturing facility in LaPlace, Louisiana
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves emissions from Denka’s neoprene manufacturing facility at the Pontchartrain Works Site in St. John the Baptist Parish (LaPlace), Louisiana; Denka operates the facility and DuPont owns the land.

evidences: emitting chloroprene—a chemical classified by the EPA in 2010 as likely carcinogenic to humans.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The pollutant at issue is chloroprene, which the EPA classified in 2010 as likely carcinogenic to humans.

evidences: Air monitoring near the facility reportedly detected chloroprene concentrations up to 14 times the EPA's recommended levels, posing a risk to the majority-Black population surrounding the facility.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Air monitoring detected chloroprene concentrations up to 14 times EPA-recommended levels near the facility, indicating elevated exposure risk in nearby communities.

evidences: Air monitoring near the facility reportedly detected chloroprene concentrations up to 14 times the EPA's recommended levels, posing a risk to the majority-Black population surrounding the facility.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The impacted community surrounding the facility is majority-Black, which the monitoring results suggest is at heightened cancer risk.

evidences: This case challenges the carcinogenic chloroprene emissions from Denka Performance Elastomer,

as being unacceptably high under EPA regulations. Denka's facility produced neoprene, a synthetic rubber, emitting chloroprene—a chemical classified by the EPA in 2010 as likely carcinogenic to humans.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The carcinogenic chloroprene emissions from Denka in their production of neoprene were reported as too high under EPA regulations.

evidences: as Defendant Denka may need permission or cooperation from Defendant DuPont to take the necessary actions to abate the imminent and substantial endangerment posed by its current chloroprene emissions.
Plaintiff also sought an injunctive relief ordering Defendant DuPont to authorize and not impede construction and necessary measures for Defendant Denka to comply with the court’s order.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Because DuPont owns the site, the United States alleged Denka might need DuPont’s cooperation to implement emission control measures; Plaintiff sought an order requiring DuPont to authorize and not impede needed measures.

evidences: On February 28, 2023, the United States government filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.

Plaintiff sued Defendant Denka under Section 303 of the Clean Air Act, 42 U.S.C. § 7603, alleging that Defendant Denka's chloroprene emissions from its neoprene manufacturing facility in LaPlace, Louisiana, posed an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health across communities in St. John the Baptist Parish.
Factual Basis of Case.value: On February 28, 2023, the United States sued Denka in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana under Clean Air Act §303, alleging its chloroprene emissions posed an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health in St. John the Baptist Parish.

evidences: Defendant Denka argued that the Plaintiff’s issuance and application of its 2010 rule, which set the acceptable limits of chloroprene, was “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and not in accordance with the law” in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), because the rule makers failed to consider and ignored the best available scientific data, as well as new scientific models, despite concerns raised by qualified peer reviewers.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Denka’s counter-evidence position: the EPA’s 2010 chloroprene standard was allegedly arbitrary and unsupported by the best available science and models.

evidences: Defendant DuPont argued that it was not involved in any of the alleged harmful activity, nor had Plaintiff identified any actual or immediate current harm that would occur if Defendant DuPont were not included as a Party in this action.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Defendant DuPont argued that it had no immediate involvement in the matter and should not be included as a Party in this action.

evidences: Specifically, Plaintiff argued that Defendant Denka's challenges to the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) actions were time-barred and that certain EPA decisions were committed to agency discretion, thus not subject to judicial review.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiff reasoned that Defendant Denka's counterclaim was time-barred and that certain EPA decisions were at the discretion of the agency, making it not subject to judicial review.

evidences: On May 16, 2024, the EPA published a new rule titled “New Source Performance Standards for the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturing Industry and National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants for the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturing Industry and Group I & II Polymers and Resins Industry” (89 Fed. Reg. 42932). This rule updated and amended existing standards to control emissions of hazardous air pollutants, including chloroprene emissions, from manufacturing facilities. Specifically, the new rule imposed stricter emission standards on facilities that produce or use chloroprene, requiring the application of advanced control technologies to minimize emissions.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background regulatory development: In May 2024, EPA issued a new rule imposing stricter chloroprene emission standards and requiring advanced control technologies at relevant facilities.

evidences: The Parties attended a status conference on November 21 to discuss the future of the case.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Parties attended a November 21 status conference.

evidences: On February 28, 2023, the United States government filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.

Plaintiff sued Denka Performance Elastomer LLC, the owner and operator of a neoprene manufacturing facility, and DuPont Specialty Products, the owner of the land on which the neoprene manufacturing facility was located and leased to Defendant Denka.

Plaintiff sought injunctive relief requiring that Defendant Denka immediately reduce its chloroprene emissions to levels that no longer cause or contribute to unacceptably high cancer risks within the communities surrounding the facility.
Plaintiff also sought an injunctive relief ordering Defendant DuPont to authorize and not impede construction and necessary measures for Defendant Denka to comply with the court’s order.
Note Important Filings.value: Complaint filed by United States on 2023-02-28 in E.D. La. under CAA § 303 against Denka and DuPont, seeking injunctive relief to reduce chloroprene emissions and to require DuPont’s authorization/non-interference.

evidences: On March 20, 2023, Plaintiff filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting the court to order Defendant Denka to implement significant pollution controls to reduce chloroprene emissions promptly. The motion emphasized the urgency of protecting the health of the local community. ​
Note Important Filings.value: Plaintiff’s motion for preliminary injunction filed on 2023-03-20 to require Denka to promptly implement significant pollution controls (ruling not stated).

evidences: In response, Defendant Denka filed a counterclaim against the Plaintiff. Defendant Denka argued that the Plaintiff’s issuance and application of its 2010 rule, which set the acceptable limits of chloroprene, was “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and not in accordance with the law” in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), because the rule makers failed to consider and ignored the best available scientific data, as well as new scientific models, despite concerns raised by qualified peer reviewers. Defendants sought declaratory relief and injunctive relief enjoining Plaintiff from using the 2010 rule until it reconsidered the rule in light of the new evidence.
Note Important Filings.value: Denka filed a counterclaim challenging the EPA’s 2010 chloroprene rule under the APA, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.

evidences: On May 2, 2023, Defendant DuPont filed a motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction and failure to state a claim. Defendant DuPont argued that it was not involved in any of the alleged harmful activity, nor had Plaintiff identified any actual or immediate current harm that would occur if Defendant DuPont were not included as a Party in this action. The court denied this motion.
Note Important Filings.value: DuPont filed a motion to dismiss on 2023-05-02

evidences: On May 4, 2023, Plaintiff filed a motion to dismiss Defendant Denka's counterclaims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.
Note Important Filings.value: (May 4, 2023) Plaintiff filed motion to dismiss counterclaims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction

evidences: and Plaintiff filed this motion again on May 8.
Note Important Filings.value: (May 8, 2023) Plaintiff re-filed the same motion (second time) to dismiss Defendant Denka's counterclaims with the same rationale

evidences: On May 9, Plaintiff filed a third motion to dismiss with the same reasoning as the first.
Note Important Filings.value: (May 9, 2025) Plaintiff re-filed the same motion (third time) to dismiss Defendant Denka's counterclaims with same rationale

evidences: On October 25, 2023, Defendant Denka filed an amended counterclaim.

This new counterclaim added new additional allegations and facts about how Plaintiff had disregarded substantial scientific evidence that adopting the 2010 standard as a bright-line rule was not necessary to protect human health or the environment.
Note Important Filings.value: (October 25, 2023) Defendant Denka filed an amended counterclaim, that included new allegations and facts about how Plaintiff had disregarded new scientific evidence that the standard used to back Plaintiff's claims against Denka were not necessary to protect human health and the environment

evidences: Defendant Denka refiled on November 3, 2023.
Note Important Filings.value: (November 3, 2023) Defendant Denka refiled the amended counterclaim

evidences: Shortly after, Plaintiff filed a motion to dismiss the amended counterclaim for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.
On January 10, 2025 granted the motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction and dismissed the counterclaim with prejudice.
Note Important Filings.value: Plaintiff filed a motion to dismiss the amended counterclaim for lack of subject matter jurisdiction; granted and counterclaim dismissed with prejudice on Jan. 10, 2025

evidences: The following month, Defendant Denka filed a motion for summary judgment on December 29. In its motion, Defendant emphasized that its chloroprene emissions posed a cancer risk of 5-in-10,000 to a person who breathed in these emissions all day, every day for 70 years. Defendant argued that this risk did not amount to an “imminent and substantial endangerment” warranting the chloroprene emission limitations imposed by the 2010 rule.
Note Important Filings.value: (December 12, 2023) Defendant Denka filed a motion for summary judgement arguing no “imminent and substantial endangerment”

evidences: The same day, Defendant DuPont filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings. The court denied the motion in July 2024, as Defendant offered no new grounds to warrant its dismissal from the case beyond those already denied by the Defendant’s motion to dismiss.
Note Important Filings.value: (December 12, 2023) Defendant DuPont filed a motion for judgement on the pleadings

evidences: On May 16, 2024, the EPA published a new rule titled “New Source Performance Standards for the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturing Industry and National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants for the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturing Industry and Group I & II Polymers and Resins Industry” (89 Fed. Reg. 42932).

The same day, Defendant Denka filed a petition for review of the new rule in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, arguing that this new rule was arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, and not in accordance with law (docket no. 24-01135).
Note Important Filings.value: (May 16, 2024) Denka filed a petition for review (No. 24-1135) of EPA’s May 16, 2024 rule in the D.C. Circuit

evidences: Meanwhile, on June 11, several nonprofits (including the Concerned Citizens of St. John, Rise St. James Louisiana, Louisiana Environmental Action Network, Texas Environmental Justice Advocacy Services, Air Alliance Houston, California Communities Against Toxics, Environmental Defense Fund, Environment Integrity Project, and Sierra Club) filed a motion to intervene in the petition for review of the new EPA rule.
Note Important Filings.value: (June 11, 2024) Nonprofit groups filed a motion to intervene in the D.C. Circuit petition filed by Denka

evidences: On September 17, 2024, Plaintiff filed a motion to reopen the case.
Note Important Filings.value: (September 17, 2024) Plaintiff filed a motion to reopen the district court case

evidences: On March 7, 2025, Plaintiff filed a motion to voluntarily dismiss the case.
Note Important Filings.value: (March 07, 2025) Plaintiff filed motion to voluntarily dismiss case

evidences: The case was assigned to Judge Eldon E. Fallon and Magistrate Judge Michael North. The case was later reassigned to Judge Carl J Barbier.
Trials.value: Trial judge assignment: first Judge Eldon E. Fallon and Magistrate Judge Michael North. later reassigned to Judge Carl J. Barbier

evidences: On May 31, the Parties attended a status conference to discuss how the new rule would affect the ongoing litigation, and Defendant Denka proposed to hold the case in abeyance until October 15, to determine whether the new rule would render the current litigation moot. The Parties filed status reports throughout the summer.
Trials.value: Status conference held May 31, 2024; Denka proposed holding the case in abeyance until October 15, 2024, affecting trial scheduling.

evidences: On March 7, 2025, Plaintiff filed a motion to voluntarily dismiss the case. The Trump administration stated that this decision aligned with efforts to dismantle "radical Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) programs" and ensure unbiased law enforcement (Justice Dept. says ending Louisiana petrochemical case helps ‘dismantle radical DEI programs’ [https://www.google.com/url?q=https://apnews.com/article/trump-louisiana-cancer-denka-chloroprene-epa-lawsuit-89b1f870816f65370eeb75ff269e9c0e&sa=D&source=docs&ust=1743371953208062&usg=AOvVaw347nD5ij_RdIBBz8L0b3GS]). The case was officially dismissed on March 10.
This case is now closed.
Trials.value: No trial was held; the case was voluntarily dismissed and officially closed on March 10, 2025.

evidences: On May 2, 2023, Defendant DuPont filed a motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction and failure to state a claim.
The court denied this motion.
Court Rulings.value: Denied—DuPont’s motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction and failure to state a claim (filed May 2, 2023).

evidences: It was deemed deficient,

Court Rulings.value: Denied—DuPont’s motion for judgment on the pleadings (denied July 2024).

evidences: The court granted in part the motion to reopen the case.
Court Rulings.value: Granted in part—Plaintiff’s motion to reopen the case.

evidences: On January 10, 2025 granted the motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction and dismissed the counterclaim with prejudice.
Court Rulings.value: District Court granted Plaintiff's motion to dismiss Denka's counterclaim for lack of jurisdiction

evidences: On March 7, 2025, Plaintiff filed a motion to voluntarily dismiss the case.
The case was officially dismissed on March 10.
Court Rulings.value: Granted—Plaintiff’s motion for voluntary dismissal; case dismissed (Mar. 10, 2025).

evidences: On May 15, 2025, the Oregon Council for the Humanities and the Federation of State Humanities Councils filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against DOGE and its Acting Administrator, the NEH and its Acting Chairman, and the National Council on the Humanities.

They argued that the termination of the grants violated the National Council on the Humanities' grant statute, the Administrative Procedure Act, and the Separation of Powers, and exceeded DOGE's legal authority.

finding that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims, specifically citing violations of the Separation of Powers doctrine, the Impoundment Control Act, and the Administrative Procedure Act.
Cause of Action.value: Administrative Procedure Act (APA) claim challenging the grant terminations and procedures

evidences: They argued that the termination of the grants violated the National Council on the Humanities' grant statute, the Administrative Procedure Act, and the Separation of Powers, and exceeded DOGE's legal authority.

They argued that these actions violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the Separation of Powers, as Congress, not the President, has the power to create agencies and direct how federal funds are spent.

finding that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims, specifically citing violations of the Separation of Powers doctrine, the Impoundment Control Act, and the Administrative Procedure Act.

evidences: Represented by private counsel, the plaintiffs sought an order directing the NEH to follow proper procedures for grant applications and funding, to continue providing funds appropriated by Congress to the Federation's members, and to set aside the unlawful termination of grants.

evidences: This case challenges the alleged illegal termination of grant money for state and jurisdictional humanities councils by the United States DOGE Service.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case overview: The US DOGE Service is challenged due to the alleged illegal termination of grant money for state and jurisdictional humanities councils.

evidences: The National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) was established by Congress in 1965 with the declaration that "The arts and the humanities belong to all the people of the United States". The goal was to provide funding for research, publication of scholarly works, and the promotion of the humanities. Congress also created a statutory framework to protect the agency from political influence.
In 1972, Congress amended the NEH statutes to create grants-in-aid programs for each state and territory, which led to the funding of state and jurisdictional humanities councils.

The Federation of State Humanities Councils, founded in 1977, is a non-profit organization that includes almost all of the 56 state and jurisdictional humanities councils as members. The Federation's mission is to advocate for increased investment in and engagement with this national network, and to support and amplify the work of its members.
An example is the Oregon Council for the Humanities (Oregon Humanities), a non-profit corporation created in 1971 to distribute NEH funds for public humanities projects throughout Oregon.
Factual Basis of Case.value: NEH was created by Congress in 1965 with a protective statutory framework; in 1972, Congress established grants-in-aid funding state and jurisdictional humanities councils. The Federation of State Humanities Councils (founded 1977) represents nearly all councils, and Oregon Humanities (created 1971) distributes NEH funds in Oregon.

evidences: Executive Order 14158, signed on January 20, 2025, by President Trump, created the "United States DOGE Service" (DOGE) as part of the Executive Office of the President.

Following the order, the chair of the NEH was directed to resign in March 2025, and the NEH was allegedly instructed to review grants issued since 2021 for potential violations of new executive orders.
This review allegedly resulted in the termination of nearly all grants to state and jurisdictional councils in March and April 2025, halting their operations and prompting the filing of this lawsuit.
Factual Basis of Case.value: EO 14158 created DOGE on Jan. 20, 2025; thereafter the NEH chair was directed to resign, NEH was allegedly told to review grants since 2021, and that review allegedly led to termination of nearly all state/jurisdictional council grants in March–April 2025, halting operations.

evidences: On May 15, 2025, the Oregon Council for the Humanities and the Federation of State Humanities Councils filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against DOGE and its Acting Administrator, the NEH and its Acting Chairman, and the National Council on the Humanities.

They argued that the termination of the grants violated the National Council on the Humanities' grant statute, the Administrative Procedure Act, and the Separation of Powers, and exceeded DOGE's legal authority.

Represented by private counsel, the plaintiffs sought an order directing the NEH to follow proper procedures for grant applications and funding, to continue providing funds appropriated by Congress to the Federation's members, and to set aside the unlawful termination of grants.
The case was assigned to Judge Michael Howard Simon.
Factual Basis of Case.value: On May 15, 2025, Oregon Humanities and the Federation sued DOGE, NEH, and the National Council on the Humanities in the District of Oregon, alleging statutory, APA, and Separation of Powers violations and seeking orders to restore and continue congressionally appropriated grant funding; the case was assigned to Judge Michael H. Simon.

evidences: The plaintiffs alleged that DOGE illegally “gutted the NEH and terminated almost all grants issued to the state and jurisdictional councils” without reasoned analysis or proper notice and opportunity to appeal as required by law.

They argued that these actions violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the Separation of Powers, as Congress, not the President, has the power to create agencies and direct how federal funds are spent.

The plaintiffs claimed that the NEH could not refuse to spend funds appropriated by Congress and that the delays and grant terminations caused “irreparable harm” to the Federation and its members, including councils terminating staff, canceling events, and risking permanent closure due to the loss of millions of dollars in already-awarded funding.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs allege DOGE unlawfully gutted NEH and terminated nearly all council grants without reasoned analysis or required notice/appeal, violating the APA and Separation of Powers. They assert NEH cannot refuse to spend appropriated funds and that terminations caused irreparable harm: staff layoffs, event cancellations, and risk of permanent closures due to loss of millions in awarded funds.

evidences: On June 25, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, arguing that they were likely to succeed on the merits.
They also claimed that they would suffer irreparable harm without the injunction, citing the need for councils to terminate staff, cancel events, and face potential permanent closure.
They also argued that the balance of equities and public interest favored the injunction, as it would prevent unlawful agency action and protect the humanities.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs assert the likelihood of success and irreparable harm (staff terminations, event cancellations, risk of closure) and that the equities/public interest favored preventing unlawful agency action.

evidences: On May 15, 2025, the Oregon Council for the Humanities and the Federation of State Humanities Councils filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against DOGE and its Acting Administrator, the NEH and its Acting Chairman, and the National Council on the Humanities.

Represented by private counsel, the plaintiffs sought an order directing the NEH to follow proper procedures for grant applications and funding, to continue providing funds appropriated by Congress to the Federation's members, and to set aside the unlawful termination of grants.
Note Important Filings.value: Complaint filed on May 15, 2025, by Oregon Council for the Humanities and the Federation of State Humanities Councils in the District of Oregon against DOGE, NEH, and the National Council on the Humanities; sought orders requiring lawful grant procedures, continued funding, and setting aside the grant terminations.

evidences: The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on June 11, 2025, underscoring the central role of federal grants in their work and including a table of congressional appropriations through 2024 to demonstrate Congress’s ongoing support for the program.

The amended complaint also added a new section addressing NEH’s purported “rescission” on June 2 of the 2025 grant terminations, contending that the rescission letters were largely boilerplate, lacked individualized analysis, and still resulted in significant funding cuts while maintaining the rescission of other types of grants.
Finally, the amended complaint introduced a new claim for relief under the Impoundment Control Act and the Appropriations Clause, asserting that the grant terminations were ultra vires.
Note Important Filings.value: Amended complaint filed on June 11, 2025; added allegations regarding NEH’s June 2 rescission letters and introduced a new claim under the Impoundment Control Act and the Appropriations Clause.

evidences: On June 25, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, arguing that they were likely to succeed on the merits. They also claimed that they would suffer irreparable harm without the injunction, citing the need for councils to terminate staff, cancel events, and face potential permanent closure. They also argued that the balance of equities and public interest favored the injunction, as it would prevent unlawful agency action and protect the humanities.

evidences: On July 7, 2025, the states of Oregon, Maryland, Washington, Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Hawai‘i, Maine, Michigan, Nevada, New Mexico, Rhode Island, Wisconsin, Vermont, and the District of Columbia filed a brief supporting the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, citing unlawful termination of NEH grants to their humanities councils. The brief emphasized the cultural and legal interests at stake, the councils’ close ties to state governments, and argued the court had jurisdiction because the claims rested on statutory and constitutional grounds, not contract law, making the Tucker Act inapplicable. It supported the plaintiffs’ showing of likely success, irreparable harm, and a public interest in preserving funding, noting specific harms such as program pauses and potential cancellation of the nation’s 250th anniversary celebrations.
Note Important Filings.value: States’ supporting brief filed on July 7, 2025, by Oregon, Maryland, Washington, Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Hawai‘i, Maine, Michigan, Nevada, New Mexico, Rhode Island, Wisconsin, Vermont, and D.C., backing the motion for a preliminary injunction.

evidences: On August 6, 2025, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims, specifically citing violations of the Separation of Powers doctrine, the Impoundment Control Act, and the Administrative Procedure Act. 2025 WL 2237478. The court rejected the defendants' argument that they had the discretion to terminate grants, emphasizing that the Executive Branch cannot refuse to spend congressionally appropriated funds. Furthermore, the court agreed that the plaintiffs would suffer irreparable harm without the injunction and that the public interest favored the injunction to prevent unlawful agency action and to protect the humanities.
Note Important Filings.value: Order granting plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction on August 6, 2025 (2025 WL 2237478); court found likely success on merits (Separation of Powers, Impoundment Control Act, APA), irreparable harm, and that public interest and equities favored relief.

evidences: This case challenged the abrupt dismantling of the federal government's primary education research agency. On April 4, 2025, the Association for Education Finance and Policy, Inc. and the Institute for Higher Education Policy filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. They sued the U.S. Department of Education under various laws, primarily the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and raised constitutional concerns. Represented by the Public Citizen Litigation Group, the plaintiffs sought a court order to stop the Department of Education's actions and to restore the functions of the research agency. They argued that the Department was acting illegally by shutting down the Institute of Education Sciences (IES), an agency created by Congress. This case was assigned to Judge Trevor N. McFadden.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves a lawsuit filed on April 4, 2025 in D.D.C. by the Association for Education Finance and Policy, Inc. and the Institute for Higher Education Policy against the U.S. Department of Education under the APA, alleging illegal shutdown of the Institute of Education Sciences and seeking to stop the Department’s actions and restore IES functions; the case was assigned to Judge Trevor N. McFadden.

evidences: According to the lawsuit, Congress established IES in 2002 to conduct and share high-quality research, statistics, and evaluations related to education from early childhood through postsecondary study.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background: Congress created IES in 2002 with a mandate to conduct and disseminate high-quality education research, statistics, and evaluations from early childhood through postsecondary education.

evidences: According to the lawsuit, Congress established IES in 2002 to conduct and share high-quality research, statistics, and evaluations related to education from early childhood through postsecondary study. The plaintiffs, organizations that rely on IES research for their work in education finance, policy, and higher education access, claimed that the Department of Education took several actions that effectively halted IES's operations. These actions included the mass cancellation of contracts that supported IES research, the elimination of approximately 90% of IES staff positions, and the termination of remote access for outside researchers to existing data. The plaintiffs argued that these actions exceeded the authority of the Department, violated specific laws, and were made without proper reasoning.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Core alleged actions: The Department of Education allegedly halted IES operations by mass-canceling research-supporting contracts, eliminating about 90% of IES staff positions, and terminating remote access for outside researchers to existing data; plaintiffs rely on IES research for their work.

evidences: Subsequently, on April 17, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a Motion for a Preliminary Injunction, detailing the harm the plaintiffs and their members were already experiencing due to the lack of access to IES data and the cancellation of research programs.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Evidence of harm alleged: Plaintiffs filed a preliminary injunction motion on April 17, 2025, detailing harms from loss of access to IES data and cancellation of research programs.

evidences: On June 3, Judge McFadden denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.
The court found that the plaintiffs were "improperly bundling together a series of actions for wholesale correction rather than challenging one 'circumscribed [and] discrete' action."

Instead of bringing a challenge to a discrete and final agency action, the plaintiffs brought a “challenge [to] an entire program by simply identifying specific allegedly-improper final agency actions within that program."
Therefore, the court found that the plaintiffs were not likely to succeed on the merits of their claims, which doomed their request for a preliminary injunction. 2025 WL 1568301.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Procedural development: On June 3, the court denied the preliminary injunction, finding the plaintiffs’ claims were an impermissible programmatic challenge rather than targeting discrete final agency action, and concluding plaintiffs were unlikely to succeed on the merits.

evidences: The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on June 18. The amended complaint challenged the termination of eight specific programs run by the Department of Education: (1) the termination of the National Postsecondary Student Aid Study;  (2) the termination of the 2020/25 Beginning Postsecondary Students Longitudinal Study; (3) the termination of the High School Longitudinal Study of 2009; (4) the termination of the High School and Beyond Longitudinal Study of 2022; (5) the termination of the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study-Kindergarten: 2024; (6) the termination of IES’s peer review program for new grant funding; (7) the termination of IES’s program for remote access to restricted-use data; and (8) the termination of processing applications for access to restricted-use data. The amended complaint added/removed factual allegations and causes of action under the APA to match the new focus of the complaint.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Refined factual focus: On June 18, plaintiffs amended their complaint to challenge eight discrete program terminations (specific longitudinal studies, peer review, and restricted-use data access programs), aligning facts and APA claims to discrete actions.

evidences: On July 2, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss, arguing that the court still lacked jurisdiction over the plaintiffs' claims under the Tucker Act, and that the plaintiffs still were making a programmatic challenge, rather than a challenge to a discrete, final agency action as required by the APA.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Defendants’ position: They moved to dismiss on July 2, arguing lack of jurisdiction under the Tucker Act and that plaintiffs continued to pursue a programmatic (non-discrete) challenge contrary to APA requirements.

evidences: The plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint on July 16.

The second amended complaint removed the challenges to two of the terminations mentioned in the first amended complaint: the National Postsecondary Student Aid Study and IES's program for remote access to restricted-use data.

The amended complaint also added more concrete allegations detailing how the remaining terminations caused harm to the plaintiffs and emphasized that the plaintiffs were challenging the final agency action of terminating the programs.
Given the second amended complaint, the court denied as moot the defendants' motion to dismiss and ordered them to file a renewed motion by August 19.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Further narrowing and evidentiary detail: On July 16, plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint removing two challenges, adding concrete allegations of harm from the remaining terminations, and emphasizing challenges to final agency terminations; the court denied the prior motion to dismiss as moot and set a new briefing schedule.

evidences: On July 2, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss, arguing that the court still lacked jurisdiction over the plaintiffs' claims under the Tucker Act, and that the plaintiffs still were making a programmatic challenge, rather than a challenge to a discrete, final agency action as required by the APA.
Trials.value: Defendants filed a motion to dismiss on July 2, arguing lack of jurisdiction under the Tucker Act and that plaintiffs’ claims remained a programmatic APA challenge.

evidences: The plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint on July 16.
Given the second amended complaint, the court denied as moot the defendants' motion to dismiss and ordered them to file a renewed motion by August 19.
Trials.value: Second amended complaint filed July 16; the court denied the prior motion to dismiss as moot and ordered a renewed motion by August 19.

evidences: On June 3, Judge McFadden denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.
The court found that the plaintiffs were "improperly bundling together a series of actions for wholesale correction rather than challenging one 'circumscribed [and] discrete' action."

The court also rejected the plaintiffs' constitutional claims, finding that they were simply repackaged APA claims to the "entire program." Since the plaintiffs' APA claims failed, so too did the constitutional claims.
Therefore, the court found that the plaintiffs were not likely to succeed on the merits of their claims, which doomed their request for a preliminary injunction. 2025 WL 1568301.
Court Rulings.value: June 3, 2025: Motion for Preliminary Injunction denied by Judge Trevor N. McFadden; court held the suit was an improper programmatic challenge rather than a discrete final agency action and rejected constitutional claims; not likely to succeed on the merits. Citation: 2025 WL 1568301.

evidences: On July 2, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss, arguing that the court still lacked jurisdiction over the plaintiffs' claims under the Tucker Act, and that the plaintiffs still were making a programmatic challenge, rather than a challenge to a discrete, final agency action as required by the APA.
Given the second amended complaint, the court denied as moot the defendants' motion to dismiss and ordered them to file a renewed motion by August 19.

evidences: The plaintiffs, represented by Children's Rights, filed this class action suit against the Oklahoma Department of Human Services (DHS) in February 2008 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Parties and filing: Children's Rights filed a class action on behalf of children against Oklahoma DHS in February 2008 in the Northern District of Oklahoma.

evidences: The complaint alleged that DHS placed children in dangerous and inappropriate placements, including extended stays in emergency shelters; failed to monitor the safety of children in DHS custody due to excessive case worker caseloads; failed to provide mental health and other behavioral services; and failed to provide legal representation.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Core factual allegations: DHS allegedly subjected children to dangerous/inappropriate placements (including extended emergency shelter stays), failed to monitor safety due to excessive caseloads, and failed to provide mental/behavioral services and legal representation.

evidences: The complaint alleged violations of the First, Fifth, Ninth, and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution, the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980, 42 U.S.C. § 621 et seq., the Adoption and Safe Families Act of 1997, 42 U.S.C. § 670 et seq., and Oklahoma state law.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Legal framework/context: Plaintiffs grounded their claims under multiple constitutional amendments, federal child welfare statutes, and Oklahoma state law.

evidences: In January 2009, Judge Gregory K. Frizzell granted the motion to dismiss claims under federal common law and the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980, but denied the motion with regard to the other claims. D.G. v. Henry, 594 F. Supp. 2d 1273 (N.D. Okl. 2009).
Factual Basis of Case.value: Procedural background: Early motion to dismiss was granted in part (federal common law and AACWA claims dismissed) and denied as to other claims, allowing key allegations to proceed.

evidences: On May 5, 2009, the court certified the class of the plaintiffs as all children who are or will be in the legal custody of the Oklahoma Department of Human Services (1) due to a report or suspicion of abuse or neglect; or (2) who are or will be adjudicated deprived due to abuse or neglect.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Class definition: All children in or entering DHS legal custody due to abuse/neglect reports or adjudications of deprivation.

evidences: The parties then engaged in extensive and contested discovery. The plaintiffs provided five expert reports and filed numerous motions to compel the defendants to produce various items.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Evidence development: Plaintiffs supported their case with five expert reports and pursued extensive discovery through motions to compel.

evidences: In November and December 2011, the court denied the motion to decertify and granted the motion for summary judgment only as to claims pertaining to rights of familial association and procedural due process. 2011 WL 6009628.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Procedural background: Class maintained; summary judgment granted only on certain due process/familial association claims, leaving the core safety and services claims for trial/settlement.

evidences: By January 2012, they negotiated an agreement providing for structural reorganization of DHS and appointed experts to oversee the development and implementation of the Compromise Settlement Agreement (CSA). After a series of fairness hearings, the court approved the CSA on February 29, 2012.

The CSA implementation plans provided that the defendant DHS would restructure its agency; improve screening, investigating, and reporting of abuse; reduce the use of emergency shelters; and reduce workloads and improve training for caseworkers.
The parties agreed to designate three individuals as Co-Neutrals to act as arbiters of any dispute arising out of the CSA and to evaluate and render judgments about DHS's ongoing compliance efforts.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Settlement framework and remedial measures: The court-approved CSA required DHS to reorganize, improve abuse screening/investigation/reporting, reduce emergency shelter use, and lower caseloads with better training, with compliance overseen by Co-Neutrals.

evidences: Additionally, on March 31, 2013, the Court ordered the defendants to pay attorneys' fees and expenses in the amount of about $6 million. 2013 WL 1343151.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Fee award context: Court awarded approximately $6 million in attorneys' fees and expenses.

evidences: Although DHS originally planned to exit from the CSA in December 2016, it was unable to do so for failure to adequately comply with its terms.

In their August 2018 report, the Co-Neutrals noted that although DHS had made important advancements over the course of its reform, those advances were not yet fully instituted, particularly with respect to manageable caseloads and an adequate array of placements for children. The report noted that in some areas, most critically safety for children in the care and custody of DHS, the department’s efforts had been inadequate.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Compliance findings as evidence of ongoing deficiencies: Co-Neutrals found continued noncompliance, especially on caseloads, placements, and child safety, preventing DHS’s exit from the CSA in 2016 and documented again in 2018.

evidences: In May 2018, the Co-Neutrals requested that the Court suspend the operations of a particular children's center for failure to comply with the CSA. The Court granted this request and DHS complied by relocating the children from that center.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Specific safety action: Operations of a children’s center were suspended for CSA noncompliance; children were relocated, evidencing concrete safety concerns.

evidences: On June 5, 2018, the court entered a judgment and terminated the case.

However, the case was reopened three years later when the parties moved to modify the settlement on December 13, 2021. This motion noted that unforeseen circumstances, namely the COVID-19 pandemic, seriously impacted the defendant’s good faith efforts to comply with the settlement agreement. As a result, the parties agreed to suspend the previously scheduled biannual good faith determinations by the Co-Neutrals during the pandemic recovery period as to some of the defendant's obligations. The court granted the motion the following day.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Case status and COVID-19 context: Case was terminated in 2018, then reopened in 2021 to modify settlement obligations due to COVID-19 impacts on compliance and to suspend certain good faith determinations.

evidences: On March 22, 2023, the Co-Neutrals determined that the Department had met the two-year continuous period of good faith requirements mandated by the CSA as to the obligations that had not been delayed by COVID-19. On April 24, 2023, the court issued an order terminating these obligations.

Two years later, on February 11, 2025, the Co-Neutrals filed a final report indicating the defendants had complied for two years with the remaining CSA obligations. A month later, on March 13, the court terminated the defendant's obligations under the CSA. The case is now closed.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Final compliance and closure: Co-Neutrals and court confirmed two-year good-faith compliance (first for non-COVID-delayed obligations in 2023, then remaining obligations in 2025), after which all CSA obligations were terminated and the case closed.

Court Rulings.value: Attorneys' fees: approximately $6 million awarded on March 31, 2013; 2013 WL 1343151.

evidences: In May 2018, the Co-Neutrals requested that the Court suspend the operations of a particular children's center for failure to comply with the CSA. The Court granted this request and DHS complied by relocating the children from that center.
Court Rulings.value: Request to suspend operations of a children's center: granted in May 2018.

evidences: However, the case was reopened three years later when the parties moved to modify the settlement on December 13, 2021.
The court granted the motion the following day.
Court Rulings.value: Motion to modify settlement: granted on December 14, 2021 (motion filed December 13, 2021).

evidences: Although DHS originally planned to exit from the CSA in December 2016, it was unable to do so for failure to adequately comply with its terms.

In their August 2018 report, the Co-Neutrals noted that although DHS had made important advancements over the course of its reform, those advances were not yet fully instituted, particularly with respect to manageable caseloads and an adequate array of placements for children. The report noted that in some areas, most critically safety for children in the care and custody of DHS, the department’s efforts had been inadequate.
Disputes Over Settlement Enforcement.value: Noncompliance delayed DHS’s exit from the CSA; Co‑Neutrals’ Aug. 2018 report found inadequate safety and incomplete progress on caseloads and placements.

evidences: In May 2018, the Co-Neutrals requested that the Court suspend the operations of a particular children's center for failure to comply with the CSA. The Court granted this request and DHS complied by relocating the children from that center.
Disputes Over Settlement Enforcement.value: Enforcement action: Due to failure to comply with CSA, the court granted Co‑Neutrals’ request to suspend a children’s center for CSA noncompliance; DHS relocated the children.

evidences: On June 5, 2018, the court entered a judgment and terminated the case. However, the case was reopened three years later when the parties moved to modify the settlement on December 13, 2021.

This motion noted that unforeseen circumstances, namely the COVID-19 pandemic, seriously impacted the defendant’s good faith efforts to comply with the settlement agreement. As a result, the parties agreed to suspend the previously scheduled biannual good faith determinations by the Co-Neutrals during the pandemic recovery period as to some of the defendant's obligations. The court granted the motion the following day.
Disputes Over Settlement Enforcement.value: Modification of enforcement due to COVID-19: Case reopened in 2021; biannual Co‑Neutral good‑faith determinations suspended for some obligations; court granted the modification.

evidences: On March 22, 2023, the Co-Neutrals determined that the Department had met the two-year continuous period of good faith requirements mandated by the CSA as to the obligations that had not been delayed by COVID-19. On April 24, 2023, the court issued an order terminating these obligations.
Disputes Over Settlement Enforcement.value: Enforcement outcome: Co‑Neutrals found two years of good‑faith compliance on non‑COVID‑delayed obligations; court terminated those obligations.

evidences: Two years later, on February 11, 2025, the Co-Neutrals filed a final report indicating the defendants had complied for two years with the remaining CSA obligations. A month later, on March 13, the court terminated the defendant's obligations under the CSA. The case is now closed.
Disputes Over Settlement Enforcement.value: Final enforcement resolution: Co‑Neutrals reported two-year compliance on remaining obligations; court terminated all remaining CSA obligations; case closed.

evidences: On April 11, 2025, four international students holding F-1 visas filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Acting Director of the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).
The plaintiffs claimed that the termination of their Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) records violated the Administrative Procedure Act

They argued that the terminations were arbitrary and capricious because the government failed to provide individualized notice, consider relevant facts, or justify its decisions, and improperly relied on visa revocation, which was not a permissible basis under agency regulations and guidance.

The court held that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their Administrative Procedure Act claim, finding that the defendants had not demonstrated compliance with regulatory requirements for SEVIS termination and that visa revocation alone did not justify such action.
Cause of Action.value: Administrative Procedure Act (APA) claim challenging SEVIS terminations as arbitrary and capricious and contrary to agency regulations.

evidences: The amended filing expanded the claims to directly challenge the Department of State’s role in the SEVIS terminations by targeting the underlying visa revocations.

They argued that the Department unlawfully relied on 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i) to revoke thousands of F-1 visas, contending that the statute was intended only for visas of individuals who had not yet entered the United States.
Cause of Action.value: APA-based challenge to State Department visa revocations premised on alleged misuse of 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i).

evidences: The plaintiffs claimed that the termination of their Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) records violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the Due Process Clause and Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.

They argued that the terminations were arbitrary and capricious because the government failed to provide individualized notice, consider relevant facts, or justify its decisions, and improperly relied on visa revocation, which was not a permissible basis under agency regulations and guidance.

The court held that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their Administrative Procedure Act claim, finding that the defendants had not demonstrated compliance with regulatory requirements for SEVIS termination and that visa revocation alone did not justify such action.
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: Administrative Procedure Act (APA)

evidences: The plaintiffs claimed that the termination of their Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) records violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the Due Process Clause and Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.
Second, they asserted a due process violation, claiming a protected interest in their F-1 status and SEVIS records that was taken away without notice, explanation, or an opportunity to respond.
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause

evidences: The plaintiffs claimed that the termination of their Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) records violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the Due Process Clause and Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.

Third, they alleged an equal protection violation, contending that the terminations unlawfully discriminated against Chinese students, who were disproportionately targeted without evidence of security threats or regulatory violations, and were treated differently from similarly situated students of other national origins.
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: Fifth Amendment Equal Protection Clause

evidences: They argued that the Department unlawfully relied on 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i) to revoke thousands of F-1 visas, contending that the statute was intended only for visas of individuals who had not yet entered the United States.
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i) (statutory provision challenged as improperly relied upon for visa revocations)

evidences: the Fifth Amendment. Represented by private counsel, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to halt the terminations, restore their legal status, and prevent further irreparable harm.

evidences: This case is one of numerous lawsuits challenging the Trump administration’s abrupt termination of immigration visas—mostly student or work visas—with no notice to the visa-holders and with dubious or no legal basis.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background: part of a broader pattern of abrupt visa terminations without notice during the Trump administration.

evidences: On April 11, 2025, four international students holding F-1 visas filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Acting Director of the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).
Judge Steven White presides over the case.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Parties and filing details: Four F-1 international students sued DHS and ICE leadership in N.D. Cal. on April 11, 2025; Judge Steven White presides.

evidences: The plaintiffs claimed that the termination of their Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) records violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the Due Process Clause and Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.
Represented by private counsel, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to halt the terminations, restore their legal status, and prevent further irreparable harm.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Core event and relief sought: Plaintiffs’ SEVIS records were terminated; they seek to halt terminations, restore status, and prevent harm.

evidences: They argued that the terminations were arbitrary and capricious because the government failed to provide individualized notice, consider relevant facts, or justify its decisions, and improperly relied on visa revocation, which was not a permissible basis under agency regulations and guidance.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs’ factual assertions: Government provided no individualized notice and improperly relied on visa revocations to terminate SEVIS records.

evidences: Third, they alleged an equal protection violation, contending that the terminations unlawfully discriminated against Chinese students, who were disproportionately targeted without evidence of security threats or regulatory violations, and were treated differently from similarly situated students of other national origins.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Alleged disparate impact: Chinese students were disproportionately targeted without evidence of security threats or regulatory violations.

evidences: Second, they asserted a due process violation, claiming a protected interest in their F-1 status and SEVIS records that was taken away without notice, explanation, or an opportunity to respond.
Factual Basis of Case.value: F-1 status and SEVIS records that was taken away without notice, explanation, or an opportunity to respond.

evidences: On April 18, 2025, the court granted a temporary restraining order for 14 days. 2025 WL 1150697.

During that period, the defendants were barred from arresting or incarcerating the four plaintiffs, transferring them outside the Northern District of California, or imposing any legal effect from the termination of their SEVIS status or the potential unlawful revocation of their visas.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Initial court relief: TRO barred legal consequences from SEVIS terminations or visa revocations and restricted arrests/transfers of the four plaintiffs.

evidences: The court held that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their Administrative Procedure Act claim, finding that the defendants had not demonstrated compliance with regulatory requirements for SEVIS termination and that visa revocation alone did not justify such action.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Court’s factual findings underpinning relief: Defendants did not show compliance with SEVIS termination regulations; visa revocation alone was insufficient justification.

evidences: The court emphasized that although three plaintiffs had been arrested, none had been convicted of a crime.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Relevant factual background: Three plaintiffs were arrested but none convicted.

evidences: The court further held that the plaintiffs faced a strong likelihood of irreparable harm because their studies and work were threatened and they risked immediate arrest and deportation.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Harm evidence: Threats to studies and work, and risk of immediate arrest and deportation.

evidences: On May 22, 2025, the court granted a preliminary injunction and expanded the earlier TROs into a nationwide injunction. 2025 WL 1467543.
The court held that termination of a SEVIS record effectively ended F-1 status, rejecting the defendants’ argument that it served only as a “red flag.”
The court pointed to DHS’s own materials and guidance from SEVP-approved institutions showing that terminated records invalidated both student status and work authorization.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Key evidentiary basis for injunction: DHS and SEVP institutional guidance showed that terminated SEVIS records ended F-1 status and work authorization.

evidences: The order barred the government from arresting, detaining, or transferring the plaintiffs and similarly situated individuals outside their jurisdictions of residence, from imposing legal consequences based on terminated SEVIS records, and from reversing reinstated records of those maintaining status.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Scope of preliminary injunction: Prohibited arrests/transfers and legal consequences based on terminated SEVIS records; protected reinstated records.

evidences: On July 30, 2025, the plaintiffs moved for an amended preliminary injunction that shifted the focus of the case to the Department of State’s role in visa revocations.

They argued that the Department unlawfully relied on 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i) to revoke thousands of F-1 visas, contending that the statute was intended only for visas of individuals who had not yet entered the United States.
Although the court’s earlier injunction restored SEVIS status, the plaintiffs emphasized that the revoked visas continued to cause harm by preventing international travel and risking re-entry denial.
The motion included new declarations from three recently added plaintiffs describing these harms.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs’ evidence and harms re visa revocations: DOS allegedly used 8 U.S.C. § 1201(i) to revoke thousands of F-1 visas; revoked visas prevent travel and risk re-entry denial; supported by new declarations from added plaintiffs.

evidences: This case challenged a rule published by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) that allegedly endangered 24 million Americans' health coverage under the Affordable Care Act (ACA). CMS, which is a subagency of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), proposed the challenged rule in March 2025, soon after the Trump Administration took office.

The rule, entitled "Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act; Marketplace Integrity and Affordability," allegedly added several roadblocks to the acquisition of ACA health insurance; these included new fees, reductions in the enrollment period, and even a revocation of the ACA's central promise that any American can purchase health insurance.
Factual Basis of Case.value: CMS, a subagency of HHS, proposed in March 2025 a rule titled “Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act; Marketplace Integrity and Affordability,” which allegedly threatened ACA coverage for 24 million people by adding new fees, shortening enrollment, and revoking guaranteed purchase rights.

evidences: On July 2, 2025, plaintiffs filed a motion requesting a stay, or alternatively a preliminary injunction, of the new CMS rule.
The municipal plaintiffs argued that as healthcare providers of last resort for those who lose insurance under the new rule, the rule would bestow a heavy financial burden on them.
The organizational plaintiffs argued that the rule would make it harder for them to pay their employees or to receive adequate compensation for healthcare services rendered.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs moved on July 2, 2025, for a stay or preliminary injunction, asserting municipal financial burdens as providers of last resort and organizational difficulties paying employees or being compensated for services.

evidences: First, the court found that Main Street Alliance and the city plaintiffs had standing based on the increased premiums and uncompensated care costs that would be "predictable results" of the challenged provisions.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Standing was based on predictable increased premiums and uncompensated care costs affecting Main Street Alliance and the city plaintiffs.

evidences: Next, it addressed the plaintiffs’ likelihood of success on the merits of their claims across three categories: (1) challenges to provisions that eroded the value of coverage, including a provision imposing a $5 monthly surcharge to reconfirm eligibility, a provision revising the premium adjustment methodology, and a provision revising the actuarial value policy; (2) challenges to provisions that imposed barriers on enrollment, including a provision requiring enrollees to pay past-due premiums before receiving new coverage and a provision adding verification requirements for some enrollments; and (3) challenges to provisions that limited the availability of subsidized coverage, including a provision re-instituting a policy regarding failure-to-reconcile tax data and two provisions requiring heightened income verification under certain circumstances.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The court evaluated three categories of provisions: (1) coverage value erosion (surcharge, premium adjustment methodology, actuarial value policy), (2) enrollment barriers (past-due premium requirement, added verification), and (3) subsidy limitations (failure-to-reconcile policy, heightened income verification).

evidences: Ultimately, the court held that the appropriate course of action was to temporarily stay the seven challenged provisions as to which it found likelihood of success on the merits, postponing the effective date until final resolution of the lawsuit.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The court temporarily stayed seven provisions pending final resolution, concluding CASA did not bar preliminary set-aside of agency rules under the APA.

evidences: On August 25, 2025, the plaintiffs filed an unopposed motion to clarify the scope of the preliminary injunction, which the court granted that same day, amending its August 22, 2025 order as clarified to order that the effective dates of the following provisions of the rule were stayed pending resolution of the merits of the case:

• The imposition of a $5 premium penalty on automatic re-enrollees, through the addition of 45 C.F.R. § 155.335(a)(3) and (n) and revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 155.330(j);   • The revocation of guaranteed insurance coverage for individuals with past-due premiums, through revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 147.104(i);   • The failure to reconcile policy in 45 C.F.R. § 155.305(f)(4), including the final rule’s amendments to that policy through the addition of 45 C.F.R. § 155.305(f)(4)(iii);   • The imposition of eligibility verification for the special enrollment period, through the revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 155.420(g);   • The imposition of a requirement that Exchanges verify household income inconsistencies when a tax filer’s attested projected annual household income differs from “trusted data sources,” through revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 155.320(c)(3)(iii) and the addition of 45 C.F.R. § 155.320(c)(3)(vi)(C)(2);   • The changes to the de minimis ranges for actuarial value calculations, through revisions to 45 C.F.R. §§ 156.140(c), 156.200(b)(3), and 156.400;   • The changes to the policy regarding self-attestation of projected income, through revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 155.320(c)(5).
Factual Basis of Case.value: Stayed provisions (effective dates stayed): $5 premium penalty for automatic re-enrollees; revocation of coverage for past-due premiums; failure-to-reconcile policy; special enrollment period eligibility verification; heightened verification when projected income differs from trusted data sources; changes to de minimis actuarial value ranges; changes rescinding self-attestation of projected income.

evidences: The effective dates of the following provisions were not stayed:

• The change to the measure for calculating the premium adjustment percentage set forth in 90 Fed. Reg. 27,166 through 27,178;     • The elimination of the 60-day extension of time to resolve inconsistencies in household income data, through the removal of 45 C.F.R. § 155.315(f)(7) and revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 155.320(c)(5).
Factual Basis of Case.value: Not stayed: change to the measure for calculating the premium adjustment percentage; elimination of the 60-day extension to resolve income data inconsistencies.
