evidences: The court held a hearing on the requested preliminary injunction on August 14, 2025.
Trials.value: Preliminary injunction hearing held on August 14, 2025.

evidences: On August 22, 2025, it issued an order granting in part and denying in part the plaintiffs' motion and entering a stay enjoining certain provisions of the CMS rule that were to take effect on August 25. 2025 WL 2426382. It reasoned that the plaintiffs had shown a likelihood of success on the merits of their challenges to seven provisions of the rule, but that they failed to show likelihood of success on the merits sufficient to warrant preliminary relief as to their remaining challenges to two other provisions of the rule. As to the seven, the plaintiffs had also shown that they faced irreparable harm – economic harms that could not adequately be remedied at the conclusion of litigation –  and that the balance of the equities and the public interest weighed in favor of a stay.
Trials.value: On August 22, 2025, the court granted in part and denied in part the PI motion (2025 WL 2426382), staying certain provisions set to take effect August 25; found likelihood of success on seven provisions (not two), irreparable harm, and equities/public interest favoring a stay.

evidences: First, the court found that Main Street Alliance and the city plaintiffs had standing based on the increased premiums and uncompensated care costs that would be "predictable results" of the challenged provisions.
Trials.value: Court found standing for Main Street Alliance and the city plaintiffs based on predictable economic harms (increased premiums and uncompensated care).

evidences: Next, it addressed the plaintiffs’ likelihood of success on the merits of their claims across three categories: (1) challenges to provisions that eroded the value of coverage, including a provision imposing a $5 monthly surcharge to reconfirm eligibility, a provision revising the premium adjustment methodology, and a provision revising the actuarial value policy;

As to the first category, the court held that CMS lacked authority to impose the challenged fees, which were untethered to the statutory formula, and that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claim that the agency acted in an arbitrary and capricious manner by revising the actuarial value policy because it provided an insufficient and conclusory rationale for the changes.

However, the court concluded that plaintiffs were unlikely to succeed on their claim that the provision revising premium adjustment methodology was arbitrary and capricious because the agency provided the necessary and reasoned explanation for the changes.
Trials.value: Category 1 (value of coverage): $5 monthly surcharge unauthorized; actuarial value policy revision arbitrary and capricious; premium adjustment methodology revision likely lawful.

evidences: As to the second category, the court held that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their challenge to past-due payment requirements, because the agency was not authorized to create a new exception to the ACA’s categorical guaranteed-issue rule, and to the verification requirements provision because defendants’ rationale for imposing the requirements was not indicative of reasoned decision-making.
Trials.value: Category 2 (enrollment barriers): past-due premium requirement unauthorized (contrary to guaranteed-issue); special enrollment verification requirement lacked reasoned basis.

evidences: As to the third category, the court first held that plain text of the ACA contradicted the agency’s failure-to-reconcile provision, and therefore that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claim that the provision was imposed contrary to law.

Next considering the agency’s decision to rescind an automatic 60-day extension to reconcile income verification data, the court concluded that the plaintiffs had failed to show that the agency had misinterpreted its modification authority.

The court did find, however, that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claim that the agency acted arbitrarily by instituting additional verification requirements for income below the federal poverty line and by rescinding a regulation requiring acceptance of self-attestation of projected household income because those changes were made without sufficient data justifying the need to impose them and in light of the agency’s circular reasoning and conclusory statements offered in support of the changes.
Trials.value: Category 3 (subsidized coverage limits): failure-to-reconcile provision contrary to the ACA; elimination of the 60‑day extension likely lawful; added sub‑FPL verification and rescission of self‑attestation arbitrary.

evidences: Ultimately, the court held that the appropriate course of action was to temporarily stay the seven challenged provisions as to which it found likelihood of success on the merits, postponing the effective date until final resolution of the lawsuit.
Trials.value: Relief: temporarily stayed seven provisions pending final resolution; CASA did not bar preliminary vacatur/stay under the APA.

evidences: On August 25, 2025, the plaintiffs filed an unopposed motion to clarify the scope of the preliminary injunction, which the court granted that same day, amending its August 22, 2025 order as clarified to order that the effective dates of the following provisions of the rule were stayed pending resolution of the merits of the case:
• The imposition of a $5 premium penalty on automatic re-enrollees, through the addition of 45 C.F.R. § 155.335(a)(3) and (n) and revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 155.330(j);
• The revocation of guaranteed insurance coverage for individuals with past-due premiums, through revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 147.104(i);
• The failure to reconcile policy in 45 C.F.R. § 155.305(f)(4), including the final rule’s amendments to that policy through the addition of 45 C.F.R. § 155.305(f)(4)(iii);
• The imposition of eligibility verification for the special enrollment period, through the revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 155.420(g);

• The imposition of a requirement that Exchanges verify household income inconsistencies when a tax filer’s attested projected annual household income differs from “trusted data sources,” through revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 155.320(c)(3)(iii) and the addition of 45 C.F.R. § 155.320(c)(3)(vi)(C)(2);
• The changes to the de minimis ranges for actuarial value calculations, through revisions to 45 C.F.R. §§ 156.140(c), 156.200(b)(3), and 156.400;
• The changes to the policy regarding self-attestation of projected income, through revisions to 45 C.F.R. § 155.320(c)(5).
Trials.value: On August 25, 2025, the court granted an unopposed motion to clarify and explicitly stayed the effective dates of seven provisions: (1) $5 premium penalty on auto re‑enrollees; (2) revocation of guaranteed coverage for past‑due premiums; (3) failure‑to‑reconcile policy; (4) special enrollment period verification; (5) heightened income inconsistency verification; (6) actuarial value de minimis range changes; (7) rescission of self‑attestation policy.

Court Rulings.value: Aug 22, 2025: Plaintiffs’ motion for a stay or, alternatively, a preliminary injunction — granted in part and denied in part (2025 WL 2426382). The court entered a stay enjoining certain provisions and temporarily stayed the effective dates of seven provisions pending final resolution. Stayed provisions: (1) $5 premium penalty on automatic re-enrollees (45 C.F.R. § 155.335(a)(3), (n); § 155.330(j)); (2) revocation of guaranteed coverage for individuals with past-due premiums (45 C.F.R. § 147.104(i)); (3) failure-to-reconcile policy (45 C.F.R. § 155.305(f)(4), including § 155.305(f)(4)(iii)); (4) eligibility verification for the special enrollment period (45 C.F.R. § 155.420(g)); (5) requirement that Exchanges verify household income inconsistencies when projected income differs from trusted data sources (45 C.F.R. § 155.320(c)(3)(iii) and § 155.320(c)(3)(vi)(C)(2)); (6) changes to de minimis ranges for actuarial value calculations (45 C.F.R. §§ 156.140(c), 156.200(b)(3), 156.400); (7) changes to policy regarding self-attestation of projected income (45 C.F.R. § 155.320(c)(5)). Not stayed: (1) change to the measure for calculating the premium adjustment percentage (90 Fed. Reg. 27,166–27,178); (2) elimination of the 60-day extension to resolve inconsistencies in household income data (removal of 45 C.F.R. § 155.315(f)(7) and revisions to § 155.320(c)(5)).

evidences: On February 10, 2020, fourteen prisoners at the Mississippi State Penitentiary in Parchman, Mississippi, filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi.
The plaintiffs claimed that state officials were aware of and deliberately indifferent to inhumane conditions, in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.
The plaintiffs sued the Commissioner of the Mississippi Department of Corrections and the Superintendent of the Mississippi Penitentiary under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.
Cause of Action.value: 42 U.S.C. § 1983 claim alleging Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment violations (deliberate indifference to inhumane prison conditions) against the MDOC Commissioner and Parchman Superintendent.

evidences: The court also dismissed the plaintiffs’ allegation under 42 U.S.C. § 1985(3) that the defendants conspired to deprive plaintiffs of equal protection because the allegations failed to allege that racial animus motivated the conspiracy.
Cause of Action.value: 42 U.S.C. § 1985(3) conspiracy to deprive equal protection (dismissed for lack of racial-animus allegations).

evidences: The plaintiffs claimed that state officials were aware of and deliberately indifferent to inhumane conditions, in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.

Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that Parchman’s chronic understaffing and overcrowding, frequent outbreaks of violence, and physical neglect to the facilities violated the constitutional ban on cruel and unusual punishment.
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: Eighth Amendment – Cruel and Unusual Punishments Clause

Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Plaintiffs allege state officials knew of and were deliberately indifferent to inhumane conditions at Parchman, including chronic understaffing, overcrowding, frequent violence, and physical neglect of facilities.

evidences: Press reports [https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/14/us/jay-z-yo-gotti-mississippi-prisons-lawsuit-trnd/index.html] connected this sue to entertainment mogul Jay-Z, who had the month before written an open letter to Mississippi Governor Phil Bryant decrying the conditions at state correctional facilities.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background context: Public attention, including an open letter by Jay-Z in January 2020 criticizing Mississippi prison conditions, was linked by press reports to this lawsuit.

evidences: The plaintiffs outlined how Parchman’s frequent outbreaks of violence culminated in eight deaths in the first month of 2020.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Frequent violence allegedly culminated in eight inmate deaths in January 2020.

evidences: The understaffing and overcrowding at Parchman led to severe failure to provide adequate living conditions, including exposure to raw sewage and extreme temperatures, denial of urgent medical care, and food and water unfit for human consumption.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Alleged conditions included exposure to raw sewage, extreme temperatures, denial of urgent medical care, and food and water unfit for consumption, attributed to understaffing and overcrowding.

evidences: The defendant moved to dismiss the amended complaint less than two weeks later on March 30, 2021, raising qualified immunity and asserting that the plaintiffs failed to state a claim or to allege physical injuries, as required by the Prison Litigation Reform Act.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Defendants asserted that plaintiffs failed to state a claim or allege physical injuries, which is required by the Prison Litigation Reform Act.

evidences: On October 23, 2024, defendants moved to sever the plaintiffs' claims into separate civil actions, capitalizing on the court's opinion denying class certification in arguing that severing the Plaintiffs’ claims into separate actions, or at least holding separate trials, would help the court to avoid prejudice and delay and ensure fairness of proceedings.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Defendants filed a motion for severance in order to allow each Plaintiff's claim to be heard independently after class certification was rejected.

evidences: The court ordered the plaintiffs to limit their separate lawsuits to the claims raised in this lawsuit and to tailor each case to each respective plaintiff.  The parties expected to complete remaining discovery in the new cases.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The parties would complete remaining discovery in the newly severed cases.

evidences: On October 23, 2024, defendants moved to sever the plaintiffs' claims into separate civil actions, capitalizing on the court's opinion denying class certification in arguing that severing the Plaintiffs’ claims into separate actions, or at least holding separate trials, would help the court to avoid prejudice and delay and ensure fairness of proceedings.

evidences: On March 4, 2022, defendants filed a motion to dismiss plaintiffs' fifth amended complaint. The motion was granted in part on March 22, dismissing the claims against Marshal Turner, superintendent of Parchman, but preserving all other claims.

evidences: Discovery proceeded with several interruptions over the next several years with parties scheduling depositions and filing motions with respect to expert testimony.

evidences: On September 23, 2024, Judge Aycock rejected certification of the class on the basis that the plaintiffs failed to establish that the putative class members’ claims each depended upon a common issue such that its resolution would resolve the claims of all members of the class.  The order note that resolving claims challenged by qualified immunity required proof that each Defendant was aware of each specific allegedly unconstitutional condition that each Plaintiff faced and failed to respond as a reasonable officer would have done under the circumstances. The order also noted the length of the class period and the variations in violations raised by different plaintiffs.
Trials.value: Judge Aycock rejected class certification on September 23, 2024.

evidences: On November 13, 2024, the court held that the appropriate resolution was for each individual plaintiff to file their own lawsuit.  The court ordered the plaintiffs to limit their separate lawsuits to the claims raised in this lawsuit and to tailor each case to each respective plaintiff.  The parties expected to complete remaining discovery in the new cases.
Trials.value: Motion for severance was granted on November 13, 2024.

evidences: On January 6, 2025, Justice Aycock dismissed plaintiffs' claims without prejudice. This case is now closed.
Trials.value: 01/06/2025 – Case outcome: dismissed without prejudice; case closed (no trial described in the summary before closure).

evidences: On March 2, 2021, Judge Brown dismissed the plaintiffs’ complaint for failure to provide adequate notice to the defendants of the claims against them.
Court Rulings.value: March 2, 2021 — Court dismissed the complaint for failure to provide adequate notice to defendants.

evidences: On November 2, 2021, Judge Brown dismissed the plaintiffs’ claims for compensatory damages to the extent that the claims were based on mental or emotional, rather than physical, injuries.  The court also dismissed the plaintiffs’ allegation under 42 U.S.C. § 1985(3) that the defendants conspired to deprive plaintiffs of equal protection because the allegations failed to allege that racial animus motivated the conspiracy.  In the same order, however, the court denied the defendants’ motion to dismiss the lawsuit on the basis of qualified immunity, finding that the plaintiffs pleaded facts that, if proven, would amount to violation of clearly established constitutional rights.
Court Rulings.value: November 2, 2021 — On defendants’ March 30, 2021 motion to dismiss, the court: (a) dismissed compensatory-damages claims to the extent based on mental or emotional injuries; (b) dismissed the § 1985(3) conspiracy claim; and (c) denied dismissal on qualified-immunity grounds.

The order also noted the length of the class period and the variations in violations raised by different plaintiffs.

evidences: On October 7, 2024, the U.S. government brought a lawsuit against the City of Durham, North Carolina, in U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina.
This case is about enforcing Title VII of the Civil Rights Act.
Plaintiff argued that the CEB disproportionately affected black applicants’ employment prospects, even though the CEB was not meaningfully related to the job or otherwise necessary.

Plaintiff also alleged that even for applicants who passed, however, there continued to be race-related discrimination: 32% of black applicants who passed the test and were eligible for an in-person interview did not receive one; only 14% of white applicants similarly positioned did not receive an interview invitation.

Plaintiff also asserted that the CEB was not job-related, nor consistent with business necessity – even if the CEB were, however, plaintiff also reasoned that alternative selection procedures could have been used.

Plaintiff set forth in its complaint that the city of Durham was in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e (“Title VII”), by engaging in a pattern of employment discrimination against black applicants.
Cause of Action.value: Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e) — pattern-or-practice employment discrimination, including a disparate-impact claim challenging the CEB and allegations of disparate treatment at the interview stage.

evidences: This case is about enforcing Title VII of the Civil Rights Act.

Plaintiff set forth in its complaint that the city of Durham was in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e (“Title VII”), by engaging in a pattern of employment discrimination against black applicants.
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e) — statutory basis (no constitutional claim alleged)

evidences: Plaintiff sought a court order mandating the following: that Durham no longer use written tests for entry-level firefighter positions if they have disparate racial impact and are not job-related nor otherwise do not meet the requirements of Title VII; provide remedial relief to people who had suffered individual loss as a result of the discrimination alleged in the complaint; and adopt any other non-discriminatory measures to correct the present effects of its discriminatory policies.
Remedy Sought.value: Court-ordered injunctive relief barring use of written tests with disparate racial impact that are not job-related/Title VII-compliant; remedial relief to individuals harmed; and adoption of other non-discriminatory measures to correct present effects.

evidences: On the same day, the parties filed a joint motion for provisional approval and entry of consent decree.
The parties asked the court to provisionally approve that agreement, to schedule a Fairness Hearing, and stay all deadlines in the litigation pending determination on the consent decree.
Remedy Sought.value: Provisional approval and entry of a consent decree; scheduling of a Fairness Hearing; and a stay of litigation deadlines pending determination on the consent decree.

evidences: The parties had jointly negotiated a consent decree to resolve the litigation, which would require: (1) Durham replace the challenged CEB exam with new employment screening practices which comply with Title VII; and (2) Durham provide individual relief to eligible black applicants who were excluded from further consideration as entry-level firefighters due to the CEB.
Remedy Sought.value: Consent decree relief requiring replacement of the CEB with Title VII-compliant screening practices and provision of individual relief to eligible Black applicants excluded by the CEB.

evidences: With respect to the first requirement, Durham agreed to not administer any written exam for use in selecting entry-level firefighters without the assent of the U.S. government or court approval, and to hire a Test Developer to explore other selection devices that would reduce or eliminate disparate racial impact on applicants.
Remedy Sought.value: Consent decree terms: no written exam for firefighter selection without DOJ assent or court approval; hire a Test Developer to identify alternative selection devices reducing or eliminating disparate racial impact.

evidences: With respect to the second requirement, Durham agreed to pay $980,000 into a settlement fund, which would be used to compensate eligible claimants.
Remedy Sought.value: Monetary relief: $980,000 settlement fund to compensate eligible claimants.

On the same day, the parties filed a joint motion for provisional approval and entry of consent decree.

This case is about enforcing Title VII of the Civil Rights Act.
On October 7, 2024, the U.S. government brought a lawsuit against the City of Durham, North Carolina, in U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina.

Plaintiff set forth in its complaint that the city of Durham was in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e (“Title VII”), by engaging in a pattern of employment discrimination against black applicants.
Who are the Parties.value: Plaintiff: U.S. government — brought a Title VII enforcement lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina.

evidences: On October 7, 2024, the U.S. government brought a lawsuit against the City of Durham, North Carolina, in U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina.

The Durham Fire Department (“FDF”), which is overseen by the city of Durham, used a multiple-choice and written test, the Comprehensive Examination Battery (“CEB”), to screen entry-level firefighter applications.

Plaintiff set forth in its complaint that the city of Durham was in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e (“Title VII”), by engaging in a pattern of employment discrimination against black applicants.
Who are the Parties.value: Defendant: City of Durham, North Carolina — municipal government overseeing the Durham Fire Department, alleged to be in violation of Title VII due to the Fire Department’s use of the Comprehensive Examination Battery (CEB) in entry-level firefighter hiring.

evidences: The Durham Fire Department (“FDF”), which is overseen by the city of Durham, used a multiple-choice and written test, the Comprehensive Examination Battery (“CEB”), to screen entry-level firefighter applications.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Employment practice at issue: The Durham Fire Department used the Comprehensive Examination Battery (CEB), a multiple-choice and written test, to screen entry-level firefighter applicants.

evidences: Applicants who scored less than 70% on the CEB did not advance in the screening process.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Screening threshold: Applicants scoring below 70% on the CEB were excluded from further consideration.

evidences: There was a measurable difference in CEB outcome based on race: Around 37% of black test-takers failed the test, as opposed to around 11% of white test-takers who failed.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Disparate impact evidence (test failure rates): Approximately 37% of Black test-takers failed the CEB compared to about 11% of White test-takers.

evidences: 32% of black applicants who passed the test and were eligible for an in-person interview did not receive one; only 14% of white applicants similarly positioned did not receive an interview invitation.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Disparate treatment/impact in interviews: Among applicants who passed, 32% of Black candidates did not receive interviews versus 14% of similarly situated White candidates.

evidences: Plaintiff also asserted that the CEB was not job-related, nor consistent with business necessity – even if the CEB were, however, plaintiff also reasoned that alternative selection procedures could have been used.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Job-relatedness and alternatives: The government alleged the CEB was not job-related or consistent with business necessity and that less discriminatory alternative selection procedures were available.

evidences: Plaintiff sought a court order mandating the following: that Durham no longer use written tests for entry-level firefighter positions if they have disparate racial impact and are not job-related nor otherwise do not meet the requirements of Title VII; provide remedial relief to people who had suffered individual loss as a result of the discrimination alleged in the complaint; and adopt any other non-discriminatory measures to correct the present effects of its discriminatory policies.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Relief sought: Injunctive relief limiting use of written tests with disparate impact and lacking Title VII compliance, remedial relief for affected individuals, and adoption of non-discriminatory measures.

evidences: On the same day, the parties filed a joint motion for provisional approval and entry of consent decree.

The parties had jointly negotiated a consent decree to resolve the litigation, which would require: (1) Durham replace the challenged CEB exam with new employment screening practices which comply with Title VII; and (2) Durham provide individual relief to eligible black applicants who were excluded from further consideration as entry-level firefighters due to the CEB.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Proposed resolution: The parties jointly sought provisional approval of a consent decree requiring replacement of the CEB with Title VII-compliant screening and individual relief for eligible Black applicants excluded due to the CEB.

evidences: With respect to the first requirement, Durham agreed to not administer any written exam for use in selecting entry-level firefighters without the assent of the U.S. government or court approval, and to hire a Test Developer to explore other selection devices that would reduce or eliminate disparate racial impact on applicants.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Consent decree terms (screening reforms): Durham agreed not to administer any written exam for entry-level firefighter selection without U.S. assent or court approval and to hire a Test Developer to explore lower-impact selection devices.

evidences: With respect to the second requirement, Durham agreed to pay $980,000 into a settlement fund, which would be used to compensate eligible claimants.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Consent decree terms (monetary relief): Durham agreed to contribute $980,000 to a settlement fund for eligible claimants.

evidences: The matter was assigned to Judge Thomas D. Schroeder.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Judicial assignment: Judge Thomas D. Schroeder was assigned to the case.

evidences: On December 16, 2024, a Motion Hearing was held. While a transcript of that hearing is not available to the Clearinghouse, the court ordered the parties to submit supplemental briefing, to address whether Ricci v. DeStefano, 557 U.S. 557, 585 (2009), applied in this matter.

In Ricci, which involved a similar Title VII challenge to a written exam requirement for firefighter applicants, set a high standard that there must be a “strong basis in evidence” that without the race-based remedy, the organization would be liable under Title VII.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Court’s inquiry: After a December 16, 2024 hearing, the court ordered supplemental briefing on whether Ricci v. DeStefano applies, including the 'strong basis in evidence' standard.

evidences: The American Alliance for Equal Rights, a non-profit member organization focused on racial discrimination issues, filed a motion for leave to file an amicus brief in opposition to the proposed consent decree and participate in oral arguments.
The court granted the organization leave to file.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Amicus participation: The American Alliance for Equal Rights moved to oppose the consent decree as amicus and was granted leave.

evidences: The American Alliance for Equal Rights, a non-profit member organization focused on racial discrimination issues, filed a motion for leave to file an amicus brief in opposition to the proposed consent decree and participate in oral arguments. The American Alliance for Equal Rights argued that this case directly implicates their interests, as the government’s theory of disparate-impact liability would force employers to inject race in employment decision-making processes.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The American Alliance for Equal Rights, an organization focused on racial discrimination issues, argued that this case implicates their interests because race was injected in employment decisions.

evidences: The American Alliance for Equal Rights did submit its amicus brief on January 15, 2025.

In that amicus brief, the organization argued that Durham currently used a race-neutral test. They argued that the consent decree would require the city to implement a race-based test, and urged the court to avoid granting such a remedy as the organization believed that would itself violate Title VII’s bar on intentional discrimination.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Amicus arguments: AAER argued the existing test is race-neutral and that the consent decree would compel a race-based test violating Title VII’s ban on intentional discrimination.

evidences: On January 15, 2025, plaintiff submitted the requested brief, on the applicability of Ricci.

In that brief, plaintiff argued that (1) Ricci was distinguishable and that the court should be guided by United States v. North Carolina, 80 F.3d 574, 581 (4th Cir. 1999), which set a more lax fair-and-reasonable standard and which is controlling law in the Fourth Circuit, and (2) even if Ricci applied, there was sufficiently strong basis in evidence to support the U.S.’s prima facie case of disparate impact discrimination and the consent decree as it was formulated.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiff’s Ricci briefing: The U.S. argued Ricci is distinguishable and Fourth Circuit precedent (United States v. North Carolina) controls; alternatively, there is a strong basis in evidence supporting disparate impact and the consent decree.

evidences: The court had not yet issued a decision on this matter.

The U.S. government changed presidential administrations on January 20, 2025. Following that change in administration, on February 25, 2025, the U.S. government filed notice that it was voluntarily dismissing its claims in this matter.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Case status: Before any court decision, the U.S. changed administrations and voluntarily dismissed its claims on February 25, 2025.

evidences: On April 2, 2025, the American Public Health Association; IBIS Reproductive Health; International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace, and Agricultural Implement Workers (UAW); and four private plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.

The plaintiffs brought seven claims, primarily under the Administrative Procedure Act , to challenge the defendants' actions, including the termination of grants, refusal to consider applications, and the issuance of new directives.

evidences: On July 18, 2025, the First Circuit denied the defendants’ motion for a stay pending appeal, holding that the district court had jurisdiction under the Administrative Procedure Act to review the agency action and issue declaratory relief.

The court declared the Directives void, unlawful, of no effect, set aside, and vacated. Likewise, the resulting grant terminations were also declared void, unlawful, of no effect, set aside, and vacated.

evidences: On August 21, 2025, the Supreme Court partially granted and partially denied the stay application.

The court stayed the district court’s judgments vacating the government’s termination of research grants, reasoning that the court likely lacked jurisdiction over claims based on a contractual “obligation to pay money,” which belonged in the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act, and that the government would face irreparable harm if funds were disbursed. However, the court denied the stay for judgments vacating the NIH guidance documents, finding that the government had failed to show irreparable harm from their vacatur.
Dates of All Decrees.value: August 21, 2025: Supreme Court order partially granting and partially denying the stay application; stayed the district court’s judgments vacating the termination of research grants; denied the stay as to vacatur of NIH guidance documents.

evidences: On April 2, 2025, the American Public Health Association; IBIS Reproductive Health; International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace, and Agricultural Implement Workers (UAW); and four private plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts.

The plaintiffs, consisting of leading health research organizations and individual research scientists, sued the National Institutes of Health and the United States Department of Health and Human Services.
The case was initially assigned to Judge Murphy, but on May 1, 2025, he recused himself and the case was reassigned to Judge William G. Young.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves a suit filed on April 2, 2025, in the District of Massachusetts by major public health organizations and individual scientists against NIH and HHS, initially assigned to Judge Murphy and then reassigned to Judge William G. Young.

evidences: This case challenged the abrupt termination of numerous National Institutes of Health (NIH) funded research projects and the halting of grant application processes.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Case challenged the cancelation of research projects funded by the NIH.

evidences: The lawsuit arose from a series of government directives beginning in February 2025 aimed at terminating NIH-funded research on topics and populations the administration disfavored, including “gender identity,” “Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion” (DEI), “vaccine hesitancy,” and studies involving certain foreign entities.
According to the complaint, these directives followed President Trump’s January 2025 executive orders seeking to end equity-related programs and grants.
The plaintiffs alleged that, in response, NIH issued guidance instructing staff to identify and terminate grants in these categories.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves administration directives starting February 2025, following January 2025 executive orders, and NIH guidance instructing staff to identify and terminate grants in disfavored categories.

evidences: This led to the abrupt termination of ongoing projects—many years in progress with significant financial and time investments—and the refusal to consider certain pending applications, including those aimed at diversifying researcher backgrounds.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves abrupt termination of long-running NIH-funded projects and refusal to consider pending applications, including those aimed at diversifying researcher backgrounds, despite significant invested time and funds.

evidences: The plaintiffs argued that these terminations lacked scientifically valid reasons and disregarded established NIH protocols, which normally require non-compliance or cause to justify termination.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves allegations that NIH terminated grants without scientifically valid reasons and in violation of established NIH protocols requiring non-compliance or cause.

evidences: The plaintiffs brought seven claims, primarily under the Administrative Procedure Act , to challenge the defendants' actions, including the termination of grants, refusal to consider applications, and the issuance of new directives.
The first three counts alleged that these actions were arbitrary and capricious, contrary to law, and exceeded statutory authority.

Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed the defendants failed to provide adequate reasoning, ignored their own policies, and improperly relied on external guidance that had not yet been formally adopted.

The plaintiffs also alleged that the defendants unreasonably delayed reviewing grant applications, and that the directives were unconstitutionally vague, violating the Fifth Amendment's due process clause.
Finally, they asserted that the defendants violated the separation of powers by usurping Congress's legislative authority and ignoring statutory mandates.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves factual allegations that defendants acted without adequate reasoning, ignored NIH policies, relied on non-adopted external guidance, and unreasonably delayed application reviews, forming the basis of APA and related claims.

evidences: They requested an order requiring NIH to restore the terminated grants retroactively and to review all properly submitted applications in accordance with existing NIH policies and strategic plans.

Additionally, the plaintiffs sought regular status reports from the defendants confirming compliance with any court orders, an injunction protecting them from any retaliatory consequences for their involvement in the litigation, and an award of their reasonable costs and attorneys’ fees.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background information includes the plaintiffs’ request for restoration of terminated grants, resumption of application reviews under existing NIH policies, compliance reporting, anti-retaliation protections, and fees.

evidences: On April 25, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction and a motion for a protective order.

In the protective order motion, the plaintiffs requested that the court safeguard the names and other identifying information of certain organizational declarants from unnecessary disclosure to the defendants and prevent their participation in the litigation from being used for any potentially retaliatory purposes.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves evidentiary protections sought for organizational declarants due to concerns about retaliation, alongside a preliminary injunction motion to halt ongoing terminations.

evidences: Between April and June 2025, a wide range of academic institutions, professional associations, civil rights organizations, and attorneys general from 20 states and the District of Columbia filed a series of amicus briefs.

They emphasized the dangers of politicizing scientific grantmaking, warned against the erosion of established peer review protocols, and highlighted the discouraging effect on critical research related to marginalized populations, public health misinformation, and global health collaboration.

Several amici also detailed the institutional and societal harms caused by abruptly halting ongoing projects—pointing to disruptions to career trajectories, institutional partnerships, and public trust in federal research systems.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background evidence from numerous amici highlights systemic harms from politicized grantmaking, erosion of peer review, disruptions to research on marginalized populations and public health, and institutional harms from abrupt project halts.

evidences: These briefs collectively underscored the broad alarm within the scientific, academic, and public health communities regarding the sweeping implications of the challenged NIH policies.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The briefs underscored the alarm regarding the implications of the challenged NIH policies.

evidences: On May 22, 2025, the court held a status conference to clarify the procedural posture of the case, focusing on the defendants’ earlier filings that raised jurisdictional and legal sufficiency challenges. During the conference, Judge Young and the parties discussed treating portions of the government’s prior briefing as a de facto motion to dismiss. The judge noted that resolving these threshold legal issues early would help streamline the litigation. On May 28, 2025, Judge Young held a hearing on the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. The plaintiffs emphasized the immediate and irreversible harms resulting from the abrupt termination of their NIH-funded research, as well as the chilling effect on future scientific inquiry. The defendants responded that NIH had acted within its discretion in realigning grant priorities in accordance with updated government policy.
Factual Basis of Case.value: On May 22, 2025, the court held a status conference to clarify the case's procedural posture, with Judge Young considering treating the government’s earlier filings as a motion to dismiss. On May 28, a hearing was held on the plaintiffs’ request for a preliminary injunction, where they argued the sudden end to NIH funding caused serious harm. The government responded that NIH acted within its policy discretion.

evidences: This order narrowed the litigation to the core equitable and statutory challenges related to grant reinstatement and procedural fairness, while preserving plaintiffs’ ability to refile the dismissed constitutional claims at a later stage if appropriate.
Factual Basis of Case.value: This order limited the case to key legal and fairness issues around grant reinstatement, but allowed the plaintiffs to potentially refile their constitutional claims later.

evidences: On June 16, 2025, Judge Young issued a temporary order barring further grant terminations and granted the protective order in part, allowing limited redactions of declarant identities to prevent retaliation.

That same day, he granted the preliminary injunction, concluding that NIH’s termination of numerous grants was “arbitrary, unlawful, and discriminatory.” The court ordered NIH to reinstate funding for affected grants and resume review of pending applications per established procedures—emphasizing the unprecedented and unlawful nature of NIH’s actions. The injunction took immediate effect.
Factual Basis of Case.value: A court found the terminations likely arbitrary, unlawful, and discriminatory, issuing a preliminary injunction ordering reinstatement of funding and resumption of application reviews, and permitting protective measures for declarant identities.

evidences: On July 18, 2025, the First Circuit denied the defendants’ motion for a stay pending appeal, holding that the district court had jurisdiction under the Administrative Procedure Act to review the agency action and issue declaratory relief.

The court declared the Directives void, unlawful, of no effect, set aside, and vacated. Likewise, the resulting grant terminations were also declared void, unlawful, of no effect, set aside, and vacated.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Appellate background: the First Circuit denied a stay, affirmed APA review jurisdiction, and declared the directives and resulting terminations void and vacated.

evidences: They argued [https://www.scotusblog.com/2025/07/trump-administration-urges-supreme-court-to-pause-order-requiring-payment-of-grants/] that the district court lacked authority under federal law to compel the grant payments, citing a prior Supreme Court order permitting the Department of Education to suspend comparable funding. They also contended that the case belonged in the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act.
Factual Basis of Case.value: They argued that the district court lacked authority to order grant payments, citing a Supreme Court ruling allowing similar funding suspensions, and claimed the case should be heard in the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act.

evidences: On August 21, 2025, the Supreme Court partially granted and partially denied the stay application.

The court stayed the district court’s judgments vacating the government’s termination of research grants, reasoning that the court likely lacked jurisdiction over claims based on a contractual “obligation to pay money,” which belonged in the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act, and that the government would face irreparable harm if funds were disbursed.
However, the court denied the stay for judgments vacating the NIH guidance documents, finding that the government had failed to show irreparable harm from their vacatur.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Supreme Court procedural context: partial stay granted (staying vacatur of grant terminations due to Tucker Act concerns) but not for vacatur of NIH guidance documents.

evidences: The decision was closely divided: Justices Thomas, Alito, Gorsuch, and Kavanaugh favored granting the stay in full; the Chief Justice and Justices Sotomayor, Kagan, and Jackson favored denying it in full; and Justice Barrett concurred in the partial grant and partial denial.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The decision was closely split: four Justices favored fully granting the stay, four favored fully denying it, and Justice Barrett provided the deciding vote by supporting a partial grant and partial denial.

evidences: This case is about the alleged unlawful termination, suspension, or reduction of federal research grants to University of California researchers under a series of executive orders issued by President Trump and directives from the Department of Governmental Ethics (DOGE).

On June 4, 2025, a group of University of California researchers, faculty, staff, academic appointees, and employees filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against President Trump, DOGE, and numerous federal agencies, departments, and their heads. Judge Rita F. Lin was assigned to the case.

Also on June 5, 2025, the plalintiffs moved for class certification, seeking to represent a proposed class of “All University of California researchers, including faculty, staff, academic appointees, and employees across the University of California system whose research grants have been or will be terminated, denied, suspended, or reduced” by the defendants pursuant to Executive Orders 14151, 14154, 14158, 14168, 14173, 14217, 14238, and/or 14222, or any other Trump Administration or DOGE directives issued on or after January 20, 2025.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves UC researchers alleging unlawful terminations, suspensions, or reductions of federal research grants under Trump executive orders and DOGE directives; they filed a June 4, 2025 class action in N.D. Cal. against President Trump, DOGE, and multiple federal agencies before Judge Rita F. Lin, seeking to represent UC researchers affected by actions taken under specified executive orders issued on or after January 20, 2025.

evidences: Represented by private counsel, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to halt the enforcement of the challenged executive orders and directives, as well as reinstatement of their research funding and attorneys’ fees and costs.
On June 5, 2025, the plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order to stop the defendants from taking any further actions to unlawfully terminate federal research grants.

Specifically, the plaintiffs asked the court to restore their previously awarded grants, provide no-cost extensions for the time necessary to complete their interrupted work, and require the defendants to return to their lawful grant procedures from before January 20, 2025.

These procedures included providing plaintiffs with reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard before termination, as well as a specific, individualized explanation for any proposed termination. The motion also sought to compel the defendants to file declarations verifying their compliance with the court's order.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves plaintiffs seeking declaratory/injunctive relief, reinstatement of funding, and fees; supported by a TRO motion to restore grants, provide no‑cost extensions, revert to pre‑Jan. 20, 2025 procedures (notice, hearing, individualized reasons), and require compliance declarations; with background that defendants allegedly unlawfully terminated grants.

evidences: The plaintiffs alleged that these grant-related actions (1) exceeded presidential and agency authority in violation of the Separation of Powers, (2) infringed on academic freedom and free expression in violation of the First Amendment, (3) deprived them of due process in violation of the Fifth Amendment, (4) violated statutory limitations on executive spending authority under the Impoundment Control Act, and (5) constituted arbitrary and capricious agency action in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background information includes plaintiffs’ legal theories: separation of powers, First Amendment, Fifth Amendment due process, Impoundment Control Act limits, and APA arbitrary and capricious claims.

evidences: On June 23, 2025, Judge Lin granted the motion for a preliminary injunction and provisional class certification, extending the injunction to all similarly situated University of California researchers. 2025 WL 1734471.

The court found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claims under the First Amendment and the Administrative Procedure Act, noting that the defendants’ actions showed signs of "quintessential viewpoint discrimination".

The order immediately enjoined the Trump Administration, DOGE, and the involved federal agencies from giving effect to the vacated grant terminations and prohibited any future terminations that would meet the criteria of the certified classes. It also required that the defendants restore the grants to the plaintiffs, pending the resolution of the case.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves a June 23, 2025 preliminary injunction and provisional class certification, supported by the court’s finding of likely success under the First Amendment and APA due to signs of viewpoint discrimination; with background that the order barred effect of terminations, prohibited future qualifying terminations, and required grant restoration.

evidences: On July 10, 2025, the defendants appealed the preliminary injunction to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.

The following day, they filed a motion in the Ninth Circuit seeking a partial stay of the district court’s injunction, limited to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH).

They argued that the injunction was overly broad, that the First Amendment did not require the defendants to subsidize particular projects or to do so on a content-neutral basis, that the district court lacked jurisdiction under the Tucker Act, and that the EPA’s actions were unreviewable because they were committed to agency discretion by law.

The defendants asserted that the injunction caused irreparable harm to the public fisc and the Executive Branch. The defendants did not seek a stay as to the National Science Foundation (NSF), which had no plans to re-terminate grants during the appeal.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves defendants’ appeal and a motion for a partial stay (limited to EPA and NEH), supported by arguments about breadth, First Amendment subsidy/content neutrality, Tucker Act jurisdiction, and unreviewability; with background that no stay was sought for NSF due to no plans to re‑terminate grants.

evidences: Back in the district court, on July 18, 2025, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint that added two University of California researchers whose work was affected by the terminated grants as plaintiffs.
The amended filing also sought to add the U.S. Department of Defense and the U.S. Department of Transportation as defendants.

The filing included concrete examples, identifying specific projects and their details to support the plaintiffs’ allegations of widespread and unlawful grant terminations, such as the termination of an NSF grant supplement commemorating the agency’s 75th anniversary.

It also added new information about the Department of Energy, noting that the agency would review 179 awards totaling more than $15 billion to ensure consistency with the Trump Administration’s policies and priorities.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves an amended complaint adding two affected UC researchers and naming DoD and DOT as defendants, supported by concrete examples including termination of an NSF 75th‑anniversary grant supplement and DOE’s review of 179 awards totaling over $15 billion; with background indicating alleged widespread unlawful terminations.

evidences: The Ninth Circuit heard oral argument on the preliminary injunction appeal on July 31, 2025.
The following day, the court issued an order to show cause and set a hearing in the district court for August 12, 2025.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves key procedural events including Ninth Circuit oral argument on July 31, 2025, and a district court order to show cause and hearing set for August 12, 2025.

evidences: On August 4, 2025, in a letter brief to the court, the plaintiffs alleged that NSF had violated the June 23 preliminary injunction by indefinitely suspending hundreds of grants to UCLA researchers is a "de facto termination" and a "brazen end-around" the court's order.

The letter stated that the NSF's July 30, 2025, letter to UCLA's Chancellor had suspended the grants because they were "not aligned with current NSF priorities and/or programmatic goals," which the plaintiffs argued was "indistinguishable" from the form termination letters that the court had already deemed insufficient under the Administrative Procedure Act.

An August 1, 2025, letter from the NSF further accused UCLA of noncompliance with federal statutes and regulations, citing its "affirmative action" policies, its failure to combat "antisemitism and bias," and its allowance of transgender athletes in women's sports.
The plaintiffs argued that these actions violated the First Amendment and constituted an attempt to "penalize disfavored viewpoints."

The letter also highlighted that the NSF had not sought a stay of the preliminary injunction and, in fact, that its attorney had told the Ninth Circuit that the NSF did not want to terminate grants, reinstate them, and then terminate them again—an assertion the plaintiffs believed misrepresented their intent.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves plaintiffs’ allegation that NSF violated the injunction by indefinitely suspending hundreds of UCLA grants as a de facto termination, supported by NSF letters citing misalignment with priorities/programmatic goals and alleged UCLA noncompliance (affirmative action, antisemitism/bias, transgender athletes); with background that plaintiffs asserted First Amendment violations and noted NSF did not seek a stay.

evidences: The defendants argued that the June 23 preliminary injunction should not be extended to cover the suspension of grants to UCLA.
They contended that the factual and legal basis for the suspensions was fundamentally different from the terminations at issue in the original injunction.
They stated that the suspensions were based on an investigation into UCLA's alleged discriminatory practices, not on a keyword-based termination of "equity-related" grants.
The defendants also argued that the plaintiffs lacked standing to challenge the suspensions because none of the named plaintiffs had their grants suspended for the reasons cited in the NSF's letters.

Furthermore, they asserted that the court lacked jurisdiction to modify the injunction, as it would "materially alter the core questions of the case on appeal" by requiring a new analysis of different claims and facts.

The brief also highlighted that the suspensions were a temporary action, not a permanent termination, and that the NSF was willing to work with UCLA to bring them into compliance to prevent termination.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves defendants’ position that UCLA grant suspensions were based on an investigation into alleged discriminatory practices, were temporary, and outside the injunction’s scope, with arguments about standing and jurisdiction to modify the injunction.

evidences: The following day, the court issued an order to show cause and set a hearing in the district court for August 12, 2025.
After the hearing, the court ordered the NSF to vacate the grant suspensions and restore the affected class members to the status quo by reinstating their grants.
The court found that the NSF’s use of “suspension” was indistinguishable from a termination, which the preliminary injunction prohibited.
The court clarified that “termination” encompassed long-term or indefinite funding cuts, such as the NSF’s suspensions.
The court also held that the NSF’s letters lacked grant-specific reasons for the cuts and failed to explain how researchers’ reliance interests were considered.
Although the letters included boilerplate language on reliance interests, they contained no individualized analysis of harm to researchers.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves the district court’s August 12, 2025 action ordering NSF to vacate and reinstate suspended UCLA grants, supported by findings that suspensions were indistinguishable from prohibited terminations, encompassed indefinite cuts, and lacked grant‑specific reasons or individualized reliance analysis.

evidences: On August 21, 2025, the Ninth Circuit denied the defendants’ motion to partially stay the June 23 preliminary injunction, finding that the defendants were unlikely to succeed on the merits, the district court had jurisdiction under the Administrative Procedure Act, the plaintiffs had standing, and that the grant terminations were likely arbitrary, capricious, and viewpoint-based under the First Amendment.
The court rejected the defendants’ claims of irreparable harm, reasoning that stopping unlawful practices did not qualify.
By contrast, the court found that a stay would cause serious harm to the plaintiffs, including layoffs, program disruptions, and the loss of research.
Finally, ithe court determined that the public interest weighed against halting taxpayer-funded projects already underway.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves the Ninth Circuit’s August 21, 2025 denial of a partial stay, supported by findings of likely arbitrary/capricious and viewpoint‑based terminations, APA jurisdiction and standing, lack of irreparable harm to defendants, and significant harm to plaintiffs and the public interest if stayed.

evidences: On October 15, 2018, individuals without secure housing filed this class-action lawsuit suing the city of Grants Pass, Oregon (the “City”) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.
The case was assigned to Magistrate Judge Mark D. Clarke.
After a hearing, Magistrate Judge Clarke granted the plaintiffs’ motion for class certification on August 7, 2019. 2019 WL 3717800.

Magistrate Judge Clarke granted the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment on the procedural due process claim because the park exclusions would go into effect immediately and were not stayed for appeal, leaving a person excluded from a park subject to arrest for reentry as soon as they received the exclusion notice. The court concluded that the deficient appeal procedures were unconstitutional and violated the procedural protections of due process. However, the court denied the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment on their equal protection claim because the plaintiffs failed to demonstrate that the ordinances were selectively enforced and motivated by a discriminatory purpose. Likewise, summary judgment was denied on the plaintiffs’ substantive due process claim because they failed to convince the court that they had a liberty interest to sleep or camp in a public place and had not shown that the city engaged in “conscience shocking behavior.” 2020 WL 4209227.

The court also found that the ordinances violated the Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause of the Eighth Amendment because they punished people for sleeping or resting outside with a blanket when they had no other place to go due to the City’s lack of adequate shelter. The ordinances also violated the Excessive Fines Clause of the Eighth Amendment because the plaintiffs were being punished for trying to live, and likely could not afford to pay the fines, resulting in additional fees and punishments that made it even more difficult for them to find housing. 2020 WL 4209227.

Furthermore, the Ninth Circuit vacated the grant of summary judgment on the procedural due process claim and remanded with instructions to dismiss the claim as moot because the City amended the ordinance so it was no longer unconstitutional. 50 F.4th 787.
The parties thereafter, by October 5, 2020, reached an agreement for the plaintiffs to receive $300,000 with interest for their costs and attorneys’ fees. 2020 WL 6060925.

In response to the Ninth Circuit’s denial for a rehearing en banc, the City filed a petition for writ of certiorari on August 22, 2023, requesting the Supreme Court to rule on whether laws regulating camping on public property constituted cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth Amendment. 2023 WL 5530379.
On June 28, 2024, the Supreme Court issued its decision, ruling 6-3 to reverse and remand. 2024 WL 3208072.

evidences: On October 15, 2018, individuals without secure housing filed this class-action lawsuit suing the city of Grants Pass, Oregon (the “City”) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.

Represented by the Oregon Law Center, the plaintiffs challenged the City’s enforcement of Grants Pass’s anti-sleeping ordinance, anti-camping ordinance, park exclusion ordinance, and criminal trespass laws stemming from violations of these ordinances as unconstitutional under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S Constitution.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The case involves individuals without secure housing suing the City of Grants Pass in federal court under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, challenging enforcement of anti-sleeping, anti-camping, park exclusion, and related criminal trespass laws as violating the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.

evidences: The plaintiffs’ counsel had contacted the City on September 10, 2018, to demand relief, but the parties were unable to resolve the dispute outside of court.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Before filing, plaintiffs demanded relief on September 10, 2018, but the dispute was not resolved.

evidences: On January 2, 2019, the City amended its ordinance, removing “sleeping” from the definition of camping in an attempt to comply with a previous case, Martin v. Boise, which held that an ordinance punishing people for sleeping outside was unconstitutional when there was nowhere else for them to go.

In amending its ordinance, the City meant to clarify that the act of “sleeping” no longer automatically constituted illegal “camping,” permitting those without shelter to sleep or rest in the City’s parks.
Factual Basis of Case.value: As background, the City removed “sleeping” from the definition of camping post-filing to align with Martin v. Boise, clarifying that sleeping alone would not constitute illegal camping and permitting unsheltered people to sleep or rest in parks.

evidences: On January 2, 2019, the City amended its ordinance, removing “sleeping” from the definition of camping in an attempt to comply with a previous case, Martin v. Boise, which held that an ordinance punishing people for sleeping outside was unconstitutional when there was nowhere else for them to go.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Referenced precedent: Martin v. Boise

evidences: The court defined the class as: "All involuntarily homeless individuals living in Grants Pass, Oregon, including homeless individuals who sometimes sleep outside city limits to avoid harassment and punishment by Defendant as addressed in this lawsuit."
Factual Basis of Case.value: Class definition: All involuntarily homeless individuals in Grants Pass, including those sleeping outside city limits to avoid harassment and punishment.

evidences: Magistrate Judge Clarke granted the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment on the procedural due process claim because the park exclusions would go into effect immediately and were not stayed for appeal, leaving a person excluded from a park subject to arrest for reentry as soon as they received the exclusion notice.
The court concluded that the deficient appeal procedures were unconstitutional and violated the procedural protections of due process.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Magistrate Judge Clarke reasoned that park exclusion notices took immediate effect without a stay pending appeal, exposing recipients to arrest upon reentry, and the appeal procedures were deficient.

evidences: However, the court denied the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment on their equal protection claim because the plaintiffs failed to demonstrate that the ordinances were selectively enforced and motivated by a discriminatory purpose. Likewise, summary judgment was denied on the plaintiffs’ substantive due process claim because they failed to convince the court that they had a liberty interest to sleep or camp in a public place and had not shown that the city engaged in “conscience shocking behavior.”
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The court reasoned that the plaintiffs failed to demonstrate that the ordinances were discriminatory.

evidences: The court also found that the ordinances violated the Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause of the Eighth Amendment because they punished people for sleeping or resting outside with a blanket when they had no other place to go due to the City’s lack of adequate shelter.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Key factual finding: The City lacked adequate shelter, and the ordinances punished people for sleeping or resting outside with a blanket when they had nowhere else to go.

evidences: The ordinances also violated the Excessive Fines Clause of the Eighth Amendment because the plaintiffs were being punished for trying to live, and likely could not afford to pay the fines, resulting in additional fees and punishments that made it even more difficult for them to find housing.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Excessive fines factual basis: Plaintiffs likely could not afford fines, leading to additional fees and penalties that hindered their ability to obtain housing.

evidences: The City could not enforce the park exclusion ordinance, which allowed police officers to issue an order barring a person from all City park properties if the individual had been issued two or more citations violating regulations relating to city parks, or one citation violating state laws while on city park property.
Unless it gave at least a 24-hour warning, the City also could not enforce the camping ordinances, which prohibited setting up or remaining on public property.
Finally, the City could not enforce the criminal trespassing ordinance in city parks during nighttime hours.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Content and enforcement of challenged ordinances: (1) Park exclusion allowed blanket bans from all parks after specified citations; (2) Camping ordinances prohibited setting up or remaining on public property (with a 24-hour warning requirement under injunction); (3) Criminal trespass enforced in parks at night.

evidences: The Ninth Circuit’s decision on September 28, 2022, affirmed that the city’s “anti-camping” ordinance prohibiting individuals from using bedding supplies violated the Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause.

The case was remanded with direction to the district court to narrow its injunction to only enjoin enforcement of ordinances against unhoused individuals who take necessary measures to keep themselves warm and safe when there is no shelter available.

Furthermore, the Ninth Circuit vacated the grant of summary judgment on the procedural due process claim and remanded with instructions to dismiss the claim as moot because the City amended the ordinance so it was no longer unconstitutional.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Additional factual contours: The anti-camping ordinance barred using bedding supplies; enforcement should be limited to circumstances where no shelter is available and unhoused individuals take necessary measures to keep warm/safe; the City amended procedures mooting prior due process defects.

evidences: In response to the Ninth Circuit’s denial for a rehearing en banc, the City filed a petition for writ of certiorari on August 22, 2023, requesting the Supreme Court to rule on whether laws regulating camping on public property constituted cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth Amendment. 2023 WL 5530379.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: After the Ninth Circuit denied a rehearing en banc, the City requested the Supreme Court to rule on whether laws regulating public camping were prohibited under the Eighth Amendment's Cruel and Unusual Punishments clause.

evidences: In a concurrence, Justice Thomas noted his opinion that the 1962 case rendering “status crimes” unconstitutional was wrongly decided, and rejected the Court of Appeals’ conclusion that the Cruel and Unusual Punishments clause governed civil penalties because they could later become criminal offenses.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Justice Thomas concurred, reasoning that the 1962 case rendering "status crimes" unconstitutional was wrongly decided.

evidences: The dissenting opinion, authored by Justice Sotomayor and joined by Justices Kagan and Jackson, urged that the Eighth Amendment prohibits criminalizing the status of homelessness by making it a crime to sleep outside when a person has no other place to sleep. The dissent further noted that the Court had not decided whether the ordinance violated the Eighth Amendment’s Excessive Fines Clause, Due Process, or state law.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The dissenting opinion reasoned that the Eighth Amendment prohibits criminalizing homelessness and that the Court had not decided whether the ordinance violated the Excessive Fines Clause, Due Process, or state law.

evidences: On August 26, 2020, Judge Clarke issued an injunction enjoining the enforcement of three city ordinances against the plaintiff class.

The City could not enforce the park exclusion ordinance, which allowed police officers to issue an order barring a person from all City park properties if the individual had been issued two or more citations violating regulations relating to city parks, or one citation violating state laws while on city park property.
Unless it gave at least a 24-hour warning, the City also could not enforce the camping ordinances, which prohibited setting up or remaining on public property.
Finally, the City could not enforce the criminal trespassing ordinance in city parks during nighttime hours.
That same day, the city of Grants Pass appealed the district court’s grant of partial summary judgment and its permanent injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit (No. 20-35752).
Court Rulings.value: Injunction (Aug 26, 2020): Injunction issued enjoining enforcement of the park exclusion ordinance; camping ordinances absent at least 24-hour warning; and criminal trespass in parks during nighttime hours; appealed the same day as a permanent injunction.

evidences: The Ninth Circuit’s decision on September 28, 2022, affirmed that the city’s “anti-camping” ordinance prohibiting individuals from using bedding supplies violated the Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause.

The case was remanded with direction to the district court to narrow its injunction to only enjoin enforcement of ordinances against unhoused individuals who take necessary measures to keep themselves warm and safe when there is no shelter available.

Furthermore, the Ninth Circuit vacated the grant of summary judgment on the procedural due process claim and remanded with instructions to dismiss the claim as moot because the City amended the ordinance so it was no longer unconstitutional. 50 F.4th 787.
Court Rulings.value: Ninth Circuit ruling (Sept 28, 2022; 50 F.4th 787): Affirmed Eighth Amendment C&U Punishment violation as to anti-camping bedding ban; remanded to narrow the injunction; vacated summary judgment on procedural due process and remanded to dismiss as moot.

evidences: On June 28, 2024, the Supreme Court issued its decision, ruling 6-3 to reverse and remand. 2024 WL 3208072.

The majority’s decision, written by Justice Gorsuch and joined by Chief Justice Roberts and Justices Thomas, Alito, Kavanaugh, and Barrett, reasoned that the Eighth Amendment focuses on the “method or kind of punishment” that may be imposed after conviction, and not on whether the government may criminalize particular behavior, and therefore could not support the relief sought.
The Court further held that the punishments imposed by Grants Pass under the challenged statute were not cruel and unusual.

The majority opinion further rejected the argument that laws against camping criminalized the “status” of homelessness, reasoning that the challenged law applied to anyone who undertook the act of camping, rejecting plaintiffs’ argument “camping, for people without other housing options, was “involuntary” and thus could not be criminalized.
The Court therefore reversed and remanded for further proceedings.
Court Rulings.value: Supreme Court ruling (June 28, 2024; 2024 WL 3208072): Reversed and remanded; held the Eighth Amendment could not support the relief and that punishments were not cruel and unusual; rejected the status-crime theory.

evidences: Therefore, the court entered a preliminary injunction prohibiting the defendants and their officers, agents, employees, attorneys, and any person in active concert or participation with them from (1) installing any additional industrial-style lighting (so-called “Sunbelt” lighting); or doing any paving, filling, excavating, or fencing; or doing any other site expansion, including placing or erecting any additional buildings, tents, dormitories, or other residential or administrative facilities on the TNT site; and (2) bringing any additional persons onto the TNT site who were not already being detained at the site at the time the order went into effect.

It further ordered that after no more than sixty days, and once population attrition allowed for safe implementation, the defendants were to remove 1) the temporary fencing in order to allow tribe members access to the site consistent with the access they enjoyed before the facility was built; 2) the Sunbelt lighting fixtures and any additional lighting installed for the use of the property as a detention facility; and 3) all generators, gas, sewage, and other waste and waste receptacles that were installed for this project.
