evidences: On August 21, 2025, after a hearing, the court granting in part plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. 2025 WL 242325.

Therefore, the court entered a preliminary injunction prohibiting the defendants and their officers, agents, employees, attorneys, and any person in active concert or participation with them from (1) installing any additional industrial-style lighting (so-called “Sunbelt” lighting); or doing any paving, filling, excavating, or fencing; or doing any other site expansion, including placing or erecting any additional buildings, tents, dormitories, or other residential or administrative facilities on the TNT site; and (2) bringing any additional persons onto the TNT site who were not already being detained at the site at the time the order went into effect.

It further ordered that after no more than sixty days, and once population attrition allowed for safe implementation, the defendants were to remove 1) the temporary fencing in order to allow tribe members access to the site consistent with the access they enjoyed before the facility was built; 2) the Sunbelt lighting fixtures and any additional lighting installed for the use of the property as a detention facility; and 3) all generators, gas, sewage, and other waste and waste receptacles that were installed for this project.
Dates of All Decrees.value: August 21, 2025: Court granted in part plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction (2025 WL 242325) and entered a preliminary injunction prohibiting further site expansion and intake of additional detainees, allowing only safety-related modifications, and ordering removal within sixty days (once safe) of fencing, added lighting, and generators/waste equipment.

evidences: This case challenged Florida's and the Trump Administration's construction of an immigration detention facility dubbed "Alligator Alcatraz" in the Everglades.
The facility was built in mere days, which plaintiffs alleged circumvented or ignored regulatory and environmental standards.
Designed to hold up to 5,000 noncitizens at a time, the facility was located on the grounds of the Dade-Collier Training and Transition Airport.
Although the airport was located in Collier County, 36 miles west of Miami, it was owned by Miami-Dade County and operated by that county's aviation department.
Miami-Dade County regulations limited the use of the site to aviation purposes.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves the rapid construction of a large (up to 5,000-person) immigration detention facility (“Alligator Alcatraz”) in the Everglades at the Dade-Collier Training and Transition Airport, alleged to have been built in days and to have bypassed regulatory/environmental standards; supported by the cited facility description and timing; with background such as the site’s ownership/operation by Miami-Dade County, its location 36 miles west of Miami in Collier County, and local regulations limiting the site to aviation uses.

evidences: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis stated that the facility's construction was requested, and would be fully bankrolled, by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) using Federal Emergency Management Agency funds.
In addition, evidence the federal defendants requested that the facility be built and committed federal funding precluded them from disclaiming involvement or responsibility under NEPA.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves DHS’s request for the facility and federal financing via FEMA; supported by the Governor’s statement and the court’s finding that federal defendants requested the build and committed federal funding; with background that this federal involvement ties DHS/ICE to NEPA obligations.

evidences: Plaintiffs were two Florida-based environmental nonprofits, Friends of the Everglades and Center for Biological Diversity.

On June 27, 2025, they filed this action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against DHS and its Secretary; U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and its Acting Director; the Florida Division of Emergency Management and its Executive Director; and Miami-Dade County.

Plaintiffs sought a declaration that defendants' actions were unlawful, an injunction against the continued construction and use of the facility for non-aviation purposes including immigration detention, and attorneys' fees.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves two environmental nonprofits (Friends of the Everglades and Center for Biological Diversity) suing DHS/ICE, the Florida Division of Emergency Management, and Miami-Dade County on June 27, 2025, alleging NEPA, APA, and Miami-Dade County Code violations and ultra vires action; supported by the filing/party details; with background that plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief halting construction/use for non-aviation purposes and fees.

evidences: The County argued that the state of Florida had commandeered the airport under state emergency authority and that it could not use county law to restrain the state; additionally, the County contended that plaintiffs did not have a right of action to compel the County to enforce its own regulations.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case background includes Miami-Dade County’s assertion that Florida commandeered the airport under state emergency authority, limiting the County’s ability to enforce its aviation-only regulations; supported by the County’s response; with context that control of the site was asserted under state emergency powers.

evidences: The federal agencies argued that plaintiffs' case was likely to fail because it did not challenge a final agency action, and did not show that they would suffer an irreparable harm from the detention center's construction given Supreme Court precedent that NEPA violations do not give rise to a presumption of irreparable injury.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Federal agencies argued the case would likely fail because it challenged no final agency action and did not show irreparable harm, noting that NEPA violations don't presume such harm under Supreme Court precedent.

evidences: The Tribe noted that Big Cypress National Preserve, which included the land co-opted to build the detention center, had traditionally been part of its home and that the center's continued construction and operation would accelerate the land's environmental degradation.
The environmental risks posed by the facility threatened irreparable harm to the plaintiffs,
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves environmental and tribal impacts, including risks of environmental degradation to Big Cypress National Preserve—traditionally part of the Miccosukee Tribe’s home—and irreparable environmental harm to plaintiffs; supported by the Tribe’s statements and the court’s finding of environmental risks; with background that the facility sits on land within Big Cypress.

evidences: On July 14, 2025, the Miccosukee Tribe of Florida moved to intervene as a plaintiff in the case.
The court granted the Tribe's motion to intervene on July 30, 2025.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves the Miccosukee Tribe as an intervenor plaintiff due to impacts on its traditional lands within Big Cypress; supported by the intervention and grant dates; with background that tribal interests are directly implicated by the site’s location and environmental impacts.

evidences: the court entered a temporary restraining order that prohibited the state and federal defendants from installing any additional industrial-style lighting, doing any paving, filling, excavating, or fencing, or doing any other site expansion including placing or erecting buildings and other structures.

the court entered a preliminary injunction prohibiting the defendants and their officers, agents, employees, attorneys, and any person in active concert or participation with them from (1) installing any additional industrial-style lighting (so-called “Sunbelt” lighting); or doing any paving, filling, excavating, or fencing; or doing any other site expansion, including placing or erecting any additional buildings, tents, dormitories, or other residential or administrative facilities on the TNT site; and (2) bringing any additional persons onto the TNT site who were not already being detained at the site at the time the order went into effect.

It further ordered that after no more than sixty days, and once population attrition allowed for safe implementation, the defendants were to remove 1) the temporary fencing in order to allow tribe members access to the site consistent with the access they enjoyed before the facility was built; 2) the Sunbelt lighting fixtures and any additional lighting installed for the use of the property as a detention facility; and 3) all generators, gas, sewage, and other waste and waste receptacles that were installed for this project.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves ongoing site expansion activities (industrial ‘Sunbelt’ lighting, paving, filling, excavating, fencing, buildings/tents/dormitories, generators and waste systems) that were enjoined, evidencing the nature and scale of construction; supported by the TRO/PI terms; with background that the court ordered removal of fencing, lighting, and generators/waste systems after attrition to mitigate environmental/tribal access harms.

evidences: As to the TRO, the court concluded that, at minimum, the federal defendants' legal control over the facility's operations, evidence that it was constructed at the request of DHS, and regular inspections of the site by ICE officials, as well as undisputed lack of prior environmental assessment under NEPA, created a sufficient likelihood of success of the merits of the APA claim to warrant preliminary relief.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves federal operational control and involvement (including ICE inspections) and an undisputed absence of a NEPA environmental assessment/EIS despite major environmental effects; supported by the court’s findings; with background that the no-assessment decision was a definitive, final agency action causing concrete injury to plaintiffs.

evidences: Moreover, a substantial portion of events that gave rise to the lawsuit took place within the Southern District, and some of the environmental concerns relevant to the NEPA claim would also affect the Southern District. Finally, the court found that the plaintiffs met the criteria for issuance of a preliminary injunction. As to a likelihood of success on the merits of plaintiffs' NEPA claims, the court noted that the defendants did not dispute the "major" environmental effects that would justify the need for an environmental impact statement or assessment.  Moreover, the decision to construct the detention camp without issuing an impact statement or conducting an assessment was a definitive position that caused actual, concrete injury to the plaintiffs' recreational and conservational interests, and therefore constituted a final agency action. In addition, evidence the federal defendants requested that the facility be built and committed federal funding precluded them from disclaiming involvement or responsibility under NEPA.  The environmental risks posed by the facility threatened irreparable harm to the plaintiffs, and the balance of equities and the public interest similarly favored granting the preliminary injunction.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The court found venue proper in the Southern District due to relevant events and environmental concerns, and granted a preliminary injunction. It held that the government's decision to build the detention center without an environmental assessment caused concrete harm, constituted final agency action, and posed irreparable environmental risks. The balance of equities and public interest also supported the injunction.

evidences: On August 7, 2025, while a multi-day hearing on the preliminary injunction motion was ongoing, the court issued an order granting in part and denying in part the plaintiffs' renewed motion for a limited temporary restraining order.

Citing minimal harm to the defendants from briefly suspending expansion of the facility and the difficulty of reversing course at a later date, the court entered a temporary restraining order that prohibited the state and federal defendants from installing any additional industrial-style lighting, doing any paving, filling, excavating, or fencing, or doing any other site expansion including placing or erecting buildings and other structures.
The TRO was to last fourteen days from the date of the order or until the court entered an order on the preliminary injunction.

evidences: On August 7, 2025, while a multi-day hearing on the preliminary injunction motion was ongoing, the court issued an order granting in part and denying in part the plaintiffs' renewed motion for a limited temporary restraining order.

It further rejected defendants' challenge to the court's jurisdiction, reasoning that because the plaintiffs did not seek to enjoin or restrain the operation of any immigration statute, the statute cited by the defendants to assert lack of jurisdiction was inapplicable.

the court entered a temporary restraining order that prohibited the state and federal defendants from installing any additional industrial-style lighting, doing any paving, filling, excavating, or fencing, or doing any other site expansion including placing or erecting buildings and other structures.
The TRO was to last fourteen days from the date of the order or until the court entered an order on the preliminary injunction.
Court Rulings.value: Renewed motion for a temporary restraining order: Granted in part and denied in part on August 7, 2025; court rejected jurisdictional challenge, deferred venue ruling, and entered a 14-day TRO prohibiting additional lighting, paving, filling, excavating, fencing, or other site expansion (including placing/erecting buildings or structures).

evidences: On August 21, 2025, after a hearing, the court granting in part plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. 2025 WL 242325.

First, it again found that it had jurisdiction over plaintiffs' claim, which neither challenged the fact nor the manner of detention or removal, nor sought to halt, suspend, or alter operation of any INA provision, nor otherwise challenged the defendants' authority to implement or enforce immigration laws (as would preclude jurisdiction under 8 U.S.C. 1252).
Next, the court held that the defendants had waived challenge to venue in the Southern District of Florida by litigating the case on the merits for a month before raising venue issues.

Rejecting the venue argument on the merits, it reasoned that the NEPA claim did not involve "real property" within the meaning of the applicable venue statute and therefore that venue was proper in the Southern District as the home of plaintiff's principal place of business, and not required to lie in the Middle District of Florida, where the facility is located.

Therefore, the court entered a preliminary injunction prohibiting the defendants and their officers, agents, employees, attorneys, and any person in active concert or participation with them from (1) installing any additional industrial-style lighting (so-called “Sunbelt” lighting); or doing any paving, filling, excavating, or fencing; or doing any other site expansion, including placing or erecting any additional buildings, tents, dormitories, or other residential or administrative facilities on the TNT site; and (2) bringing any additional persons onto the TNT site who were not already being detained at the site at the time the order went into effect.
The preliminary injunction did not prohibit modification or repairs to existing facilities that were made for the purpose of increasing safety or mitigating environmental or other risks at the site.

It further ordered that after no more than sixty days, and once population attrition allowed for safe implementation, the defendants were to remove 1) the temporary fencing in order to allow tribe members access to the site consistent with the access they enjoyed before the facility was built; 2) the Sunbelt lighting fixtures and any additional lighting installed for the use of the property as a detention facility; and 3) all generators, gas, sewage, and other waste and waste receptacles that were installed for this project.
Court Rulings.value: Motion for preliminary injunction: Granted in part on August 21, 2025 (2025 WL 242325); court held it had jurisdiction, found defendants waived venue challenge and that venue was proper; found likelihood of success and irreparable harm; enjoined additional lighting, paving, filling, excavating, fencing, or other expansion (including additional structures) and bringing any additional persons onto the site; allowed safety-related repairs; ordered, within no more than 60 days once feasible, removal of fencing, Sunbelt lighting, and generators/waste infrastructure.

Specifically, he granted summary judgment in favor of the individual defendants on all counts, citing both qualified and statutory immunity. evidences: In the aftermath of George Floyd's death in May 2020, nationwide protests erupted, including a significant demonstration in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on May 31, 2020.
Factual Basis of Case.value: A significant protest occurred in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on May 31, 2020, following George Floyd’s death.

evidences: During the protest, the Fort Lauderdale Police Department (FLPD) attempted to disperse the crowd through use of tear gas and kinetic impact projectiles, otherwise known as rubber bullets.
Factual Basis of Case.value: FLPD attempted to disperse the crowd using tear gas and rubber bullets (kinetic impact projectiles).

evidences: The plaintiff in this case, a participant in the May 2020 demonstration, alleged she was shot in the eye by a direct impound round, causing severe, painful, and permanent physical and emotional injuries.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The plaintiff, a protest participant, alleges she was shot in the eye by a direct projectile round, resulting in severe, painful, and permanent physical and emotional injuries.

evidences: In response to her injuries, she filed a lawsuit against the City of Fort Lauderdale and several FLPD officers in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida on May 31, 2022.
The eight-count complaint alleged violations of her constitutional rights under the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments, as well as state law claims for battery and negligence.
The plaintiff asserted municipal liability under a Monell “failure to train” theory.
The plaintiff sought damages, including punitive damages, prejudgment interest on liquidated damages, costs, and compensatory damages.
Factual Basis of Case.value: On May 31, 2022, the plaintiff sued the City of Fort Lauderdale and several FLPD officers in S.D. Fla., alleging First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment violations and state-law battery and negligence, asserting Monell failure-to-train municipal liability, and seeking punitive, compensatory, prejudgment interest, and costs.

evidences: The plaintiff filed an amended complaint on October 27, 2022, wherein she revised the list of named FLDP defendants and added two additional counts: a claim against the City of Fort Lauderdale for negligent instruction, training, and supervision of its officers and a Fourteenth Amendment Procedural Due Process claim against all defendants, alleging that FLDP officers did not issue a proper dispersal order prior to deploying force.
For these additional claims, the plaintiff sought compensatory damages, costs, and injunctive relief.
Factual Basis of Case.value: In the amended complaint, the plaintiff alleged negligent instruction/training/supervision by the City and a Fourteenth Amendment procedural due process violation based on the lack of a proper dispersal order before force was used, seeking compensatory damages, costs, and injunctive relief.

evidences: On September 4, 2024, Judge Ruiz issued an order granting in part and denying in part the various summary judgment motions. 2024 WL 4039849.
Specifically, he granted summary judgment in favor of the individual defendants on all counts, citing both qualified and statutory immunity.

With respect to the city, he denied summary judgment on the two First Amendment claims under the plaintiff’s failure-to-train Monell theory and denied summary judgment as to the state-law battery claim, holding that it would be up to a jury to determine whether the city was liable for the plaintiff’s injuries “through its policies, procedures, and officers’ conduct.”
Factual Basis of Case.value: The court found individual officers immune, but left for a jury the plaintiff’s Monell-based First Amendment claims and state-law battery claim against the City, focusing on potential liability through the City’s policies, procedures, and officers’ conduct.

evidences: On October 28, 2024, before the case proceeded to trial, the parties attended mediation and came to a full and final settlement of all claims, pending final consideration and approval by the Fort Lauderdale City Commission.
The city commission approved [https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/broward/article296526834.html] a $1.975 million settlement at its meeting on December 3, 2024.
As part of the settlement, FLPD also agreed to overhaul its internal policies.
The court approved the settlement on December 23, 2024.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The parties settled all claims: the City approved a $1.975 million payment, FLPD agreed to overhaul internal policies, and the court approved the settlement on December 23, 2024.

evidences: On April 28, 2025, the American Federation of Government Employees and several other labor organizations, nonprofits, and cities/counties filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.
They named President Donald Trump and numerous federal departments and agencies and their agency heads as Defendants.
They challenged the executive order and implementing memoranda under the Separation of Powers and the Administrative Procedure Act.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs (AFGE and other unions, nonprofits, and local governments) filed suit on April 28, 2025 in N.D. Cal. against President Trump and multiple federal departments/agencies and their heads, asserting Separation of Powers and APA claims.

evidences: The Plaintiffs challenged Executive Order 14210, which ordered agencies across the federal government to engage in a radical transformation of the federal bureaucracy, including by conducting large-scale Reductions in Force (RIFs), without Congressional authorization.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The challenged action is Executive Order 14210 directing large-scale federal bureaucracy transformation and RIFs without Congressional authorization.

evidences: The government immediately filed an appeal, and sought a stay pending appellate litigation.
The district court declined to enter a stay, and the 9th Circuit set a schedule for briefing to proceed through May 22 (the day before the TRO is set to expire unless extended).
On May 16, the government asked the Supreme Court to grant a stay.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The government promptly appealed and sought stays in both the Ninth Circuit and Supreme Court during the TRO phase.

evidences: Back in the district court, after briefing, on May 22, 2025, Judge Illston granted a preliminary injunction, barring the challenged government actions during the pendency of the litigation.
Following the lead of numerous other courts, Judge Illston rejected the arguement that the agencies were acting of their own accord and were not directed by OMB.
Judge Illston held the President would exceed his authority by dismantling programs authorized by Congress.
The court reasoned that the dramatic staff reductions will render the agencies unable to do what Congress directs the agencies to do.
In light of the evidence, Judge Illston held that the plaintiff's were likely to succeed in their claims that the defendants exceeded their statutory and constitutional authority.
American Federation Of Government Employees, AFL-CIO v. Trump, F. Supp. 3d, 2025 WL 1358477 (N.D. Cal. 2025).
Factual Basis of Case.value: On May 22, 2025, the court issued a preliminary injunction, finding evidence that OMB directed agency actions, that large RIFs would disable congressionally mandated functions, and that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on claims that the Executive lacked statutory/constitutional authority.

evidences: A dissent by Circuit Judge Consuelo M. Callahan countered that Article II of the Constitution vests the President with sufficient authority to cover the challenged conduct.

Judge Callahan dissented that the Executive Order and memorandum merely directed agencies to exercise their own lawful statutory authority and that the district court erred by not finding whether specific RIFs would violate statutory mandates or eliminate agencies.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The Ninth Circuit dissent argued Article II provides sufficient authority and faulted the district court for not analyzing specific RIFs’ statutory impacts.

evidences: First looking at jurisdiction, the court found that the plaintiffs' claims were not appropriately channeled through the comprehensive administrative system established by the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA), because the CSRA did not give any administrative tribunal the authority to address broad challenges to the defendants' constitutional and statutory authority to direct large-scale federal reorganizations and reductions in force.  On the merits, the court found that neither the Constitution nor any federal statute grants the President the authority to direct the kind of large-scale reorganization of the federal government at issue, noting that the challenged RIFs appear "inextricably intertwined with broad agency reorganization, which the president undoubtedly cannot undertake without Congress."
Factual Basis of Case.value: The Ninth Circuit denied a stay, concluding CSRA channeling did not apply to these broad challenges and indicating the President likely lacks authority for large-scale reorganizations/RIFs without Congress.

evidences: On July 8, the Court granted the stay of the preliminary injunction entered by the United States District Court for the Northern District of California pending the appeal in the United States Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit and the disposition of a petition for a writ of certiorari.
The Court reasoned that the executive order and implementing memoranda themselves were likely legal as they only direct agencies to plan reorganizations in force "consistent with applicable law.".
The Court declined to express a view on the legality of the Agency RIF or Agency RIF and Reorganization Plan (ARRPs) saying that it was outside the scope of the question in front of them.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The Supreme Court stayed the preliminary injunction, reasoning that the EO and memoranda likely only direct planning consistent with law and expressly reserving judgment on the legality of specific Agency RIFs/ARRPs.

evidences: Justice Jackson dissented from grant of application for stay.
She argued that the Court made this determination outside of the facts and evidence necessary to "responsibly override, reasoned lower court fact-finding."
Justice Jackson pointed to the District Court's preliminary findings (which were based "on actual evidence") and argued that the Supreme Court should have declined to intervene.
She further argued that the executive order and memorandum themselves were unconstitutional executive action that does not "rest on any grant of reorganization authority by Congress."
Factual Basis of Case.value: Justice Jackson’s dissent emphasized the district court’s evidence-based findings and argued the EO/memorandum lack congressional reorganization authority.

evidences: The Court resting the granting of the stay on the merits of the case was inappropriate because the District Court issued an injunction based on the facts collected.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Court granting of the stay was inappropriate because the district court an injunction based on the facts.

evidences: In response to the stay by the Supreme Court, the plaintiffs asked Judge Illston to reconsider the plaintiffs' request that the government turn over the specific agency proposals for reductions-in-force (RIFs).
The government asserted that these documents were protected by the deliberative process privilege.
However, Judge Illston rejected this argument, finding that the documents were "likely not pre-decisional and deliberative documents."
Judge Illston then ordered the government to respond to the plaintiffs' request by July 14, 2025.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs sought production of specific agency RIF proposals; the court rejected deliberative process privilege and ordered a response by July 14, 2025.

evidences: The plaintiffs moved for an order shortening the government's time to respond to the discovery request for the RIFs and AARPs (from the standard 30 days to 14 days).
The government responded by saying that all the plaintiffs' claim were APA claims and thus, there is no basis for any discovery in the adjudication of those claims.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs sought expedited discovery of RIFs and ARRPs; the government argued APA review precludes discovery.

evidences: The motion consisted of seven major claims:

• Discovery is premature because the government still had not responded to the complaint and was planning on moving to dismiss the complaint. The government requested the court rule on the forthcoming motion first before the request for discovery.   • The government reiterated that it would be inappropriate to grant discovery in the adjudication of an APA claim, particularly before an administrative record is certified.   • The requested information is not relevant in light of the stay by the Supreme Court.   • DOGE and United States DOGE services are not agencies that can be sued subject to the APA. The discovery sought against them is without basis.   • The Request for Production (RFP) 1 seeks documents that should be protected by deliberative process privilege.   • The plaintiffs' demand for application for waivers of RIF notice periods and all responses by OMB or OPM to those applications are not relevant to the issues before the court.   • The discovery sought by the plaintiffs is outside the scope of relief the court could grant. The court cannot review the lawfulness of the ARRPs because they are not final agency actions under the APA.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The government argues discovery is premature, as it plans to move for dismissal first. It claims the requested information is irrelevant and protected by privilege, and DOGE services can't be sued under the APA. Additionally, the ARRPs aren’t final agency actions, so the court can't review them.

evidences: Judge Illston granted this motion in part and denied it in part on July 18.
The court reject the government's assertion that the Supreme Court's stay "ends this case" because the stay did not reach several claims in the amended complaint.

The Supreme Court's decision did not foreclose considerations of the legality of the ARRPs ("In a concurrence, Justice Sotomayor noted that the Supreme Court's decision allows the district court to consider the legality of the ARRPs in the 'first instance.'")
Judge Illston reiterated that a full review of the ARRPs would "significantly aid the Court's review of the merits of these APA claims."
Judge Illston rejected the government's argument that the plaintiffs never challenged any of the ARRPs as being arbitrary and capricious.
Judge Illston held that the Ninth Circuit has consistently recognized "narrow exceptions" to the general rule that the reviewal of APA claims are limited to the administrative record.

Finally, the court held that even if some material within the ARRPs should be protected by deliberative process privilege, "the need for accurate fact finding overrides the government's interest in non-disclosure."
Factual Basis of Case.value: On July 18, the court partially granted discovery: it allowed review of ARRPs as aiding APA merits, recognized exceptions to record-only review, and held any deliberative privilege yields to the need for accurate fact-finding; Supreme Court’s stay did not end claims, and ARRPs’ legality remains reviewable.

evidences: She argued that the defendants are " [arguing] essentially that plaintiffs cannot prove their case because plaintiffs do not have the ARRPs because the ARRPs have not been made public."
Factual Basis of Case.value: Illston argued that the defendants are essentially claiming that the plaintiffs can’t prove their case because the ARRPs haven’t been made public.

evidences: However, at this point, Judge Illston limited the distribution of the ARRPs to the plaintiffs' counsel and the court.
The court also allowed the defendants to redact any material addressing union negotiating strategy to the plaintiffs' counsel.
The government was ordered to provide the full version to the court and to highlight any redacted material.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Discovery protections: ARRPs limited to counsel and court; union negotiation strategy may be redacted for plaintiffs’ counsel, with full unredacted versions submitted to the court highlighting redactions.

evidences: The government filed two motions on July 21: a motion to dismiss and a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction. The government alleged that in light of the Supreme Court's decision, all the plaintiff's claims fail. This is due to the fact that all the claims in the amended complaint "depend on the assertion that the Workforce Executive Order, the Workforce Memorandum, or both are unlawful." Further, the government alleged that to the extent the complaint challenges the ARPs, the ARPs are not final agency actions subject to review under the APA. The government complains that the allegations regarding the RIFs and the ARPs are speculation about future actions the government will take. In regards to the jurisdiction arguments, the government argued that challenges to the lawfulness of federal agency personnel action are precluded from district court review. The government reasserted its claim that the complaint be dismissed as to DOGE which is an initiative and not an agency that can be sued.
Factual Basis of Case.value: On July 21, the government moved to dismiss on merits and jurisdictional grounds: asserting Supreme Court’s stay undermines claims, ARPs are not final APA actions, CSRA precludes district court review of personnel actions, and DOGE is not a suable agency.

evidences: The district court released a statement in response to augment the appellate record. However, in response to the discovery order, the petitioners produced a list of those represented RIFs, and numerous agencies that were not defendants in the case (and therefore, not enjoined by the preliminary injunction) were included in the figure presented to the Supreme Court. Judge Illston highlighted that this is no insignificant discrepancy and she reasserted her previous finding that "any deliberative process privilege. . .is overridden by 'the need for accurate fact-finding in this litigation.'"

evidences: Back in the district court, after briefing, on May 22, 2025, Judge Illston granted a preliminary injunction, barring the challenged government actions during the pendency of the litigation. Following the lead of numerous other courts, Judge Illston rejected the arguement that the agencies were acting of their own accord and were not directed by OMB. Judge Illston held the President would exceed his authority by dismantling programs authorized by Congress. The court reasoned that the dramatic staff reductions will render the agencies unable to do what Congress directs the agencies to do. In light of the evidence, Judge Illston held that the plaintiff's were likely to succeed in their claims that the defendants exceeded their statutory and constitutional authority. American Federation Of Government Employees, AFL-CIO v. Trump, F. Supp. 3d, 2025 WL 1358477 (N.D. Cal. 2025).
Court Rulings.value: Preliminary injunction granted on May 22, 2025, barring the challenged actions during the litigation.

American Federation Of Government Employees, AFL-CIO v. Trump, F. 4th, 2025 WL 1541714 (9th Cir. 2025).

evidences: The plaintiffs sought a declaration that South Carolina's current congressional and legislative plans were unconstitutional; an injunction preventing the defendants from using the old plans in any future elections; an order establishing a schedule by which the State—or the court if they fail—must enact new, lawful congressional and legislative redistricting plans; and an order staying the primary candidate filing and qualification deadlines pending the implementation of lawful new districts.
Remedy Sought.value: Declaratory judgment that current congressional and legislative plans were unconstitutional; injunction barring use of old plans in any future elections; order setting a schedule for enactment of new lawful congressional and legislative plans (by the State, or by the court if the State failed); and an order staying primary candidate filing and qualification deadlines until lawful new districts are implemented.

evidences: The plaintiffs added a new request for relief, asking that the court declare the new districts unconstitutional, impose a temporary and permanent injunction barring the defendants from using the plan in any future elections, and order new redistricting plans in the event the defendants failed to adopt new plans by February 15, 2022.
Remedy Sought.value: Declaratory judgment that the newly enacted districts were unconstitutional; temporary and permanent injunction barring use of the plan in any future elections; and an order requiring new redistricting plans if defendants failed to adopt new plans by February 15, 2022.

evidences: represented by the ACLU and the NAACP Legal Defense Fund
represented by the ACLU and the NAACP Legal Defense Fund
The case was assigned to District Judge J. Michelle Childs, but the plaintiffs requested a three-judge panel under 28 U.S.C. §2284 on October 15, 2021, which the court granted on December 9.
On December 16, the Chief Judge for the Fourth Circuit appointed Circuit Judge Toby J. Heytens and District Judge Richard M. Gergel to preside with Judge Childs.
On December 16, the Chief Judge for the Fourth Circuit appointed Circuit Judge Toby J. Heytens and District Judge Richard M. Gergel to preside with Judge Childs.
District Judge Margaret B. Seymour was assigned to replace Judge Childs on the three-judge panel, but she announced her retirement from the bench a short while later.
On July 21, 2022, District Judge Mary Geiger Lewis was assigned to the case.
The court noted that numerous three-judge courts have adjudicated challenges to district lines and been affirmed by the Supreme Court. 2021 WL 5853172.
The defendants moved to disqualify Judge Gergel on January 6, and he declined to recuse himself on January 10. 2022 WL 2374229.
The defendants moved for reconsideration of his recusal on January 18, which he denied on January 19. 2022 WL 2374225.
In that light, the proceedings were stayed until January 18, 2021. 572 F.Supp.3d 215.

Given the importance of drawing fair election districts, which will exist for a decade, the court granted a large quantity of discovery to the plaintiffs, including depositions of all legislators, staff, and consultants involved in the creation of the maps, and numerous categories of documents related to their creation. 584 F.Supp.3d 152.
Also on February 10, the court gave leave to the plaintiffs to file a second amended complaint, 2022 WL 408427, which they filed that same day.

On the same day, February 14, the court denied the House defendants’ motions, holding that the NAACP plausibly alleged it has 13,000 members who reside in every county of South Carolina, which is enough to show it has standing in the pleading stage. 2022 WL 453533.

The plaintiffs and House defendants reached a settlement agreement prior to April 22, 2022, but the court denied their motions for approval of the settlement on April 25, holding that the House defendants alone did not have the requisite authority to settle the claims. 2022 WL 2375812.

The court further held that discriminatory intent and improper use of race in drawing district lines can be proved by circumstantial evidence, and the plaintiffs alleged sufficient circumstantial evidence to survive a motion to dismiss. 2022 WL 2334410.

The court denied the motion to strike on September 2, 2022, choosing instead to extend the discovery deadline to allow the defendants to respond and conduct their own discovery for the new disclosures. 2022 WL 4009058.

In two opinions filed on September 15, the court denied all of the motions because the purpose of evidentiary gatekeeping is to keep unreliable evidence from the jury. Since the forthcoming trial was to be a bench trial, the judges found “there is less need for the gatekeeper to keep the gate when the gatekeeper is keeping the gate only for herself or himself.” 2022 WL 4276713.

It held that, viewing the evidence in a light most favorable to the plaintiffs, issues of material fact remained as to whether the defendants engaged in intentional discrimination against Black South Carolinians or used race as a proxy for partisan goals. 2022 WL 4295187.

The panel issued a ruling on January 6, 2023, declaring that District 1 was a racial gerrymander and constituted intentional discrimination against the plaintiffs. The court held that the plaintiffs did not meet their burden for Districts 2 and 5. The order enjoined elections in District 1 until further order of the court and gave the South Carolina General Assembly until March 31, 2023 to present the court with a remedial map for consideration. 649 F.Supp.3d 177.
The Supreme Court noted probable jurisdiction on May 15, 2023, and the case proceeded into the merits briefing stage.
All Reported Opinions Cited with Shorten.value: 143 S.Ct. 2456 — Supreme Court noted probable jurisdiction (May 15, 2023).

The court denied these motions on June 28, 2022, holding that the private plaintiff had standing to challenge the district he lived in and the NAACP had associational standing because it had members in the challenged districts.

evidences: This case is about citizens of South Carolina challenging the constitutionality of election district apportionment, redistricting, and gerrymandering in their state.

evidences: First, the plaintiffs alleged that population shifts had caused the state's congressional and legislative redistricting plans to become malapportioned in violation of the one person, one vote constitutional principle under Article I, Section 2 and the 14th Amendment, which would  infringe on the plaintiffs' 1st and 14th Amendment rights to participate equally in the political process. Second, the plaintiffs asserted that the legislature’s decision to delay the commencement of their redistricting process until early 2022 was violating the plaintiffs' Freedom of Association because the uncertainty over new district boundaries would hurt candidates' ability to effectively run for office and restrict voters’ ability to choose candidates. They also asserted the state's shortened time period for redistricting effectively would preclude sufficient time for public input or judicial review sufficiently in advance of the elections. The plaintiffs sought a declaration that South Carolina's current congressional and legislative plans were unconstitutional; an injunction preventing the defendants from using the old plans in any future elections; an order establishing a schedule by which the State—or the court if they fail—must enact new, lawful congressional and legislative redistricting plans; and an order staying the primary candidate filing and qualification deadlines pending the implementation of lawful new districts.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Plaintiffs argued that population shifts had caused South Carolina's redistricting maps to become malapportioned and that the delay of the commencement of the redistricting process was a violation of their constitutional rights.

evidences: the plaintiffs requested a three-judge panel under 28 U.S.C. §2284 on October 15, 2021, which the court granted on December 9.
The court noted that numerous three-judge courts have adjudicated challenges to district lines and been affirmed by the Supreme Court. 2021 WL 5853172.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Procedural background: A three-judge panel under 28 U.S.C. § 2284 was convened to adjudicate the redistricting challenge, as based on previous precedent.

Factual Basis of Case.value: Background legal context: Defendants invoked Rucho v. Common Cause to argue freedom-of-association claims tied to partisan gerrymandering were nonviable.

evidences: On November 4, 2021, the House defendants moved the court to stay the case because they argued it was not ripe because new lines had yet to be drawn but would be drawn before the preliminary filing deadlines for the 2022 election cycle. They urged the court to stay the case against them until the legislature actually fails to reapportion in a timely manner. The Senate defendants filed a motion to dismiss or, in the alternative, to stay the case on November 9, 2021. Their arguments were similar to the House defendants’, but they requested a dismissal due to lack of ripeness rather than merely a stay. Also on November 9, the Governor moved to dismiss the case, arguing that the plaintiffs’ freedom of association claims did not survive the Supreme Court’s decision in Rucho v. Common Cause.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Both the Senate and House defendants moved the court to stay, but the Senate also filed a dismissal. The Governor additionally moved to dismiss the case.

evidences: The court granted the motion to stay and denied the Senate defendants’ motion to dismiss on November 12, 2021, but it declined to rule on the Governor’s motion, noting in a footnote that the motion went to the merits of the claim rather than jurisdiction. Supporting its decision to stay the case, the court noted that the threat that the Legislature won’t complete redistricting before January was too speculative. It also noted that, if redistricting still had not been completed before the Legislature’s Regular Session (beginning  January 11), the threat of vote dilution would be more imminent. In that light, the proceedings were stayed until January 18, 2021. 572 F.Supp.3d 215.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The court reasoned that it was speculation that the Legislature wouldn't complete redistricting in a timely manner.

evidences: On December 10, 2021, the Governor signed a new state legislature district map into law.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Event: South Carolina enacted a new state legislative district map on Dec. 10, 2021.

evidences: On December 23, 2021, the plaintiffs amended their complaint to add two claims challenging the redistricted maps as unconstitutional.
Their first new claim argued the map was a racial gerrymander in violation of the 14th Amendment's Equal Protection Clause.
Second, they contended the new districts were drawn with a racially discriminatory intent against Black voters in violation of the 14th and 15th Amendments.

The plaintiffs added a new request for relief, asking that the court declare the new districts unconstitutional, impose a temporary and permanent injunction barring the defendants from using the plan in any future elections, and order new redistricting plans in the event the defendants failed to adopt new plans by February 15, 2022.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Amended factual claims (Dec. 23, 2021): Plaintiffs alleged the new state legislative map was a racial gerrymander and enacted with racially discriminatory intent against Black voters, seeking injunctions and court-ordered new plans if necessary.

evidences: The plaintiffs moved to compel the House Defendants to disclose documents and testimony on February 2, 2022, after the defendants issued a blanket objection to the plaintiffs’ discovery requests by asserting “legislative privilege.”
The court granted the motion in part and denied it in part on February 10, 2022, holding that legislative privilege is qualified and depends on the balance of interests.

Given the importance of drawing fair election districts, which will exist for a decade, the court granted a large quantity of discovery to the plaintiffs, including depositions of all legislators, staff, and consultants involved in the creation of the maps, and numerous categories of documents related to their creation.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Evidence access: Court compelled significant discovery despite legislative privilege, allowing depositions of legislators, staff, and consultants, and production of map-creation documents.

evidences: Many of the motions over the rest of the following year of litigation concern the defendants claiming privilege and moving to quash discovery requests with the plaintiffs in turn filing motions to compel discovery, with the court balancing the respective interests in its rulings.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Defendants and plaintiffs battled over the rest of the year in terms of discovery requests.

evidences: At that point, the plaintiffs removed the Governor as a defendant, mooting his previous motions. Prior to February 10, the South Carolina Legislature passed redistricted maps for the state’s U.S. Congressional districts, and the second amended complaint adds two counts challenging those maps as  racial gerrymanders and alleging they were drawn with discriminatory intent.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs removed the Governor as a defendant, mooting his previous motions. Meanwhile, the South Carolina Legislature passed new redistricting maps, and the second amended complaint added two counts, challenging the maps as racial gerrymanders with discriminatory intent.

evidences: arguing that, because the individual plaintiff was not challenging the house district map and the NAACP didn’t identify any members who lived in the challenged districts, the plaintiffs lacked standing to bring their complaint against the House defendants. They also argued that the plaintiffs failed to plausibly plead racial gerrymandering.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The court argued that the plaintiffs lacked standing to bring their complaint against the House defendants.

evidences: They challenged the plaintiffs’ standing to challenge the district maps and asserted that they had not alleged enough facts to plausibly support their claims.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The Senate and House defendants asserted that the plaintiffs' claims could not be supported.

evidences: The Senate and House defendants moved for summary judgment on August 19, arguing that their maps were drawn as a partisan gerrymander to disenfranchise democratic party voters rather than based on race.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Defendants’ factual theory: The maps were drawn for partisan objectives (disadvantaging Democratic voters), not race-based purposes.

evidences: The panel based its District 1 ruling primarily on the fact that the district’s constituency changed significantly while its black voter population remained constant, which required the removal of 30,000 black residents. The standard for finding a racial gerrymander is whether race “predominated” in the drawing of a district’s boundaries (which is also the standard for discriminatory intent in reapportioning districts). The panel found that race predominated in the drawing of District 1, relying on testimony from the redistricting map’s designer as well as statistical modeling provided by expert witnesses. The map’s designer was directed to keep two of the district’s counties whole, which forced him to substantially redraw the boundaries to achieve the plan’s overall political gerrymandering goals. The court based its inference of racial predominance on the upheaval in the district’s population with the percentage of black voters remaining constant, the makeup of specific communities that were split, and models showing that the state’s ostensible partisanship goals could have been achieved without “exiling” black voters from the district. 649 F.Supp.3d 177.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Trial reasoning for District 1: court applied predominance standard; relied on mapmaker testimony and expert modeling; found race predominated due to constant Black voter percentage despite significant constituency changes requiring removal of ~30,000 Black residents.

evidences: The panel’s determination that District 2 was not a racial gerrymander rested on the fact that its disputed features were consistent with its shape before the present redistricting plan and the intent was consistent with incumbent protection—a permissible redistricting concern.
For District 5, the panel determined that the change in black voters from the previous plan to the present plan was too small to carry an inference of racial gerrymandering.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Findings for CDs 2 and 5: No racial gerrymander—CD2 changes aligned with preexisting shape and incumbent protection; CD5’s Black voter change was too small to infer racial predominance.

evidences: Defendants noted that they were awaiting the Supreme Court’s decision on their appeal, but that election deadlines for 2024 election candidates were imminent, including in District. Defendants argued that the only appropriate course of actions was for the district court to grant a partial stay and allow the 2024 elections to proceed in District 1, regardless of the district court’s view of the merits of Defendant’s appeal to the Supreme Court. The NAACP opposed defendants’ motion for partial stay of the court’s January 6, 2023 order.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The election deadlines for 2024 election candidates were imminent, so the defendants argued that the district court should grant a partial stay.

evidences: On March 20, 2024, the defendants filed an application for stay of the district court panel’s injunction for the 2024 elections with the United States Supreme Court. Again, the NAACP opposed the motion.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The NAACP opposed the defendants filing a stay of the district court panel's injunction.

evidences: The opinion for the majority was written by Justice Alito and joined by Justices Roberts, Thomas, Gorsuch, Kavanaugh, and Barrett.

The Court ruled that the district court’s finding that race predominated in the design of South Carolina’s first congressional district was clearly erroneous, so its racial-gerrymandering and vote-dilution holdings were reversed.

In the opinion, Justice Alito reasoned that the plaintiffs provided no direct evidence, and only weak circumstantial evidence, of a racial gerrymander. Further, the four experts, who the plaintiffs provided, and on whose testimony the district court relied, were flawed because they ignored certain traditional districting criteria in their analysis. Additionally, Alito states that the plaintiffs failed to provide an alternate districting map that would show how the State could have achieved its political objectives while producing greater racial balance.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Supreme Court evidentiary assessment: Reversed the racial-gerrymander/vote-dilution holdings for CD1 as clearly erroneous, citing lack of direct evidence, weak circumstantial proof, flawed expert analyses (ignoring traditional criteria), and failure to present an alternative map demonstrating feasibility.

evidences: The vote-diluting claim was additionally remanded to the district court.

On June 28. 2024, following the Supreme Court’s remand of the plaintiff’s voter-dilution claim to the district court for further proceedings, the district court issued an order requesting the parties submit memorandums addressing whether the legislature acted with dilutive intent and whether the enacted map had a dilutive effect.
On July 26, 2024, prior to either party submitting the requested memorandum, the plaintiffs filed a joint stipulation for voluntary dismissal with prejudice.
Subsequently, on August 1, 2024, the district court dismissed the case with prejudice and ordered the Clerk of the Court to close the case.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Post-remand and disposition: Vote dilution was remanded, but plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed with prejudice; the district court dismissed and closed the case on Aug. 1, 2024.

evidences: In the opinion, Justice Alito reasoned that the plaintiffs provided no direct evidence, and only weak circumstantial evidence, of a racial gerrymander. Further, the four experts, who the plaintiffs provided, and on whose testimony the district court relied, were flawed because they ignored certain traditional districting criteria in their analysis. Additionally, Alito states that the plaintiffs failed to provide an alternate districting map that would show how the State could have achieved its political objectives while producing greater racial balance. In light of these three issues, Alito stated that the district court’s finding that race predominated the redistricting map was clearly erroneous.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Justice Alito's reasoning in the majority opinion was that the plaintiffs provided no direct evidence of racial gerrymandering.

evidences: Justice Thomas joined the majority but wrote a concurring opinion, arguing that the Court’s review of the expert reports exceeds the proper scope of clear-error review.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Justice Thomas concurred, arguing that the expert reports exceed the proper scope of clear-error review.

evidences: Justice Kagan wrote a dissenting opinion and was joined by Justices Sotomayor and Jackson. Justice Kagan argued that rather than giving the district court’s view of the evidence “significant deference” as is required by the clear error standard of review, the majority inverted the clear-error standard by using the presumption that the South Carolina legislature acted in good faith and by making any “possibility” that favored the defendants as dispositive.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Justice Kagan wrote a dissenting opinion, arguing that the majority did not apply the clean-error standard correctly when assuming good faith from the South Carolina legislature.

Note Important Filings.value: Plaintiffs’ request for a three-judge panel under 28 U.S.C. § 2284 (Oct 15, 2021)

the proceedings were stayed until January 18, 2021. 572 F.Supp.3d 215.

evidences: The House defendants and the Governor filed separate motions to dismiss for failure to state a claim on January 6, 2022, with the Governor filing a motion for summary judgment on February 1, arguing that he had legislative immunity from suit for signing a bill into law, and that the general authority of a state’s chief executive is  insufficient to make a governor a defendant in a case challenging the constitutionality of a law.
Note Important Filings.value: House and Governor motions to dismiss for failure to state a claim (Jan 6, 2022)

evidences: with the Governor filing a motion for summary judgment on February 1, arguing that he had legislative immunity from suit for signing a bill into law, and that the general authority of a state’s chief executive is  insufficient to make a governor a defendant in a case challenging the constitutionality of a law.

They also moved to stay the order compelling discovery until the jurisdictional issue was resolved.

evidences: On February 15, 2022, in a hearing before Judge Gergel, the plaintiffs and House defendants requested a two week stay to allow for settlement negotiations, which was granted in the hearing.
Note Important Filings.value: Joint request by plaintiffs and House defendants for a two-week stay for settlement negotiations (Feb 15, 2022); granted.

evidences: While settlement negotiations occurred, the Election defendants filed their answer and a motion to dismiss on February 24, 2022, arguing that the plaintiffs fail to plausibly claim the new map results in adverse effects on an identifiable group and was enacted because of that effect, not merely in spite of it.
Note Important Filings.value: Election defendants’ motion to dismiss on the basis that the plaintiffs fail to provide a sufficient and believable claim that the new map constitutes discrimination against a particular group (Feb 24, 2022).

evidences: The plaintiffs amended their complaint a third time on May 6, 2022 to remove counts one and two as agreed in the settlement. They maintained their challenge to the congressional district maps as racial gerrymandering and intentional discrimination.
Note Important Filings.value: Plaintiff filed amended complaint with first two counts removed as per settlement terms, while maintaining the complaint that the congressional district maps are not racial gerrymandering and intentional discrimination (May 6, 2022).

evidences: In response, the Senate and House defendants filed separate motions to dismiss for failure to state a claim on May 20, 2022.

The court denied these motions on June 28, 2022, holding that the private plaintiff had standing to challenge the district he lived in and the NAACP had associational standing because it had members in the challenged districts.

evidences: The plaintiffs moved to compel the House Defendants to disclose documents and testimony on February 2, 2022, after the defendants issued a blanket objection to the plaintiffs’ discovery requests by asserting “legislative privilege.” The court granted the motion in part and denied it in part on February 10, 2022, holding that legislative privilege is qualified and depends on the balance of interests. Given the importance of drawing fair election districts, which will exist for a decade, the court granted a large quantity of discovery to the plaintiffs, including depositions of all legislators, staff, and consultants involved in the creation of the maps, and numerous categories of documents related to their creation. 584 F.Supp.3d 152.
Significant Terms of Decrees.value: House Defendants were ordered to provide extensive discovery, including producing numerous categories of documents related to map creation and submitting to depositions of all legislators, staff, and consultants involved.

evidences: The panel issued a ruling on January 6, 2023, declaring that District 1 was a racial gerrymander and constituted intentional discrimination against the plaintiffs. The court held that the plaintiffs did not meet their burden for Districts 2 and 5. The order enjoined elections in District 1 until further order of the court and gave the South Carolina General Assembly until March 31, 2023 to present the court with a remedial map for consideration. 649 F.Supp.3d 177.
Significant Terms of Decrees.value: Defendants were enjoined from conducting elections in Congressional District 1, and the South Carolina General Assembly was ordered to present a remedial map by March 31, 2023.

evidences: On February 4, 2023, the court denied the defendants’ motion because they did not demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits. The court did, however, extend the South Carolina legislature’s deadline to submit a new district map until 30 days after the Supreme Court resolved defendants’ appeal.
Significant Terms of Decrees.value: The deadline for the South Carolina legislature to submit a remedial district map was extended to 30 days after the Supreme Court resolved defendants’ appeal.

evidences: However, on March 28, 2024, the District Court modified its injunction to “preserve the status quo on appeal.” The District Court added language to note that the Court enjoined the conducting of an election in District 1 after the 2024 election cycle until a constitutionally valid apportionment plan was approved by the Court.

evidences: On May 5, 2022, the plaintiffs and House defendants reached an effective settlement agreement in which the parties agreed that the House defendants would take steps to enact agreed upon districting maps.
The agreement contemplates that the State Senate and Governor will complete the legislative process to enact the maps, but doesn’t bind them to do so.
In exchange, the plaintiffs agreed to drop counts one and two from their complaint, with the ability to reallege the claims if the maps were not enacted.
Significant Terms of Settlement.value: Settlement: House defendants agreed to take steps to enact agreed-upon districting maps (with no binding obligation on the Senate or Governor); plaintiffs dismissed counts one and two, reserving the right to re-allege if the maps were not enacted.

evidences: the plaintiffs requested a three-judge panel under 28 U.S.C. §2284 on October 15, 2021, which the court granted on December 9.
On December 16, the Chief Judge for the Fourth Circuit appointed Circuit Judge Toby J. Heytens and District Judge Richard M. Gergel to preside with Judge Childs.
The defendants moved to disqualify Judge Gergel on January 6, and he declined to recuse himself on January 10. 2022 WL 2374229.
The defendants moved for reconsideration of his recusal on January 18, which he denied on January 19. 2022 WL 2374225.
On April 5, 2022, Judge Childs withdrew from the case after being nominated for the D.C. Circuit.
District Judge Margaret B. Seymour was assigned to replace Judge Childs on the three-judge panel, but she announced her retirement from the bench a short while later.
On July 21, 2022, District Judge Mary Geiger Lewis was assigned to the case.
Trials.value: Three-judge panel convened; composition finalized before trial as Judges Heytens, Gergel, and Mary Geiger Lewis; motions to recuse Judge Gergel denied.

evidences: On August 16, 2022, the Senate and House defendants moved to strike plaintiffs’ supplemental disclosures as improper and to exclude some of their witnesses as untimely, arguing that the timing of the filings violated Federal Rule 26.

The court denied the motion to strike on September 2, 2022, choosing instead to extend the discovery deadline to allow the defendants to respond and conduct their own discovery for the new disclosures. 2022 WL 4009058.
Trials.value: Pretrial: motion to strike plaintiffs’ supplemental disclosures denied on Sept. 2, 2022; discovery deadline extended to accommodate trial preparation.

evidences: On September 2, 2022 the plaintiffs and defendants filed a substantial number of motions in limine to exclude expert testimony and exclude certain evidence or arguments.

In two opinions filed on September 15, the court denied all of the motions because the purpose of evidentiary gatekeeping is to keep unreliable evidence from the jury. Since the forthcoming trial was to be a bench trial, the judges found “there is less need for the gatekeeper to keep the gate when the gatekeeper is keeping the gate only for herself or himself.” 2022 WL 4276713.
Trials.value: Pretrial: all motions in limine denied on Sept. 15, 2022, with court citing reduced need for gatekeeping in forthcoming bench trial.

evidences: The court also denied the defendants’ summary judgment motion on September 15, 2022. It held that, viewing the evidence in a light most favorable to the plaintiffs, issues of material fact remained as to whether the defendants engaged in intentional discrimination against Black South Carolinians or used race as a proxy for partisan goals. 2022 WL 4295187.
Trials.value: Pretrial: defendants’ summary judgment motion denied on Sept. 15, 2022, allowing issues to proceed to trial.

evidences: On October 6, 2022, the three-judge panel held a bench trial. The trial lasted until October 14, with closing arguments held on November 29, 2022.
Trials.value: Bench trial before three-judge panel held Oct. 6–14, 2022; closing arguments on Nov. 29, 2022.

evidences: The panel issued a ruling on January 6, 2023, declaring that District 1 was a racial gerrymander and constituted intentional discrimination against the plaintiffs.
The court held that the plaintiffs did not meet their burden for Districts 2 and 5.

The order enjoined elections in District 1 until further order of the court and gave the South Carolina General Assembly until March 31, 2023 to present the court with a remedial map for consideration. 649 F.Supp.3d 177.
Trials.value: Trial outcome (Jan. 6, 2023): District 1 found to be a racial gerrymander and intentionally discriminatory; claims for Districts 2 and 5 rejected; injunction issued barring elections in District 1 and remedial map due by Mar. 31, 2023.

evidences: On January 27, 2023, the defendants notified the court that they were appealing its ruling to the U.S. Supreme Court—which exercises direct appellate review over decisions of District Courts sitting in three-judge panels—and they moved to stay the order pending the Court’s review.

On February 4, 2023, the court denied the defendants’ motion because they did not demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits. The court did, however, extend the South Carolina legislature’s deadline to submit a new district map until 30 days after the Supreme Court resolved defendants’ appeal.
Trials.value: Post-trial: defendants appealed and sought a stay; stay denied on Feb. 4, 2023; remedial deadline extended to 30 days after Supreme Court decision.

evidences: The Supreme Court noted probable jurisdiction on May 15, 2023, and the case proceeded into the merits briefing stage.
Trials.value: May 15, 2023: Supreme Court noted probable jurisdiction.

evidences: On March 7, 2024 the defendants filed a motion for a partial stay of the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina’s January 6, 2023 order for the 2024 Election Cycle.
On March 20, 2024, the defendants filed an application for stay of the district court panel’s injunction for the 2024 elections with the United States Supreme Court.

However, on March 28, 2024, the District Court modified its injunction to “preserve the status quo on appeal.” The District Court added language to note that the Court enjoined the conducting of an election in District 1 after the 2024 election cycle until a constitutionally valid apportionment plan was approved by the Court. As the District Court modified the injunction, the Supreme Court never ruled on the motion to stay.
Trials.value: Post-trial: defendants sought partial stay for 2024; on Mar. 28, 2024 the district court modified its injunction to preserve the status quo (no election in District 1 after 2024 until a valid plan approved); Supreme Court did not rule on the stay application.

evidences: On May 23, 2024, the Supreme Court issued its opinion on the matter, reversing in part and remanding in part.

The Court ruled that the district court’s finding that race predominated in the design of South Carolina’s first congressional district was clearly erroneous, so its racial-gerrymandering and vote-dilution holdings were reversed. The vote-diluting claim was additionally remanded to the district court.
Trials.value: Appellate outcome: On May 23, 2024, Supreme Court reversed the district court’s racial-gerrymandering and vote-dilution holdings for District 1 and remanded the vote-dilution claim.

evidences: On June 28. 2024, following the Supreme Court’s remand of the plaintiff’s voter-dilution claim to the district court for further proceedings, the district court issued an order requesting the parties submit memorandums addressing whether the legislature acted with dilutive intent and whether the enacted map had a dilutive effect.
Trials.value: Post-remand scheduling: On June 28, 2024, district court ordered party memoranda on dilutive intent and effect.

evidences: On July 26, 2024, prior to either party submitting the requested memorandum, the plaintiffs filed a joint stipulation for voluntary dismissal with prejudice.
Subsequently, on August 1, 2024, the district court dismissed the case with prejudice and ordered the Clerk of the Court to close the case.
Trials.value: Case resolution post-remand: Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed with prejudice on July 26, 2024; district court dismissed with prejudice and closed the case on Aug. 1, 2024.

evidences: The plaintiffs and House defendants reached a settlement agreement prior to April 22, 2022, but the court denied their motions for approval of the settlement on April 25, holding that the House defendants alone did not have the requisite authority to settle the claims. 2022 WL 2375812.
Court Rulings.value: Apr 25, 2022: Court denied motions for approval of settlement (House defendants lacked authority to settle the claims).

evidences: In response, the Senate and House defendants filed separate motions to dismiss for failure to state a claim on May 20, 2022.

The court denied these motions on June 28, 2022, holding that the private plaintiff had standing to challenge the district he lived in and the NAACP had associational standing because it had members in the challenged districts.
Court Rulings.value: Jun 28, 2022: Court denied Senate and House defendants’ motions to dismiss for failure to state a claim.

evidences: The Senate and House defendants moved for summary judgment on August 19,

The court also denied the defendants’ summary judgment motion on September 15, 2022. It held that, viewing the evidence in a light most favorable to the plaintiffs, issues of material fact remained as to whether the defendants engaged in intentional discrimination against Black South Carolinians or used race as a proxy for partisan goals.
Court Rulings.value: Sept 15, 2022: Court denied defendants’ motion for summary judgment, stating that there are still facts that remain in question that can prove racial discrimination

evidences: On January 27, 2023, the defendants notified the court that they were appealing its ruling

and they moved to stay the order pending the Court’s review. On February 4, 2023, the court denied the defendants’ motion because they did not demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits. The court did, however, extend the South Carolina legislature’s deadline to submit a new district map until 30 days after the Supreme Court resolved defendants’ appeal.
Court Rulings.value: Feb 4, 2023: Court denied defendants’ motion to stay pending appeal; extended deadline to submit remedial map.

evidences: On March 7, 2024 the defendants filed a motion for a partial stay of the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina’s January 6, 2023 order for the 2024 Election Cycle.

However, on March 28, 2024, the District Court modified its injunction to “preserve the status quo on appeal.” The District Court added language to note that the Court enjoined the conducting of an election in District 1 after the 2024 election cycle until a constitutionally valid apportionment plan was approved by the Court. As the District Court modified the injunction, the Supreme Court never ruled on the motion to stay.
Court Rulings.value: Mar 28, 2024: In response to defendants’ motion for a partial stay, the district court modified its injunction to preserve the status quo on appeal, allowing the 2024 election to proceed in District 1; Supreme Court stay application became unnecessary.

evidences: On May 23, 2024, the Supreme Court issued its opinion on the matter, reversing in part and remanding in part.

The Court ruled that the district court’s finding that race predominated in the design of South Carolina’s first congressional district was clearly erroneous, so its racial-gerrymandering and vote-dilution holdings were reversed. The vote-diluting claim was additionally remanded to the district court.
Court Rulings.value: May 23, 2024: U.S. Supreme Court reversed in part (racial gerrymander and vote-dilution holdings) and remanded the vote-dilution claim.

evidences: On July 26, 2024, prior to either party submitting the requested memorandum, the plaintiffs filed a joint stipulation for voluntary dismissal with prejudice. Court Rulings.value: Aug 1, 2024: District court dismissed the case with prejudice following joint stipulation.

evidences: On May 21, 2025, the commissioners filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland
This case challenged the removal of three former Commissioners of the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC).
All three Plaintiffs had been nominated by President Joe Biden and confirmed by the Senate and were only removable "for neglect of duty or malfeasance in office, but for no other cause."

The plaintiffs alleged that their terminations were ultra vires and in excess of the President's constitutional and statutory authority and requested the court to declare the terminations unlawful and to enjoin the defendants from taking any action to effectuate them.
Cause of Action.value: Nonstatutory ultra vires/equitable claim against federal officials alleging the removals exceeded the President’s constitutional and statutory authority and violated the CPSC’s for-cause removal protection; plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief. No specific statutory cause of action is identified in the summary.

evidences: were only removable "for neglect of duty or malfeasance in office, but for no other cause."
rejecting the defendants' argument that the statutory "for-cause" restriction on the president's removal power was unconstitutional.
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: Statutory basis: the commissioners’ for-cause removal protection limiting removal to “neglect of duty or malfeasance in office, but for no other cause.”

evidences: The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on June 13, 2025, rejecting the defendants' argument that the statutory "for-cause" restriction on the president's removal power was unconstitutional. The court found that the exception on the removal power articulated in Humphrey's Executor, where the Supreme Court "upheld tenure protections for officers of multimember bodies with quasi-judicial or quasi-legislative functions," was relevant here. Even though the Supreme Court has "revisit[ed] and recast[ed] some views articulated in Humphrey's Executor," the court found that it remained good law and required the court to "examine the characteristics of the agency before the court." Therefore, the court turned to whether the Humphrey's Executor exception applied to the CPSC.
Statutory or Constitutional Basis for th.value: Constitutional basis: challenge concerning the President’s constitutional removal power and exercise of executive power; dispute over whether for-cause limits on removal are unconstitutional.
