evidences: This is a case about healthcare and isolation practices at Wisconsin prisons.

On October 26, 2023, inmates at Wisconsin prisons brought a class action suit, filed in the U.S. District Court in the Eastern District of Wisconsin, against the Wisconsin Department of Corrections and certain named prison officials in their official capacities.
Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case involves Wisconsin inmates filing a class action on October 26, 2023, in the Eastern District of Wisconsin against the Department of Corrections and prison officials over healthcare and isolation practices, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.

evidences: (1) As a result of defendants’ longstanding practices, there were severe delays in the provision of or complete denial of medical services when inmates seek or clearly require medical, dental, and/or mental health/psychological services.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Alleged severe delays or denials of necessary medical, dental, and mental health/psychological services due to longstanding practices.

evidences: (2) Defendants implemented an unexplained seven-month lockdown at the Waupun Correctional Institution, during which medical delays continued or were exacerbated.
Factual Basis of Case.value: An unexplained seven-month lockdown at Waupun Correctional Institution allegedly continued or worsened medical delays.

evidences: (3) Defendants failed to provide minimally adequate living conditions to inmates in the lockdown period.
Factual Basis of Case.value: During the lockdown, inmates were allegedly not provided minimally adequate living conditions.

evidences: (4) Defendants maintained a policy of isolating prisoners and providing inadequate environmental stimuli or nutrition in isolation, creating a substantial risk of physical and psychiatric harm.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Alleged policy of isolating prisoners with inadequate environmental stimuli and nutrition, creating substantial risk of physical and psychiatric harm.

evidences: Plaintiffs alleged these practices and policies fall short of minimum constitutional guarantees, violating inmates’ Eighth Amendment rights.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs contend the above practices violate the Eighth Amendment’s minimum constitutional guarantees.

evidences: On November 20, 2023, Magistrate Judge William E. Duffin issued a screening order dismissing plaintiffs’ demand for compensatory and punitive damages from defendants, while preserving plaintiffs’ plea of injunctive relief.

As the state is immune from actions for damages under the Eleventh Amendment, the court dismissed plaintiffs’ demands for compensatory and punitive damages. Plaintiffs were allowed to continue to pursue injunctive relief.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Damages claims were dismissed based on Eleventh Amendment immunity; only injunctive relief claims proceeded.

evidences: The court reasoned that a suit against the state against state officials in their official capacity (as opposed to in their personal capacity), like a suit against an arm of the state such as the Department of Corrections, constitutes a suit against the state itself.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The court reasoned that a lawsuit against state officials in their official capacity—rather than their personal capacity—is effectively a suit against the state, similar to a lawsuit against a state agency like the Department of Corrections.

evidences: Plaintiffs thereafter filed an amended complaint on November 21, 2023, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against the Department of Corrections and named officials, in their individual as well as official capacities.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs amended their complaint to seek declaratory and injunctive relief against DOC and officials in both individual and official capacities.

evidences: On March 22, 2024, plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary injunction, arguing that the practices at the Wisconsin prison demonstrated a deliberate indifference to plaintiffs’ well-being and civil rights.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction, asserting the prison practices showed deliberate indifference to inmates’ well-being and civil rights.

evidences: Defendants subsequently filed a motion for partial summary judgment, alleging that plaintiffs failed to exhaust their administrative remedies before they filed their complaint.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Defendants moved for partial summary judgment based on alleged failure to exhaust administrative remedies.

evidences: On March 28, 2024, plaintiffs filed a class certification motion, seeking to certify all previous, current, and future inmates in Wisconsin correctional facilities subject to their health practices (medical, mental health, and dental care), or subject to isolation.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs sought to certify a class comprising all prior, current, and future Wisconsin inmates subject to health care practices or isolation.

evidences: Recognizing that federal law requires plaintiffs situated like the plaintiffs here must exhaust administrative remedies before filing suit, the court found that only two complaints relating to dental and eye care made by two of the named plaintiffs exhausted all administrative remedies.
The court found all other plaintiffs failed to exhaust their claims prior to filing suit.
As such, the court dismissed the plaintiffs’ mental health and isolation-related claims, and the relevant named plaintiffs whose interest in the case related only to those claims.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Only two administrative complaints (dental and eye care) by two named plaintiffs were fully exhausted; all other claims were unexhausted, leading to dismissal of mental health and isolation-related claims.

evidences: With respect to the motion for preliminary injunction, the court determined that after defendants’ summary judgment motion had been granted, only two named plaintiffs remained, each with a single discrete claim, and the plaintiffs’ motion did not address those specific claims and therefore was not entitled to a preliminary injunction.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Preliminary injunction was denied because only two discrete claims remained and the motion did not address those specific claims.

evidences: With respect to the motion to certify the suit as a class action, the court found class certification improper as plaintiffs did not specify a specific policy at issue nor specify a time period during which the policies at issue were in place.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Class certification was denied due to failure to identify a specific policy and timeframe.

evidences: Following the court’s ruling, on August 6, 2024, plaintiffs moved and stipulated to dismiss the case without prejudice. As of that date, the case was dismissed without prejudice to all parties.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The case was dismissed without prejudice on August 6, 2024, by stipulation.

evidences: On September 19, 2019, five asylum-seeking parents, on their own behalf and on behalf of their minor children, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.
The plaintiffs sued the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act ("FTCA").
Cause of Action.value: Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA)

evidences: The plaintiffs alleged both negligence on part of the United States government and that the government caused intentional infliction of emotional distress ("IIED") through its child-separation policy.
Cause of Action.value: Common-law tort claims under the FTCA: negligence and intentional infliction of emotional distress (IIED)

evidences: The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, the National Immigrant Justice Center, and the American Immigration Council, sought monetary relief and attorneys fees.
Remedy Sought.value: Monetary relief and attorneys' fees

evidences: In January 2023, the plaintiffs filed a motion for sanctions seeking evidentiary sanctions against the defendants for the production of documents after the close of discovery.
Remedy Sought.value: Evidentiary sanctions

evidences: The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, the National Immigrant Justice Center, and the American Immigration Council, sought monetary relief and attorneys fees.
Type of Counsel.value: Private counsel; Public interest nonprofit (NIJC; American Immigration Council)

evidences: The plaintiffs sued the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act ("FTCA").
The case was assigned to Judge Susan Bolton.
denied by the Judge Bolton on July 6, 2020

The district court denied the United States' motion on March 30, 2020, holding (1) the family separation alleged in the suit was a persuasive analogy to private conduct such that plaintiffs had established subject-matter jurisdiction under the FTCA and (2) neither the due care nor the discretionary function exception to the FTCA applied because the United States was not enforcing federal law when it separated plaintiffs and their children. 2020 WL 1698191.

The United States moved for leave to appeal the district court's order on May 29, 2020, which was denied by the Judge Bolton on July 6, 2020 because the United States failed to present exceptional circumstances such that interlocutory review would be appropriate. 2020 WL 5232560.

On October 24, 2023, the Court also denied the defendant's motion for summary judgment, while granting in part the plaintiffs' motion. The Court denied the defendant's motion because they had not shown that the discretionary function exception barred the plaintiffs’ claims. With regard to the plaintiffs' negligence claim, the Court concluded that the United States owed the plaintiffs a duty of care, but determined that issues of material fact existed as to whether the United States breached its duty. The Court denied the plaintiffs' IIED claim. 2023 WL 7102132.

evidences: On September 19, 2019, five asylum-seeking parents, on their own behalf and on behalf of their minor children, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.
The plaintiffs sued the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act ("FTCA").
The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, the National Immigrant Justice Center, and the American Immigration Council, sought monetary relief and attorneys fees.
The case was assigned to Judge Susan Bolton.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Parties and filing: Five asylum-seeking parents (and their minor children) sued the United States under the FTCA in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona on September 19, 2019, seeking monetary relief and attorneys’ fees; assigned to Judge Susan Bolton.

evidences: The government separated the asylum-seeking parents from their children, delayed providing parents and children information of each other’s whereabouts and well-being, failed to facilitate adequate communication between the parents and their children while separated, and failed to implement a system to ensure families could be reunited.
The government did this deliberately, plaintiffs alleged, to deter other parents with children from seeking asylum in the United States.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Core factual allegations: The U.S. government separated asylum-seeking parents from their children, delayed sharing information on whereabouts and well-being, failed to facilitate communication during separation, and failed to implement a reunification system, allegedly to deter other families from seeking asylum.

evidences: The plaintiffs alleged both negligence on part of the United States government and that the government caused intentional infliction of emotional distress ("IIED") through its child-separation policy.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Alleged harms: Negligence and intentional infliction of emotional distress arising from the child-separation policy.

evidences: The United States filed its answer to the complaint on May 13, 2020 and the parties commenced discovery in July 2020.
In January 2023, the plaintiffs filed a motion for sanctions seeking evidentiary sanctions against the defendants for the production of documents after the close of discovery.
The United States filed a motion for summary judgment and submitted a statement of facts on March 9, 2023.

On August 15, 2023, the District Court granted in part and denied in part the plaintiffs' motion for sanctions. The Court granted for the admission of the certain documents and handwritten notes if offered by the plaintiffs at trial and precluded the defendants from using them.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Evidence and evidentiary context: Discovery occurred; plaintiffs sought sanctions over late-produced documents; the court admitted certain documents and handwritten notes for plaintiffs’ use at trial; the United States submitted a statement of facts.

evidences: During this time, the 2020 presidential election resulted in a transfer of power from the Trump Administration to the Biden Administration.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The 2020 presidential occurred, resulting in the transfer of power from the Trump administration to the Biden administration.

evidences: The defendant denounced the challenged separation of families procedures as the policy decisions made by the Department of Homeland Security and Department of Justice during the former Trump Administration.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background/policy context: The separation procedures were tied to policy decisions by DHS and DOJ during the former Trump Administration.

evidences: Nonetheless, the defendant contended that the FTCA does not permit recovery in tort for harms asserted to arise from policy decisions (the so-called discretionary function exception).
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The defendant contended the FTCA does not permit recovery in tort for harms from policy decisions (discretionary function exception).

evidences: The case is considered closed.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The status of the case is now closed.

Judge James Donato was assigned.

evidences: Executive Order 14180, titled “Exclusions from Federal Labor-Management Programs,” signed on March 27, 2025

The Exclusion Order targeted nearly 40 federal departments and sub-agencies—including the Departments of Defense, Veterans Affairs, Justice, Homeland Security, and Health and Human Services—citing national security grounds.
The order also uniquely authorized only a few departments, such as DOD and VA, to restore bargaining rights to specific subdivisions, leaving thousands of workers' rights in limbo.
the Executive Order “expressly removed the employees of the listed departments, agencies, and subdivisions from Chapter 71’s coverage.”
Factual Basis of Case.value: EO 14180 (March 27, 2025) excluded employees in nearly 40 departments/sub-agencies from federal labor-management programs on asserted national security grounds, selectively allowing only certain departments (e.g., DOD, VA) to restore bargaining rights to specific subdivisions, removing covered employees from Chapter 71 and leaving thousands of workers’ rights uncertain.

evidences: alleging that it unlawfully retaliated against their protected speech in support of civil servants and violated the First Amendment, the Fifth Amendment, and the Separation of Powers Doctrine.

They also alleged statutory overreach under 5 U.S.C. § 7103(b) of the Civil Service Reform Act, claiming the order targeted them for engaging in protected activity such as litigation, public criticism, and union advocacy.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs allege EO 14180 was retaliatory against protected speech and violated the First and Fifth Amendments and Separation of Powers, and exceeded statutory authority under 5 U.S.C. § 7103(b) by targeting unions for litigation, public criticism, and advocacy.

evidences: The Exclusion Order targeted nearly 40 federal departments and sub-agencies—including the Departments of Defense, Veterans Affairs, Justice, Homeland Security, and Health and Human Services—citing national security grounds. However, the complaint alleged that the order was pretextual and driven by political animus, referencing the administration’s rhetoric and social media statements attacking “hostile unions” and “grievance filers.” The order also uniquely authorized only a few departments, such as DOD and VA, to restore bargaining rights to specific subdivisions, leaving thousands of workers' rights in limbo.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The Exclusion Order targeted nearly 40 federal agencies under national security claims, but critics said it was politically motivated. Only a few departments, like DOD and VA, could restore bargaining rights, leaving many workers unprotected.

Plaintiffs in the California case argued that these actions reflected a broader campaign to dismantle the statutory framework protecting federal labor-management relations established by the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978.
Factual Basis of Case.value: A parallel Waco, Texas lawsuit to nullify CBAs supports plaintiffs’ claim of a coordinated campaign to dismantle federal labor-management protections under the CSRA.

evidences: On April 25, the government filed its opposition to the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, arguing that the March 27 Executive Order was a lawful exercise of presidential authority in the interest of national security.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The government asserted the EO was a lawful exercise of presidential authority justified by national security.

evidences: It explained that the FLRA has authority “over those disputes which arise under Chapter 71,” but the Executive Order “expressly removed the employees of the listed departments, agencies, and subdivisions from Chapter 71’s coverage.” As a result, the court concluded it was “not precluded from exercising jurisdiction.”
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background context: FLRA ordinarily reviews Chapter 71 disputes, but the EO’s removal of employees from Chapter 71 meant district court review was not precluded.

evidences: The court found the plaintiffs likely to succeed on their First Amendment retaliation claim, noting they engaged in protected activity by “frequently speak[ing] against actions undertaken by President Trump and his administration since January 2025.”

It concluded the government’s conduct would “chill a person of ordinary firmness from continuing to engage in protected activity” and that the evidence raised “a serious question whether the agency exclusions in EO 14251 constitute retaliation for protected speech.”
Factual Basis of Case.value: Factual findings at the preliminary injunction stage: unions engaged in protected speech since January 2025; government conduct would chill such activity; evidence raised serious questions of retaliatory motive related to the EO’s agency exclusions.

evidences: Thus, the court held the plaintiffs had shown a serious First Amendment issue warranting preservation of the status quo pending further litigation. As such, the court declined to address the plaintiffs’ other arguments and enjoined the implementation of Section 2 of the EO. It also required the plaintiffs to post a $60,000 bond.
Factual Basis of Case.value: District court enjoined Section 2 of the EO to preserve the status quo pending litigation and required a $60,000 bond.

evidences: On June 26, 2025, the government appealed to the Ninth Circuit, seeking both an administrative stay and a stay pending appeal. The government also sought a stay from Judge Donato, which was denied.
On July 7, the Ninth Circuit granted the government’s administrative stay pending the appeal, without providing an explanation.

On August 1, 2025, the Ninth Circuit granted the government's motion for a stay pending appeal. 2025 WL 2180674. The court found that the government was likely to succeed on the merits, reasoning that even if the unions could show a prima facie case of retaliation, the President would have issued the order regardless of the unions' protected speech due to national security concerns. The court also found that the government would suffer irreparable harm without a stay, as an injunction would "tie the government's hands" in a national security context. Regarding the harm to other parties, the court found that any injury to the unions would be mitigated, as terminated collective bargaining agreements could be reinstated and a pause in dues collection could be managed by voluntary payments and future monetary damages. Finally, the court determined that a stay would serve the public interest by "preserving the President's autonomy under a statute that expressly recognizes his national-security expertise."
Factual Basis of Case.value: On appeal, the Ninth Circuit stayed the injunction pending appeal, crediting national security justifications, mitigation of union harms, and public interest in presidential autonomy under the statute.

evidences: On June 24, 2025, Judge Donato granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. 2025 WL 1755442.
The court rejected the government’s argument that Congress had precluded judicial review by providing administrative review through the Federal Labor Relations Authority (FLRA).

It explained that the FLRA has authority “over those disputes which arise under Chapter 71,” but the Executive Order “expressly removed the employees of the listed departments, agencies, and subdivisions from Chapter 71’s coverage.”
As a result, the court concluded it was “not precluded from exercising jurisdiction.”

The court found the plaintiffs likely to succeed on their First Amendment retaliation claim, noting they engaged in protected activity by “frequently speak[ing] against actions undertaken by President Trump and his administration since January 2025.”

It concluded the government’s conduct would “chill a person of ordinary firmness from continuing to engage in protected activity” and that the evidence raised “a serious question whether the agency exclusions in EO 14251 constitute retaliation for protected speech.”
Thus, the court held the plaintiffs had shown a serious First Amendment issue warranting preservation of the status quo pending further litigation.
As such, the court declined to address the plaintiffs’ other arguments and enjoined the implementation of Section 2 of the EO. It also required the plaintiffs to post a $60,000 bond.
Trials.value: Preliminary injunction granted on June 24, 2025 (2025 WL 1755442): court found jurisdiction not precluded, likely success on First Amendment retaliation, enjoined implementation of Section 2 of the EO, and required a $60,000 bond.

On July 7, the Ninth Circuit granted the government’s administrative stay pending the appeal, without providing an explanation.

evidences: This is a case about Houston police arresting individuals without warrants and detaining them without probable cause.
They claimed that the City of Houston regularly arrested individuals without warrants and detained them without probable cause hearings for longer than permitted by the United States Constitution.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Alleged pattern of Houston police arresting people without warrants and detaining them without timely probable cause hearings beyond constitutional limits.

evidences: On December 5, 2016, two plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas.

The plaintiffs on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated sued the City of Houston under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.
Represented by private counsel and the Civil Rights Corps, the plaintiffs sought compensatory damages and attorneys’ fees.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Filing and parties: Two plaintiffs filed in S.D. Tex. on Dec. 5, 2016 against the City of Houston under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 for alleged Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment violations, seeking compensatory damages and attorneys’ fees.

evidences: The City filed an amended motion to dismiss, which was denied on June 6, 2017. The court found that the defendants had essentially admitted that the facts the plaintiffs pleaded were true.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The court determined defendants had essentially admitted the factual allegations, supporting plaintiffs’ claims.

evidences: On August 30, 2018, the District Court issued an order stating that the City of Houston had intentionally destroyed evidence pertinent to the lawsuit.

As a result, the Court held that inferences were appropriate: (1) throughout the class period, the City of Houston had a policy of not releasing warrantless arrestees who had not received neutral determinations of probable cause within the constitutionally required period of time; (2) throughout the class period, the City’s policymakers were aware of this policy; and (3) the City acted with deliberate indifference with respect to its unconstitutional policy of not releasing warrantless arrestees who hadn’t received probable cause hearings in the appropriate amount of time.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Court found the City intentionally destroyed evidence and drew adverse inferences that the City had a policy of not releasing warrantless arrestees without timely neutral probable cause determinations, that policymakers knew of it, and that the City acted with deliberate indifference.

evidences: The first amended complaint detailed a single class of plaintiffs seeking compensatory relief, which applied to all those arrested without warrant and held for more than 48 hours without a prompt judicial determination of probable cause.

The first subclass included all those arrested and held held by the City of Houston without a warrant or a judicial determination of probably cause for 48 hours or more, and the second subclass included those who were arrested and held between 24 and 48 hours.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Affected individuals included those held more than 48 hours without a prompt judicial probable cause determination, with subclasses for 48 hours or more and for 24–48 hours.

evidences: The first subclass included all those arrested and held held by the City of Houston without a warrant or a judicial determination of probably cause for 48 hours or more, and the second subclass included those who were arrested and held between 24 and 48 hours.

Factual Basis of Case.value: Individuals were arrested without a warrant or a judicial determination of probably cause for 48 hours or more, and those who were held between 24 and 48 hours are seeking compensatory relief.

evidences: In spring 2019, the District Court issued an order overruling a motion from the City that asked the Court to exclude certain documents that they claimed to be privileged from evidence.
The plaintiffs filed a motion to compel the city to produce these documents, which was stayed by Judge Hoyt pending the City’s appeal.
The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals then vacated the District Court’s order with respect to one document, and denied the City’s claim of privilege in all other respects.
Upon remand, the District Court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to compel.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Documentary evidence: most disputed documents were ordered produced after appellate review, with privilege sustained as to only one document.

evidences: On July 3, 2019, Judge Hoyt granted the plaintiffs’ earlier motion for class certification.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Class certification was granted, confirming the case proceeded on behalf of a class of warrantless arrestees subjected to delayed probable cause determinations.

evidences: In July 2020, Houston City Council voted to pass a settlement awarding the plaintiffs $1.17 million in exchange for indemnity.
On March 18, 2021, the court approved the settlement agreement determining it was fair, reasonable, and adequate for the class. The settlement payment was $1.17 million.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background resolution: The City settled for $1.17 million, approved by the court as fair, reasonable, and adequate.

evidences: Represented by private attorneys, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief and class certification.
The case was assigned to Judge Norman K. Moon.
On November 4, 2016, Magistrate Judge Joel C. Hoppe granted the NAACP's motion for leave to file an amicus brief.
Circuit Judge Henry F. Floyd wrote the majority opinion, in which Circuit Judge Allyson K. Duncan joined.
Circuit Judge Henry F. Floyd wrote the majority opinion, in which Circuit Judge Allyson K. Duncan joined.
Chief Judge Roger L. Gregory wrote a dissenting opinion because he would have found that the district court's dismissal was an appealable final order.

Finally, Judge Moon found that the suit was barred by Eleventh Amendment immunity, which prevents federal courts from exercising jurisdiction over suits brought by citizens against non-consenting state defendants. The court found that the Ex parte Young exception, which permits such suits where the sued official has a "special relation" with the challenged statute or action, did not apply in this case. 2017 WL 963234.
Chief Judge Roger L. Gregory wrote a dissenting opinion because he would have found that the district court's dismissal was an appealable final order. 734 Fed.Appx. 858.

On December 21, 2018, Judge Moon granted the plaintiffs' motion for the preliminary injunction, finding it likely that the plaintiffs would succeed in establishing that the Virginia statute violated procedural due process and that the remaining factors relevant to the issuance of a preliminary injunction weighed in favor of the plaintiffs. 355 F. Supp. 3d 514.

The following year, on June 27, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit affirmed the lower court's ruling, agreeing that winning a preliminary injunction does not make a plaintiff a prevailing party. 37 F.4th 977.

On August 7, 2023, the Fourth Circuit vacated the district court’s denial of attorneys' fees and remanded back to the district court for further proceedings. The Fourth Circuit held that its previous bright line rule was too stringent, and preliminary injunctions can sometimes constitute “enduring, merits-based relief that satisfies all the requisites of the prevailing party standard,” making the plaintiffs in this case eligible for a fee award. 77 F.4th 200.
On March 27, 2024, Magistrate Judge Hoppe entered an oral order staying the case and on April 22, 2024, the U.S. Supreme Court agreed to hear the case.144 S.Ct. 1390.

Chief Justice Roberts reversed the Fourth Circuit’s en banc opinion and held that the plaintiffs did not qualify as “prevailing parties” and, thus, were not eligible for attorney’s fees under § 1988(b). 2025 WL 594737.

evidences: On May 7, 2020, the parties submitted a joint stipulation of dismissal after the Virginia General Assembly passed legislation eliminating the contested Virginia Code § 46.2-395 and requiring the DMV Commissioner to reinstate, without payment of fees, driver's licenses suspended under the law.
The parties agreed that the legislative action mooted the case, but disputed whether the plaintiffs should be awarded attorneys' fees.
The court adopted the stipulation of dismissal the same day and dismissed the case as moot, while retaining jurisdiction to decide the issue of attorneys' fees.
The plaintiffs appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

evidences: On July 6, 2016, indigent Virginia residents brought this putative class action in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Virginia after suffering indefinite suspension of their driver's licenses pursuant to Virginia Code § 46.2-395 for failure to pay court costs and fines that they could not afford.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Indigent Virginia residents experienced indefinite driver’s license suspensions under Va. Code § 46.2-395 for inability to pay court fines and costs, prompting the class action filed on July 6, 2016 in the W.D. Va.

evidences: They claimed that the Commonwealth's scheme of suspending licenses to coerce payment of money owed to the courts unfairly punished people for being poor, and that suspending their licenses was a violation of the due process and equal protection clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Plaintiffs alleged the suspension scheme coerced payment and punished poverty, violating Due Process and Equal Protection under the Fourteenth Amendment.

evidences: The DOJ argued that suspension of a person's driver's license in response to the failure to pay court debt without providing a person with adequate notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard constituted a deprivation of a protected interest without due process in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment.

Moreover, the DOJ argued that suspending the driver's licenses of those who failed to pay fines without inquiring into whether the failure to pay was willful or instead the result of an inability to pay may result in penalizing indigent individuals solely because of their poverty, in violation of the due process and equal protection clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: DOJ supported the theory that the process provided lacked adequate notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard and failed to assess willfulness versus inability to pay, resulting in unconstitutional penalties on indigent individuals.

evidences: On November 4, 2016, Magistrate Judge Joel C. Hoppe granted the NAACP's motion for leave to file an amicus brief.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: NAACP participated as amicus, providing supportive background input on the issues.

evidences: Since this case involved suspension orders issued by Virginia state courts, Judge Moon concluded that the plaintiffs were required to seek relief from state appellate courts and ultimately the United States Supreme Court. Furthermore, a federal court could only hear a case if it could grant some sort of remedy to the plaintiffs. In this case, because state courts, rather than the Commissioner, had suspended the licenses, a court order against the Commissioner would not provide such a remedy and so the court held the plaintiffs had no standing.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The suspensions were imposed by Virginia state courts (not directly by the DMV Commissioner), establishing how the suspensions occurred under the challenged scheme.

evidences: Circuit Judge Henry F. Floyd wrote the majority opinion, in which Circuit Judge Allyson K. Duncan joined. The Circuit Court found that it lacked jurisdiction to consider the plaintiffs' appeal because the district court's dismissal without prejudice was not a final order and because the plaintiffs might still be able to cure the deficiencies identified by the district court by amending their complaint. Chief Judge Roger L. Gregory wrote a dissenting opinion because he would have found that the district court's dismissal was an appealable final order.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: In the majority opinion written by Judge Henry F. Floyd and joined by Judge Allyson K. Duncan, the Fourth Circuit Court found that it lacked jurisdiction because the plaintiff may still be able to fix the problems identified by the district court by amending their complaint. Chief Judge Roger L. Gregory dissented because he found that the dismissal by the district court was an appealable final order.

evidences: On September 11, 2018, the plaintiffs filed an amended class action complaint and a motion for preliminary injunction.

They asked the court to enjoin the Commissioner from enforcing the statutes against the plaintiffs and future suspended class members without notice and determination of ability to pay, to remove any current suspensions of the plaintiffs' driver's licenses imposed under the statute, and to enjoin the Commissioner from charging a fee to reinstate the plaintiffs' licenses if there were no other restrictions on their licenses.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: Relief sought included halting enforcement without notice and ability-to-pay determinations, removing current suspensions, and barring reinstatement fees where no other restrictions existed.

evidences: On December 21, 2018, Judge Moon granted the plaintiffs' motion for the preliminary injunction, finding it likely that the plaintiffs would succeed in establishing that the Virginia statute violated procedural due process and that the remaining factors relevant to the issuance of a preliminary injunction weighed in favor of the plaintiffs.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The court issued a preliminary injunction, indicating likely success on a procedural due process claim—supporting the assertions about inadequate process.

evidences: On April 23, 2019, the defendant moved to dismiss the case as moot, or in the alternative sought a stay of the proceedings, arguing that a budget amendment by Virginia Governor Ralph Northam that reinstated driver’s licenses that had been revoked for failure to pay any fines ended any harm against the plaintiffs.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background development: a 2019 budget amendment reinstated licenses previously revoked for failure to pay fines, affecting ongoing harm and mootness considerations.

evidences: On June 28, 2019, Judge Moon issued an order granting the motion to stay and denying the defendant’s motion to dismiss. The court found that the budget amendment only halted enforcement of the law, and thus there was a reasonable expectation the plaintiffs would again be subjected to the same harm.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The court's reasoning behind behind granting the motion to stay and denying the motion to dismiss was that the plaintiffs could reasonably expect to be subjected to the same harm.

evidences: On May 7, 2020, the parties submitted a joint stipulation of dismissal after the Virginia General Assembly passed legislation eliminating the contested Virginia Code § 46.2-395 and requiring the DMV Commissioner to reinstate, without payment of fees, driver's licenses suspended under the law.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background resolution: in 2020, the Virginia General Assembly repealed § 46.2-395 and mandated reinstatement of licenses suspended under it without fees.

evidences: Chief Justice Roberts reversed the Fourth Circuit’s en banc opinion and held that the plaintiffs did not qualify as “prevailing parties” and, thus, were not eligible for attorney’s fees under § 1988(b). 2025 WL 594737. For purposes of § 1998(b), the court reasoned that a party “prevails” when the court grants relief that constitutes a “material alteration” of a legal relationship. Based on precedent, the court held that this alteration of the legal relationship must be (1) judicially sanctioned, and (2) enduring. Here, only a preliminary injunction was issued and no court conclusively resolved the plaintiffs’ claims on the merits. Thus, the legal relationship between the parties was not materially altered and, therefore, the plaintiffs did not qualify under § 1988(b).
Factual Basis of Case.value: Context: The Supreme Court reasoned that the plaintiffs did not qualify for attorney fees because the legal relationship between the parties was not materially altered.

evidences: On April 23, 2019, the defendant moved to dismiss the case as moot, or in the alternative sought a stay of the proceedings, arguing that a budget amendment by Virginia Governor Ralph Northam that reinstated driver’s licenses that had been revoked for failure to pay any fines ended any harm against the plaintiffs.

evidences: On June 28, 2019, Judge Moon issued an order granting the motion to stay and denying the defendant’s motion to dismiss.
The stay was ordered through April 17, 2020, and then extended until May 15, 2020.
Trials.value: On June 28, 2019, court denied motion to dismiss as moot and granted stay; stay set through April 17, 2020, later extended to May 15, 2020.

evidences: On May 7, 2020, the parties submitted a joint stipulation of dismissal after the Virginia General Assembly passed legislation eliminating the contested Virginia Code § 46.2-395 and requiring the DMV Commissioner to reinstate, without payment of fees, driver's licenses suspended under the law.
The parties agreed that the legislative action mooted the case, but disputed whether the plaintiffs should be awarded attorneys' fees.

The court adopted the stipulation of dismissal the same day and dismissed the case as moot, while retaining jurisdiction to decide the issue of attorneys' fees. Judge Moon requested that each party brief the remaining question of attorneys' fees.
Trials.value: On May 7, 2020, court adopted joint stipulation and dismissed case as moot (statute repealed and reinstatement without fees); retained jurisdiction over attorneys’ fees and ordered briefing.

evidences: On December 9, 2020, Magistrate Judge Hoppe held a hearing on the motion for attorneys' fees.

On February 16, he issued a report concluding that a plaintiff who won a preliminary injunction but whose case was later dismissed as moot was not a prevailing party for the purposes of 42 U.S.C. § 1988 and therefore not entitled to attorneys' fees, and recommended that the court deny the plaintiffs' motion.
Trials.value: Attorneys’ fees hearing held December 9, 2020; on February 16, Magistrate Judge issued R&R recommending denial (plaintiffs not prevailing parties under § 1988).

evidences: On June 4, 2021, the court delivered an opinion adopting the magistrate judge's report and recommendation and denying the request for attorneys' fees.
Trials.value: On June 4, 2021, district court adopted R&R and denied attorneys’ fees.

evidences: On July 2, 2021, the plaintiffs appealed the district court's decision to deny attorneys' fees.

The following year, on June 27, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit affirmed the lower court's ruling, agreeing that winning a preliminary injunction does not make a plaintiff a prevailing party.
Trials.value: Plaintiffs appealed fees denial on July 2, 2021; on June 27, Fourth Circuit affirmed that a preliminary injunction does not confer prevailing-party status. Citation: 37 F.4th 977.

evidences: The plaintiffs petitioned for a rehearing en banc before the entire Fourth Circuit, which was granted on August 9, 2022.
Trials.value: En banc rehearing granted by Fourth Circuit on August 9, 2022.

evidences: On August 7, 2023, the Fourth Circuit vacated the district court’s denial of attorneys' fees and remanded back to the district court for further proceedings.

The Fourth Circuit held that its previous bright line rule was too stringent, and preliminary injunctions can sometimes constitute “enduring, merits-based relief that satisfies all the requisites of the prevailing party standard,” making the plaintiffs in this case eligible for a fee award.
Trials.value: On August 7, 2023, en banc Fourth Circuit vacated denial of fees and remanded; held preliminary injunctions can sometimes meet prevailing-party standard. Citation: 77 F.4th 200.

evidences: On August 30, 2023, the district court referred the plaintiffs' petition for attorneys' fees and litigation expenses to U.S. Magistrate Judge Joel C. Hoppe.
About a month later, the court stayed briefing on the issue of attorney’s fees and litigation expenses while waiting to see if the defendant would appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court.
Trials.value: On August 30, 2023, district court referred fees petition to Magistrate Judge Hoppe and, about a month later, stayed briefing pending potential Supreme Court appeal.

evidences: On December 23, 2023, the defendant filed a notice of appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court.

evidences: The case was argued on October 8, 2024, and Chief Justice Roberts issued the Court’s majority opinion on February 25, 2025.

Chief Justice Roberts reversed the Fourth Circuit’s en banc opinion and held that the plaintiffs did not qualify as “prevailing parties” and, thus, were not eligible for attorney’s fees under § 1988(b). 2025 WL 594737.

evidences: Under the Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA), the Department, through IES, is charged with conducting, assessing, collecting, and disseminating research about education practices and policies in the U.S.
"Through IES and its Centers, Congress sought to improve both the quantity and quality of educational data collection."

evidences: On March 20, 2025, President Trump signed Executive Order 14,242, titled "Improving Education Outcomes by Empowering Parents, States, and Communities."

In this order, President Trump instructed the Secretary "to the maximum extent appropriate and permitted by law, [to] take all necessary steps to facilitate the closure of the Department of Education."
Factual Basis of Case.value: Executive Order 14,242 (Mar. 20, 2025) directed the Secretary to take steps, to the extent permitted by law, to facilitate closure of the Department of Education.

evidences: In keeping with this directive, the Department canceled most of IES's contracts with independent contractors that it used to collect, analyze, and publish educational data.
On March 11, the Department also announced a Reduction in Force of nearly 50% of its workforce.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Agency actions: The Department canceled most IES contracts used to collect/analyze/publish educational data and announced a nearly 50% Reduction in Force.

evidences: On May 2, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, telling the court that any delay in granting relief would cause them irreparable harm, given the President's directives to the Department.

evidences: On May 5, the defendants moved for a stay.

The defendants pointed to another related case that was also assigned to Judge McFadden, Association for Education Finance and Policy v. McMahon, [../../../../case/46342/] arguing that since the plaintiffs in both cases had moved for preliminary injunctions seeking identical relief, the court here should stay the proceedings until a decision was reached in the other case on the preliminary injunction.
On May 6, Judge McFadden denied the defendants' motion for a stay.
Judge McFadden said that the defendants had only argued that they would suffer hardship from having to litigate two similar cases at the same time, which does not warrant a stay.
Furthermore, the judge said that comity concerns do not exist in this case, since both matters were before the same court, rather than before courts in different jurisdictions.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Stay motion: Defendants sought a stay based on a related case; the court denied the stay (May 6), finding litigation hardship insufficient and no comity concerns since both matters were before the same court.

evidences: On May 19, the judge held a hearing on the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.
The court denied the plaintiffs' motion on June 3, finding that the plaintiffs were "seeking wholesale correction of general agency operations and bundling together claims to pursue outsized relief."

Rather than bringing a claim against a discrete agency action as required by the APA, the plaintiffs were challenging a programmatic decision, the reduction of workforce and services by the Department.
Therefore, the court found that the plaintiffs were not bringing a justiciable claim under the APA, dooming their request for a preliminary injunction based on the APA.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Preliminary injunction ruling: After a May 19 hearing, the court denied the motion on June 3, holding the APA claims were non-justiciable because they challenged programmatic decisions rather than discrete actions.

evidences: Turning to the plaintiffs' constitutional claims, the court also found them deficient, stating that "if every statutory compliance issue triggered separation of powers concerns, virtually all APA cases would balloon into disputes of constitutional proportions."
Instead, the plaintiffs' constitutional claims in this case were simply statutory violation claims in disguise.
Therefore, the court found that the plaintiffs failed to state a plausible claim for relief under the Constitution.
Given these deficiencies, the court said the plaintiffs were unlikely to prevail on the merits of their claims and denied their request for a preliminary injunction. 2025 WL 1568301.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Constitutional claims: The court found them deficient (statutory claims in disguise), concluded plaintiffs were unlikely to succeed on the merits, and denied the preliminary injunction.

plaintiffs—immigrant youth under the age of 21 who applied for Special Immigrant Juvenile status (“SIJ”)—filed a class action lawsuit in the Western District of Washington on behalf of themselves and those similarly situated to challenge the Trump Administration’s policy of refusing to adjudicate their SIJ petitions in accordance with the Immigration and Nationality Act (“INA”).

These actions, the complaint claimed, were in violation of the INA’s text. Plaintiffs, thus, sought declaratory and injunctive relief to enjoin this unlawful agency action under the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”). Plaintiffs also alleged, under the APA, that the agency action was arbitrary and capricious; that the new policy was promulgated without notice-and-comment rulemaking; and that action could not be unreasonably delayed beyond the 180 day statutory deadline.
Cause of Action.value: Administrative Procedure Act (APA) claims challenging USCIS’s SIJ policy as contrary to the INA, arbitrary and capricious, unlawfully adopted without notice-and-comment, and unreasonably delayed beyond the 180-day statutory deadline.

evidences: Due to the defendant’s duty to adjudicate applications without unreasonable delay, the plaintiffs further sought a writ of mandamus to compel a federal official or agency to adjudicate SIJ applications.
Cause of Action.value: Writ of mandamus to compel USCIS/DHS to adjudicate SIJ applications without unreasonable delay.

evidences: The plaintiffs were represented by the Northwest Immigrant Rights Project.
The case was assigned to Judge Robert S. Lasnik.
On July 17, 2019, the court certified the class. 2019 WL 3219418.

The court ordered the defendants to adjudicate outstanding SIJ petitions and to readjudicate cases that were denied on grounds that state courts did not have jurisdiction to “reunify” an immigrant with their parents. 387 F.Supp.3d 1208.
However, on August 23, the court denied the motion for reconsideration, citing that the defendants offered no new facts or legal authority that would justify reconsideration. 2019 WL 3996850.
The injunction, though, permitted SIJ petitioners to “toll” the deadline to respond to a request for evidence. 492 F.Supp.3d 1169.
As such, this portion of the injunction was vacated. 52 F.4th 821.

Dates of All Decrees.value: July 17, 2019: The court certified the class and granted a preliminary injunction ordering defendants to adjudicate outstanding SIJ petitions and to readjudicate cases denied on reunification-jurisdiction grounds.

evidences: However, on August 23, the court denied the motion for reconsideration, citing that the defendants offered no new facts or legal authority that would justify reconsideration. 2019 WL 3996850.

evidences: Back in district court, the plaintiffs then filed a motion for summary judgment on May 1, 2020, which included a request for permanent injunctive relief.

The court granted summary judgment on October 5, finding that the reunification requirement was arbitrary and capricious and that the delays in adjudication were plainly unlawful as Congress unambiguously intended the adjudication to be expeditious, providing a clear and mandatory deadline of 180 days.

The court also entered a permanent injunction, specifically with regard to adjudication timelines. The court ordered the defendants to adjudicate any SIJ petitions based on a Washington state court order within 180 days of the date that the application was filed by the petitioner. The injunction, though, permitted SIJ petitioners to “toll” the deadline to respond to a request for evidence. 492 F.Supp.3d 1169.
Dates of All Decrees.value: October 5: The court granted summary judgment and entered a permanent injunction requiring adjudication within 180 days (with tolling for responses to requests for evidence).

evidences: The Ninth Circuit entered judgment on November 3, 2022, affirming in part and vacating in part the district court’s opinion.
As such, this portion of the injunction was vacated. 52 F.4th 821.
Dates of All Decrees.value: November 3, 2022: The Ninth Circuit entered judgment affirming in part and vacating in part; it vacated the injunction’s tolling provision.

evidences: Following the Ninth Circuit’s official mandate on February 10, 2023, the parties were ordered to submit a joint status report prior to July, proposing amendments to the permanent injunction consistent with the Ninth Circuit's order.
Dates of All Decrees.value: February 10, 2023: The Ninth Circuit issued its mandate.

evidences: An amended permanent injunction was then entered by the district court on September 22, and stated as follows:

“Defendants must adjudicate any SIJ petitions based on a Washington state court order within 180 days of the date that the application is filed by the petitioner… This timeline is inclusive of any requests for additional evidence or notices of intent to deny that USCIS may issue to a petitioner. USCIS must provide SIJ petitioners with sufficient time prior to the expiration of the 180 days to respond to the request/notice in an effort to complete final adjudication of the SIJ petition in a timely manner. USCIS may not use the issuance of a request for information or notice of intent to deny for the sole purpose of avoiding the statutory deadline for adjudication of an SIJ petition.”
Dates of All Decrees.value: September 22: The district court entered an amended permanent injunction imposing a 180-day adjudication timeline inclusive of RFEs/NOIDs and prohibiting use of those requests to evade the deadline.

evidences: On March 5, 2019, plaintiffs—immigrant youth under the age of 21 who applied for Special Immigrant Juvenile status (“SIJ”)—filed a class action lawsuit in the Western District of Washington on behalf of themselves and those similarly situated to challenge the Trump Administration’s policy of refusing to adjudicate their SIJ petitions in accordance with the Immigration and Nationality Act (“INA”).
Factual Basis of Case.value: On March 5, 2019, immigrant youth under 21 who applied for SIJ filed a class action in the Western District of Washington challenging the Trump Administration’s refusal to adjudicate SIJ petitions in accordance with the INA.

evidences: “All individuals who have been issued predicate SIJS orders by Washington state courts after turning eighteen years old but prior to turning twenty-one years old, and have submitted or will submit SIJS petitions to USCIS prior to turning twenty-one years old.”
Factual Basis of Case.value: Proposed class: individuals with Washington state predicate SIJ orders issued after age 18 and before 21 who submitted (or will submit) SIJ petitions to USCIS before turning 21.

evidences: the complaint alleged that USCIS began denying SIJ applications unless petitioners could show that a state court had the power to return the youth to the custody of their parents.
Factual Basis of Case.value: USCIS implemented a policy denying SIJ applications unless petitioners proved a state court had authority to return them to parental custody.

evidences: This resulted in USCIS denying petitions to applicants after turning 18 but before the age of 21.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Effect of policy: denials targeted applicants aged 18 to under 21.

evidences: USCIS also delayed the adjudications of numerous applications.
Factual Basis of Case.value: USCIS delayed adjudication of numerous SIJ applications.

evidences: These actions, the complaint claimed, were in violation of the INA’s text.

Plaintiffs also alleged, under the APA, that the agency action was arbitrary and capricious; that the new policy was promulgated without notice-and-comment rulemaking; and that action could not be unreasonably delayed beyond the 180 day statutory deadline.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Plaintiffs alleged the denials policy and delays violated the INA and the APA (arbitrary and capricious; no notice-and-comment; delays beyond a 180-day statutory deadline).

evidences: Due to the defendant’s duty to adjudicate applications without unreasonable delay, the plaintiffs further sought a writ of mandamus to compel a federal official or agency to adjudicate SIJ applications.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background: Plaintiffs asserted defendants have a duty to adjudicate without unreasonable delay and sought mandamus to compel adjudication.

evidences: The court granted summary judgment on October 5, finding that the reunification requirement was arbitrary and capricious and that the delays in adjudication were plainly unlawful as Congress unambiguously intended the adjudication to be expeditious, providing a clear and mandatory deadline of 180 days.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Court finding confirming factual basis: the reunification requirement was arbitrary and capricious, and adjudication delays violated Congress’s clear 180-day deadline.

evidences: The court ordered the defendants to adjudicate any SIJ petitions based on a Washington state court order within 180 days of the date that the application was filed by the petitioner.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Statutory/timing background applied: SIJ petitions based on Washington state court orders must be adjudicated within 180 days of filing.

evidences: According to the Ninth Circuit panel, the tolling provisions of the injunction were not narrowly tailored to remedy the harm and did not contemplate USCIS’s relevant regulations.
Factual Basis of Case.value: The Ninth Circuit found the tolling provisions overly broad and not aligned with USCIS regulations.

evidences: On March 5, 2019, plaintiffs—immigrant youth under the age of 21 who applied for Special Immigrant Juvenile status (“SIJ”)—filed a class action lawsuit in the Western District of Washington on behalf of themselves and those similarly situated to challenge the Trump Administration’s policy of refusing to adjudicate their SIJ petitions in accordance with the Immigration and Nationality Act (“INA”).

Filed against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (“DHS”), U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (“USCIS”), and their respective directors, the complaint alleged that USCIS began denying SIJ applications unless petitioners could show that a state court had the power to return the youth to the custody of their parents.
USCIS also delayed the adjudications of numerous applications.
Plaintiffs, thus, sought declaratory and injunctive relief to enjoin this unlawful agency action under the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”).

Plaintiffs also alleged, under the APA, that the agency action was arbitrary and capricious; that the new policy was promulgated without notice-and-comment rulemaking; and that action could not be unreasonably delayed beyond the 180 day statutory deadline.

Due to the defendant’s duty to adjudicate applications without unreasonable delay, the plaintiffs further sought a writ of mandamus to compel a federal official or agency to adjudicate SIJ applications.
The plaintiffs were represented by the Northwest Immigrant Rights Project.
The case was assigned to Judge Robert S. Lasnik.
Trials.value: Case filed Mar 5, 2019 in W.D. Wash.; defendants DHS/USCIS; claims under APA/INA and mandamus; assigned to Judge Robert S. Lasnik; represented by NWIRP.

It distinguished the case from the Supreme Court’s decision in Aleman Gonzalez, emphasizing that the specific provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) at issue did not bar injunctive relief.

USCIS may not use the issuance of a request for information or notice of intent to deny for the sole purpose of avoiding the statutory deadline for adjudication of an SIJ petition.”
Court Rulings.value: On September 22, 2023, the district court entered an amended permanent injunction implementing the Ninth Circuit’s mandate, specifying the 180-day adjudication timeline is inclusive of RFEs/NOIDs and restricting use of RFEs/NOIDs to avoid the deadline.

evidences: Plaintiffs then filed a motion for attorney’s fees and costs on December 14, 2023.
On May 22, 2024, the court preliminarily approved the settlement agreement and scheduled a final approval hearing on the matter for September.
On September 5, 2024, the final settlement agreement was approved, whereby the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs $400,000.
Court Rulings.value: Attorneys’ fees: On May 22, 2024, the court preliminarily approved the parties’ settlement; on September 5, 2024, the court granted final approval, with defendants to pay $400,000.

evidences: Briefing deadlines on the matter were extended on multiple occasions as settlement negotiations on the matter continued.

evidences: Involuntarily unhoused residents of the City of San Rafael, California, filed this lawsuit pro se on August 11, 2023, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, requested a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction to stop the City of San Rafael from enforcing ordinances that the plaintiffs alleged criminalized homelessness by making “camping” on public property a criminal offense.
They sued the City of San Rafael and its Chief of Police under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Americans with Disabilities Act.

The case was assigned to Judge Edward M. Chen.
on June 14, Judge Edward M. Chen issued an order conditionally granting the City’s emergency motion for limited relief from the injunction.
On August 15, 2023, Judge Trina Thompson held a hearing on the plaintiffs’ request for a temporary restraining order.
The following day, she granted the motion for a temporary restraining order, enjoining the city from enforcing the ordinance until a hearing on the preliminary injunction could be held.
The plaintiffs were ten unhoused individuals and Camp Integrity, an unincorporated association of people and property where the unhoused individual plaintiffs lived.
The plaintiffs filed a first amended complaint on September 26, 2023, adding as plaintiffs two additional individuals and the San Rafael Homeless Union.
Class Action or Individual Plaintiffs.value: Plaintiffs: Individual, described as ten unhoused individuals and Camp Integrity (an unincorporated association); later, two additional individuals and the San Rafael Homeless Union were added

evidences: The following day, she granted the motion for a temporary restraining order, enjoining the city from enforcing the ordinance until a hearing on the preliminary injunction could be held.
The court extended the temporary restraining order on September 7, 2023.
How Long Decrees will Last.value: Until a hearing on the preliminary injunction could be held (later extended on September 7, 2023): Temporary restraining order enjoining the City from enforcing the ordinance.

evidences: The court held a hearing for the motion on the preliminary injunction on October 2 and 3 and granted in part and denied in part the preliminary injunction on October 19.

The court permitted the City to enforce the ordinance but required the City to: allow 400 square feet campsites housing up to four people that were 100 feet apart; provide assistance to campers who needed to move to a designated space; provide replacements to plaintiffs who did not have tents or bedding that could fit within the compliant space; designate the permissible campsites that complied with the ordinance as modified by the preliminary injunction on street level maps; establish a registration process so campers could find permitted campsites; and not evict or prosecute any plaintiff who submitted a request for a reasonable accommodation based on disability unless they were provided with due process. There was also a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations. The preliminary injunction applied only to residents of the encampment who had standing under this lawsuit as named plaintiffs or as members of the San Rafael Homeless Union.
On August 7, 2024, the court granted defendants’ motion to dismiss and dissolved the preliminary injunction.
How Long Decrees will Last.value: October 19, 2023 to August 7, 2024: Preliminary injunction (granted in part and denied in part) permitting the City to enforce the ordinance but requiring: 400 sq. ft. campsites for up to four people spaced 100 feet apart; assistance to campers to move to designated spaces; replacements for tents/bedding to fit within compliant space; designation of permissible campsites on street-level maps; a registration process; no eviction or prosecution of any plaintiff who submitted a reasonable accommodation request based on disability unless provided due process; and a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations. Applied only to named plaintiffs and members of the San Rafael Homeless Union.

evidences: On May 6, 2024, the City amended the ordinance in response to the Court’s preliminary injunction. The amended ordinance allowed campties of 200 square feet for one person and 400 square feet for four individuals, a 10-foot setback from other campsites, and a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations.

evidences: filed this lawsuit pro se on August 11, 2023, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California
Factual Basis of Case.value: Filed pro se on August 11, 2023, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.

evidences: The plaintiffs were ten unhoused individuals and Camp Integrity, an unincorporated association of people and property where the unhoused individual plaintiffs lived.
They sued the City of San Rafael and its Chief of Police
Factual Basis of Case.value: Parties: Plaintiffs were ten unhoused individuals and Camp Integrity; Defendants were the City of San Rafael and its Chief of Police.

evidences: They sued the City of San Rafael and its Chief of Police under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Americans with Disabilities Act.
Plaintiffs alleged that the City’s ordinance violated their rights under the First, Eighth, Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Americans with Disabilities Act.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Legal bases: 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and ADA; alleged violations of the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments and the ADA.

evidences: requested a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction to stop the City of San Rafael from enforcing ordinances that the plaintiffs alleged criminalized homelessness by making “camping” on public property a criminal offense.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Relief sought: TRO and preliminary injunction to halt enforcement of ordinances criminalizing camping on public property.

evidences: The plaintiffs argued that the ordinances criminalized survival activities, including eating and possessing public belongings in public spaces, and unconstitutionally targeted unhoused individuals while permitting identical conduct by people who had housing.

They further argued that the ordinances criminalized homelessness by banning sleeping on public property while the City of San Rafael failed to provide enough alternative shelter for the City’s homeless population.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Alleged facts: Ordinances criminalized survival activities and sleeping on public property without sufficient alternative shelter, and targeted unhoused people compared to housed individuals.

evidences: Camp Integrity, an unincorporated association of people and property where the unhoused individual plaintiffs lived.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Background: Plaintiffs lived at an encampment known as Camp Integrity.

evidences: The case was assigned to Judge Edward M. Chen.
On August 15, 2023, Judge Trina Thompson held a hearing on the plaintiffs’ request for a temporary restraining order.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Judicial assignment/background: case assigned to Judge Edward M. Chen; initial TRO hearing held by Judge Trina Thompson.

evidences: On August 15, 2023, Judge Trina Thompson held a hearing on the plaintiffs’ request for a temporary restraining order. The following day, she granted the motion for a temporary restraining order, enjoining the city from enforcing the ordinance until a hearing on the preliminary injunction could be held.

The court determined that the plaintiffs sufficiently showed that they were likely to suffer irreparable injury if the ordinance went into effect, that the plaintiffs would endure serious hardships under the ordinance, that temporary relief would serve the public interest, and that there were “serious questions” on the merits of the case.
Factual Basis of Case.value: TRO granted on August 16, 2023, enjoining enforcement; court found likely irreparable injury, serious hardships, public interest served, and serious questions on the merits.

evidences: On September 6, 2023, the court held a non-evidentiary hearing on the preliminary injunction and the defendant officials of the City of San Rafael were served. The court extended the temporary restraining order on September 7, 2023.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Preliminary injunction non-evidentiary hearing held on September 6, 2023; TRO extended on September 7, 2023.

evidences: The plaintiffs filed a first amended complaint on September 26, 2023, adding as plaintiffs two additional individuals and the San Rafael Homeless Union.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Amended complaint added two more individuals and the San Rafael Homeless Union as plaintiffs.

evidences: The court permitted the City to enforce the ordinance but required the City to: allow 400 square feet campsites housing up to four people that were 100 feet apart; provide assistance to campers who needed to move to a designated space; provide replacements to plaintiffs who did not have tents or bedding that could fit within the compliant space; designate the permissible campsites that complied with the ordinance as modified by the preliminary injunction on street level maps; establish a registration process so campers could find permitted campsites; and not evict or prosecute any plaintiff who submitted a request for a reasonable accommodation based on disability unless they were provided with due process.
There was also a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations.
The preliminary injunction applied only to residents of the encampment who had standing under this lawsuit as named plaintiffs or as members of the San Rafael Homeless Union.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Preliminary injunction (granted in part) allowed enforcement but imposed conditions: campsite size/spacing, relocation assistance, replacement tents/bedding, mapped designated sites, registration process, due process for ADA accommodations, and mens rea requirement; limited to named plaintiffs and SR Homeless Union members.

evidences: On October 26, 2023, one of the named plaintiffs filed an ex parte motion seeking a temporary restraining order to stop the defendants from disrupting his campsite and arresting him for using a pallet under his tent as a foundation. The City opposed the plaintiff’s motion.
On November 1, 2023, the court held a status conference and a hearing on the temporary restraining order, which the court denied the following day.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Named plaintiff alleged disruption/arrest threat over a pallet under his tent; court denied the requested TRO on November 2, 2023.

evidences: The court held additional settlement conferences monthly from November 2023 until May 2024.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Settlement conferences occurred monthly from November 2023 to May 2024.

evidences: On May 6, 2024, the City amended the ordinance in response to the Court’s preliminary injunction.

The amended ordinance allowed campties of 200 square feet for one person and 400 square feet for four individuals, a 10-foot setback from other campsites, and a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations.
Factual Basis of Case.value: On May 6, 2024, the City amended the ordinance to allow 200 sq ft for one person, 400 sq ft for four, a 10-foot setback, and a mens rea requirement.

evidences: Subsequently, the City filed a motion to dismiss the case, or alternatively, to dissolve the preliminary injunction, on May 10, 2024.
Factual Basis of Case.value: City moved to dismiss or dissolve the preliminary injunction on May 10, 2024.

evidences: The City then filed a motion for limited relief from the injunction on June 12, 2024 under F.R.C.P. 60(b), as it sought to relocate ten to eleven individuals camping along Francisco Boulevard West in light of alleged fire risks to their encampment.
on June 14, Judge Edward M. Chen issued an order conditionally granting the City’s emergency motion for limited relief from the injunction.
the court concluded that moving the individuals from the encampment would be permissible.
Factual Basis of Case.value: In June 2024, due to alleged fire risks at Francisco Boulevard West, the City sought and obtained conditional relief to relocate 10–11 individuals; the court deemed relocation permissible after weighing harms and safety.

evidences: The court held settlement conferences at the beginning and end of July 2024.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Settlement conferences were also held at the beginning and end of July 2024.

evidences: On August 7, 2024, the court granted defendants’ motion to dismiss and dissolved the preliminary injunction.

The court determined that the plaintiffs had not shown a reasonable expectation that the government would reenact its regulation, that the ordinance as amended on May 6, 2024 did not raise the same issues as the original ordinance, and that because the amended ordinance had given the relief sought, the case was now moot.
Therefore, the court no longer had jurisdiction to maintain the preliminary injunction, which was rendered moot as well. As of December 2024, this case is closed.
Factual Basis of Case.value: Case dismissed on August 7, 2024 as moot due to amended ordinance providing relief and no reasonable expectation of reenactment; preliminary injunction dissolved; case closed by December 2024.

Court Rulings.value: Sept 7, 2023: Court extended the temporary restraining order.

evidences: The court held a hearing for the motion on the preliminary injunction on October 2 and 3 and granted in part and denied in part the preliminary injunction on October 19.

The court permitted the City to enforce the ordinance but required the City to: allow 400 square feet campsites housing up to four people that were 100 feet apart; provide assistance to campers who needed to move to a designated space; provide replacements to plaintiffs who did not have tents or bedding that could fit within the compliant space; designate the permissible campsites that complied with the ordinance as modified by the preliminary injunction on street level maps; establish a registration process so campers could find permitted campsites; and not evict or prosecute any plaintiff who submitted a request for a reasonable accommodation based on disability unless they were provided with due process.
There was also a mens rea requirement for violating camping regulations.
The preliminary injunction applied only to residents of the encampment who had standing under this lawsuit as named plaintiffs or as members of the San Rafael Homeless Union.
Court Rulings.value: Oct 19, 2023: Court granted in part and denied in part the preliminary injunction—allowed City to enforce the ordinance but imposed conditions (e.g., 400 sq. ft. sites for up to 4 people spaced 100 ft apart, assistance to relocate, replacement tents/bedding to comply, mapping and registration of permissible sites, due process for those requesting ADA accommodations, and a mens rea requirement). Limited to named plaintiffs and San Rafael Homeless Union members.

evidences: On October 26, 2023, one of the named plaintiffs filed an ex parte motion seeking a temporary restraining order to stop the defendants from disrupting his campsite and arresting him for using a pallet under his tent as a foundation.
On November 1, 2023, the court held a status conference and a hearing on the temporary restraining order, which the court denied the following day.
Court Rulings.value: Nov 2, 2023: Court denied a named plaintiff’s ex parte motion for a temporary restraining order regarding alleged disruption/arrest over use of a pallet under his tent.

evidences: Subsequently, the City filed a motion to dismiss the case, or alternatively, to dissolve the preliminary injunction, on May 10, 2024.
On August 7, 2024, the court granted defendants’ motion to dismiss and dissolved the preliminary injunction.

The court determined that the plaintiffs had not shown a reasonable expectation that the government would reenact its regulation, that the ordinance as amended on May 6, 2024 did not raise the same issues as the original ordinance, and that because the amended ordinance had given the relief sought, the case was now moot.
Therefore, the court no longer had jurisdiction to maintain the preliminary injunction, which was rendered moot as well.
Court Rulings.value: Aug 7, 2024: Court granted defendants’ motion to dismiss and dissolved the preliminary injunction on mootness grounds (amended ordinance provided relief; no reasonable expectation of reenactment), and thus lacked jurisdiction to maintain the PI.

evidences: The City then filed a motion for limited relief from the injunction on June 12, 2024 under F.R.C.P. 60(b), as it sought to relocate ten to eleven individuals camping along Francisco Boulevard West in light of alleged fire risks to their encampment.
The court held hearings on June 13 and June 14, 2024, and on June 14, Judge Edward M. Chen issued an order conditionally granting the City’s emergency motion for limited relief from the injunction.

The court explained that it was an issue of fact whether any of the individuals whom the City sought to relocate from Francisco Boulevard West were covered by the preliminary injunction in this case, and after weighing the likelihood of irreparable injury, the balance of hardships, and the health and safety risks, the court concluded that moving the individuals from the encampment would be permissible.
Court Rulings.value: June 14, 2024: Judge Edward M. Chen conditionally granted the City’s emergency Rule 60(b) motion for limited relief from the preliminary injunction to relocate 10–11 individuals on Francisco Boulevard West due to fire risks, after weighing irreparable injury, hardships, and health/safety risks.
